Before you go to YouTube
We use cookies and data to:
- Google services delivery and maintenance
- Opt-out content and protection against spam, fraud and abuse
- Measure target group engagement and site statistics to gain insight into how our services are used and improve the quality of services
If you accept everything, we also use cookies and data for the following:
- New services developed and improved
- Ad latency viewing and measuring the effectiveness of the experience
- Personalized content display (depending on your settings)
- Personalized ad latency viewing (depending on your settings)
If you select All, we do not use cookies for these additional purposes.
Non-personalized content and advertisements influence the moment you view and your location by factors such as the content (for ads, your general location is used). Personalized content and ads include, for example, video recommendations, a customized YouTube homepage and targeted ads based on previous activity, such as the videos you watch and the items you search for on YouTube. We also use cookies and data to ensure that the functionality is selected for your lifetime, if relevant.
Select More options to view more information, including information about how you control your privacy settings. You can also always go to g.co/privacytools.

title: Increased in Special Perils Take Up Rate - Renew Allianz Insurance Online
author: Admin
description: The Special Perils is an additional coverage which motorist can opt for to cover from loss or damage caused by natural disasters such as floods, storms, earthquakes, landslides and so on.
text:
![](https://allianz.renewinsurance.my/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/car-flooded-1024x768.jpg)
The Special Perils is an additional coverage which motorist can opt for to cover from loss or damage caused by natural disasters such as floods, storms, earthquakes, landslides and so on. The actual policy wording is:
“In consideration of the additional premium that You paid Us for this endorsement, We agree that the insurance provided under Section A of this Policy will cover loss or damage to Your Car caused by flood, typhoon, hurricane, storm, tempest, volcanic eruption, earthquake, landslide, landslip, subsidence or sinking of the soil / earth or other convulsions of nature.”
The take up rate for Special Perils coverage has increased steady from 11% to 22% according to Allianz General Insurance.
One of the reasons for a higher take up rate is due to the massive flood in Dec 2021 where many motorists are caught off guard and witness their vehicles being damaged by the flood. Secondly, more motorist are now willing to add-on Special Perils coverage due to the reduction in premium. Special Perils rate has been reduced tremendously by more than 50%. From a rate of 0.5% of sum insured to 0.2%. Thus, a vehicle with a sum coverage of RM80,000, the premium for including Special Perils would be RM160.
Many a times, a motorist would opt for the cheapest premium without considering any add-on coverage, not knowing that there are certain events that the standard motor insurance does not cover. When there is a storm or heavy rain and assuming your car was damages due to falling tree, the damage will not be covered under your standard comprehensive insurance, unless you have add-on for Special Perils.
Thus, with the reduction in the premium rate for Special Perils, it is advisable to add-on when you renew your insurance. If you have recently renewed your car insurance and wish to add-on now for Special Perils, you may contact your agent to assist you to pass an endorsement.

description: GEORGE TOWN: Leave your car as it is in the event it gets trapped in a flood.
text:

GEORGE TOWN: Leave your car as it is in the event it gets trapped in a flood.
Trying to start the engine after the floodwaters recede can cost you thousands of ringgit in repairs.

title: M’sians, Check Out These Flood Aids You Can Apply For!
author: Nursabihah Zainuddin Updated
description: If you or a family member are up in the mud with the recent flooding, have a look at these available flood aids.
text:
Here's a comprehensive guide to the assistance available
1. Bantuan Wang Ihsan (BWI) up to RM1,000 for households
Image source: eCentral
In order to get this aid, you’d have to register for it first. BWI will only be given to each Malaysian Head of Household (Ketua rumah).
You’re still able to apply even if you are renting a house. The only difference is that your landlord wouldn’t be able to apply for it.
Here’s how to apply for BWI:
-
Download and print the application form from the government’s website.
-
Submit the form to the Jabatan Kebajikan Masyarakat (JKM) or Angkatan Pertahanan Awam Malaysia (APM) at Temporary Placement Centres (PPS).
-
For further assistance, you can visit your District Office or refer to your State Disaster Management Committee (Jawatankuasa Pengurusan Bencana Negeri, JPBN).
For claims related to deaths caused by floods, additional forms and proof of kinship are required.
If you’re still feeling in the dark about this, you can click here or call the MyGCC Hotline at 03-8000-8000 for more information.
2. Bantuan Banjir Zakat Selangor
For residents in Selangor, the Bantuan Banjir Zakat Selangor offers a one-off payment to ease the burden on asnaf (poor, needy, and converts) affected by floods.
Application Process:
-
Apply online via the Zakat Selangor portal (apply here).
-
Ensure eligibility by meeting these criteria:
-
Muslim, Malaysian citizen.
-
Born or residing in Selangor for at least three years.
-
Income threshold based on Haddul Kifayah calculations.
-
For more details and document downloads, visit the Zakat Selangor Website.
3. Program Prihatin Banjir
Bank Islam Malaysia Bhd has relaunched its Prihatin Banjir Program, offering relief for affected customers, including a six-month deferment on loan repayments for eligible financing types such as home, personal, and vehicle loans.
Here’s how you can apply:
-
Get the application form on the official Bank Islam website, or you can visit any Bank Islam branch near you
-
Prepare your supporting document (1) of the following:
-
Confirmation letter from ADUN (Ahli Dewan Undangan Negeri).
-
Letter from a Ketua Kampung or Penghulu.
-
Verification from the JKKK (Jawatankuasa Kemajuan & Keselamatan Kampung).
-
Letter from related agencies, such as NADMA (Agensi Pengurusan Bencana Negara) or MKN (Majlis Keselamatan Negara).
-
A police report detailing the damage caused by the flood.
-
Submit your completed form and required documents to the nearest Bank Islam branch
4. CIMB Flood Relief Assistance
In response to the recent floods, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd has introduced a Flood Relief Assistance offering a six-month payment relief on loan and financing products to help alleviate the financial burden of individuals, SMEs, and micro-SMEs.
How to apply:
-
Individual customers: Call CIMB’s Contact Centre at +603 6204 7788 or visit a branch.
-
SMEs: Apply online at CIMB Flood Relief Assistance Plan.
-
Corporate and Non-SME customers: Reach out to your CIMB Relationship Manager.
Stay protected and informed
Lastly, always make sure your vehicle is properly insured. If you're not sure which insurance provides additional protection for natural disasters, visit our car insurance page and get a quote right away or click on the image below.
We hope this article helps to lessen the burden with the available aids. The important thing here is to always be up to date with your local authorities and call the necessary parties to ensure that you do not miss out on these aids.
For more information, you can visit the gomen’s flood aid website.
*The above article is intended for informational purposes only. Loanstreet accepts no responsibility for loss that may arise from reliance on information contained in the articles.

title: Over 63,000 rubber ducks were dumped into the Chicago River for charity | CNN
author: Lauren M Johnson
description: If you peered into the Chicago River on Thursday, you might have thought it had rained rubber duckies, but it was actually Chicago’s 14th annual Ducky Derby.
text:
If you peered into the Chicago River on Thursday, you might have thought it had rained rubber duckies, but it was actually Chicago’s 14th annual Ducky Derby.
![Rubber ducks are dropped into the Chicago River to start the annual Ducky Derby.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/190808181038-01-chicago-duck-derby-2019.jpg?q=w_1110,c_fill)
Exactly 63,133 rubber ducks were dumped into the river at the Wabash Bridge to raise money for the Illinois Special Olympics, according to the organization. Last year, the derby raised over $425,000 for the charity.
Competitors buy ducks, paying $5 for one or up to $1,000 for 240.
The iconic bath toys race down the Chicago River to win prizes for their owners, depending on how they place. This year, the winners got a 2019 Chevy Equinox, $2,500, an all-inclusive vacation to the Riviera Maya, a Chicago weekend getaway or NASCAR tickets.
![The ducks are corralled along the river.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/190808165636-rubber-ducks-chicago-river.jpg?q=w_1110,c_fill)
Spectators watch from above and cheer on their ducks as they make their way to the finish line.
After the race, the ducks are collected and reused for future races.
image_caption: The ducks are corralled along the river.;The ducks are corralled along the river.;Rubber ducks float down the Chicago River during the 14th Annual Ducky Derby, on August 8, 2018 in Chicago, Illinois. - The charity event helps to raise money for Special Olympics Illinois.

title: Crossed Fingers
author: David Mikkelson
description: The definitive Internet reference source for researching urban legends, folklore, myths, rumors, and misinformation.
text:
David Mikkelson founded the site now known as snopes.com back in 1994 as a creative outgrowth of his wide-ranging interests in a variety of subjects (particularly folklore) and his professional expertise in the computer industry. Handling everything from researching and writing articles about urban legends to managing the site’s technical infrastructure, David saw snopes.com (which antedated the development of automated search engines) quickly become the go-to place for Internet users to query about anything questionable they encountered online, establishing it as the oldest and best known online fact-checking outlet operating today.
David’s educational background includes a B.S. in Computer Science from the University of Texas (San Antonio) and about a zillion course hours of post-graduate classes at California State University Northridge taken with no particular degree program in mind. His previous employment encompassed stints with the News-Chronicle (newspaper), Teledyne Electronics, USPS, JPL, Digital Equipment Corporation, Rocketdyne, and Health Net (HMO).

title: Mexico | America | elmundo.es
author: Internet Editorial Unit
description: A Los Zetas training camp has been dismantled Sixty soldiers attacked the camp from the air and the ground. In the operation, a hit man died and an arsenal was seized.
text:
World leader in Spanish
Tue. 11/05/10. Updated 7:35 p.m. (GMT-5)
ARMY OPERATION | Criminals have fled
Part of the arsenal seized in the dismantling of the Los Zetas camp. | Efe
Sixty soldiers attacked a training camp of the 'Los Zetas' cartel in Nuevo León this Tuesday from helicopters and ground vehicles. During the operation, a hit man died and an arsenal was seized: more than 230 long and short weapons, 60 grenades and rocket launchers, as well as vans and communication systems.
Four Mexican Air Force helicopters arrived at the Los Zetas camp, located in a rural area of the municipality of Higueras, 45 kilometers northeast of Monterrey, the capital of Nuevo León. “Around 50 assassins who were in the camp began to flee when they heard helicopter engines,” said a military source.
From the air, the military shot at some of the gunmen and others were chased by personnel who arrived by land at the camp. One of the criminals fell dead 500 meters from the camp, after soldiers discovered him hiding in the trees. The rest of the assassins managed to flee into a mountainous area near the camp.
The Los Zetas cartel, which emerged from elite military deserters, is one of the most violent groups in the country and originally served as the armed wing of the powerful Gulf drug cartel, for which it murdered rivals, police and military personnel.
At the beginning of this year, that alliance broke down and now the Gulf and Los Zetas are fighting a bloody war, mainly in the states of Nuevo León and its neighbor of Tamaulipas, in the Gulf of Mexico.
On the other hand, the State Attorney General, Alejandro Garza y Garza, has reported that there are already 12 municipal police officers in Monterrey arrested this Tuesday by Army personnel to be investigated for their alleged relationship with organized crime gangs.
image_caption: Part of the arsenal seized in the dismantling of the Los Zetas camp. | Efe

title: Mexico cartels: The most violent drug cartel in Mexico. The history of the Los Zetas group
text:
The most violent drug cartel in Mexico. The history of the Los Zetas group
About 40 years ago, in the 1980s, Mexico's criminal world began to flourish again. During this period, criminals, primarily those involved in drug trafficking, began to organize into large groups, creating extensive networks for the production, transportation and sale of “substances” of various kinds. All this has led to competition and widespread conflicts for the right to control territories.
The explosive growth in drug trafficking in Mexico was partly due to the victory of the US authorities over the Colombian mafia. More precisely, the US was able to destroy the cocaine supply channels from Colombia to the United States, which led to “unemployment” among Mexican couriers who specialized in transporting drugs.
Then there was an increase in the number of “drug businessmen” in Mexico, which was unable to cope with the new scourge, including due to the high level of corruption in all echelons of power.
Heroin, cocaine, marijuana, synthetic drugs could all be grown and produced locally to meet the high demand for these substances in the US, where addicts were left without a dose. Small groups appeared, which then began to organize into larger ones, then took over “medium-sized businesses”, and so on, just like in ordinary society, but without an antimonopoly authority.
One of the biggest players was the Golfo drug cartel, which was fully developed under the leadership of Juan Nepomuceno Guerra and Juan Garcia Abrego. Born in 1915, Guerra bootlegged back in the 1930s and then followed new trends, but overall he was a dark horse and never got a real sentence in his life. The much younger Abrego started his career in the 1970s as a courier whose ambitions gradually grew.
Thanks to this, he later received “recognition”, becoming the first drug lord on the FBI's list of ten most wanted criminals: by the late 1980s and early 1990s, under his patronage, about 300 tons of cocaine crossed the border between Mexico and the United States annually.
Gradually, Guerra and Abrego retired. Abrego was too eyesore for the US authorities. According to estimates by the Drug Enforcement Administration in 1994, the drug lord received about $10 billion from his business every year and organized a network of corrupt officials in Mexico and the United States. In 1995, Abrego was arrested and then extradited to the United States. And Guerra just got too old. The Golfo cartel was led by young Osiel Cardenas Gilien.
Against the background of ever-increasing competition, it became necessary to protect your “investments” and “assets”. Popular bandits — common criminals with “street” training — were often suitable for this purpose, but only for the time being due to their low qualifications and high turnover (in the case of drug wars, this word meant something other than “dismissal by agreement of the parties” or “for absenteeism”).
It was more effective to hire professionals rather than train more and more soldiers with the help of foreign instructors.
It is difficult to name the exact date of birth of Los Zetas. Different sources give different starting points. It is believed that it all started with Ruben El Chato Salinas, a retired Mexican lieutenant, whom Guillen hired as his bodyguard. However, Arturo Guzman Desena is often called the founder of Los Zetas. The young man at the time (born in 1976) served in the elite special forces of the Grupo Aeromóvil de Fuerzas Especiales (GAFE, now Cuerpo de Fuerzas Especiales), whose tasks included the fight against drug trafficking.
While in the military, Desena started working part-time for the Golfo cartel. Obviously, he was offered better terms, money and power at the same time, so he retired in 1996 or 1997, and Gilien became his main employer. Impressed by Arturo's skills, and out of fear for his life and a desire to strengthen his position, Guillen said he needed better fighters.
“There are only such people in the army,” the answer followed.
This was not an obstacle, and Desena quickly lured 34 special forces officers into his new squad — deserters ready to sacrifice their honor and morals for bonuses (and, as it turned out later, the opportunity not to limit themselves to violence against others).
By 1999, when the ongoing war for territory between clans had entered a tough phase, the squad had approximately 40 elite GAFE fighters ranging from soldier to lieutenant. Desena also appeared under the call sign Z-1, hence the band's name, Los Zetas.
The head of Golfo gradually gave the Zetas more and more power, expanding their powers, and the cartel found itself at the top of the pyramid, leaving both other clans and governments at the bottom. They could not resist trained militants who knew no restrictions; the drug mafia was superior to them both financially and militarily.
The hierarchy began to change gradually in 2002. Then Desena and six other senior Los Zetas officials were killed, and Golfo leader Osiel was later arrested  Cárdenas Guillén.
This happened in the spring of 2003 after a violent shootout between the military and Los Zetas soldiers. But Cardenas was only extradited to the United States in 2007, where he was sentenced to 25 years without parole.
Los Zetas was headed by Heriberto Lascano, also a member of the GAFE Special Forces. By about this time, Los Zetas already had more than 300 highly trained military personnel, and authorities called the group “the most formidable death squad in Mexico's history of organized crime.” Lazcano acted under the call signs Z-3 and El Lazca (Antonio Lucio Morales Betancourt with the call sign Z-2 was arrested back in 2001).
Lascano, by the way, had another nickname — El Verdugo (“The Hangman”), which he earned for his extreme cruelty: his specialty was sophisticated torture, and the Z-3 also introduced the “fashion” for decapitating victims. However, it was precisely because of its brutality that Los Zetas frightened not only ordinary people, but also other drug cartels.
Lazcano chose a strategy that was not quite familiar in these parts: instead of trying to negotiate with others, he acted as harshly as possible, forcing him to take control by force.
So the killer squad frightened other killers to such an extent that the latter swore allegiance to him. And it was violence that was Lascano's key to power: even his opponents believed that only he could oppose the Sinaloa cartel (now the largest cartel in Mexico). There were no questions about who the successor would be.
By 2007, Los Zetas formally remained under the control of the Golfo cartel, despite the fact that it already exceeded its parent company in terms of revenue, membership and influence. However, this did not suit the top of Los Zetas, which began to pull the blanket more actively over themselves, seizing more and more initiatives. The next three years were spent in constant internal conflicts, of which Los Zetas emerged victorious. In 2010, the militants became an independent group that controlled twice as much Mexican territory as its competitors, as well as part of neighboring Guatemala. The drug war was waged, with the Sinaloa, Golfo, Los Zetas cartels and numerous smaller organizations fighting for a redistribution of influence.
However, by this time, Los Zetas had lost professional military personnel, and their shortage was compensated for by super-brutality. In 2010, the San Fernando massacre took place when a mass grave with 72 unnamed migrants was discovered. Los Zetas was afraid they would join Golfo's army. The second San Fernando massacre took place in 2011. This time, 192 people were killed, again due to a possible connection with Golfo.
That same year, the Zetas set fire to a casino in Monterrey, a major Mexican city, killing 52 people. In 2012, Los Zetas sparked riots in a prison to free 30 members of the group, killing 44 people. About a year later, 49 decapitated bodies were found on the side of a road near Monterrey, believed to be victims of the Sinaloa war. Los Zetas even “worked” in Guatemala, where 27 farmers were killed. These are just a few examples of cartel brutality.
Several assassins talk about their work.
You can find videos online about the real consequences of the cartel's actions, but for ethical reasons we don't publish them.
However, along with its rapidly growing influence (the Zetas were also active in the US, Europe, Venezuela and Africa) and “business diversification” (pirated DVDs and other “almost legal” destinations appeared), Los Zetas faced problems managing the huge monster it had become. The empire began to burst at the seams, and the cartel began to rapidly fragment.
The assassination of Heriberto Lascano in 2012 also contributed to this. Also, in order not to create illusions about the impunity of drug cartels, we note that the authorities have entered an active phase of the war against criminals. In addition, the Obama administration imposed sanctions against Los Zetas, which was included in the list of especially dangerous organizations along with the Brotherly Circle, Yamaguchi-gumi and Camorra.
The leader for a short time was Miguel Treviño Morales, Z-40, who, according to Los Zetas's tradition, was extremely brutal.
It is believed that he was the one who started the war against the Golfo cartel in several regions of Mexico, kidnapping 16 gang members and killing them in 2010. He was accused of outright disloyalty to his former boss Lascano, and when Morales took his place, it turned out that the new chapter would give his predecessor a head start in bloodlust.
However, this was not enough to stay on top of the mountain, especially since most of the first 34 “zets” had been arrested or killed by that time, and the United States also awarded a $5 million reward for information about Morales. So he was arrested in 2012, his younger brother Omar (Z-42) took power, but he didn't last long, ending up in police hands in 2015.
The era of Los Zetas's dominance is over, although the remnants of the drug empire are still dangerous  continue to operate. Other groups have dismantled the controlled territories; they are also using the approaches introduced by Los Zetas. Today, a cartel made up of military deserters sometimes appears in the news, but more often than not as an example of extreme brutality.
Sources: CNN, La Jornada, PRX, The Guardian, BBC, Council on Foreign Relations, The Sydney Morning Herald, Insight Crime, Latin One, Mexico: Narco-Violence and a Failed State?

In Mexico, the authorities are losing the war against drug cartels. Why don't bullets or “hugs” help? | Hromadi TV
Last year in Mexico was the bloodiest in decades. 36,000 people were killed. Most of them died in a “war” between drug cartels and the authorities. Popular President Manuel Obrador's promises to stop violence “with hugs, not bullets” remain just words so far. And news from some Mexican states is increasingly reminiscent of chronicles from a country torn by a real war.
“Hell Thursday” or the defeat of power in person
On October 17, 2019, a squad of 46 intelligence officers surrounded a house in the wealthiest part of Culiacán, capital of the northern state of Sinaloa. Ovidio Guzman, the son of Joaquin “Shorty” Guzman, former leader of the Sinaloa drug cartel, who was sentenced to life imprisonment in the United States in 2019, was inside unguarded.
The military hoped to quickly arrest Guzman and transfer him to the airport in 25 minutes. Another 145 soldiers, divided into four groups, provided cover.
However, the cartel leaders were not caught off guard. Within a few minutes, the first shots rang out, and it became clear that you could forget about the bloodless operation. Hell Thursday has begun, which will end in what may be the most humiliating defeat for the Mexican authorities in the 13 years of the war against drugs.
Guzman's older brothers mobilized 375 fighters and besieged both the military and almost 800,000 residents of the city for several hours. The events unfolded like this.
The chronicle of “Hell Thursday”
17.10.2019
Each of the four cover groups comes under fire from cartel fighters, who arrived in armored vehicles armed with assault rifles, machine guns and grenade launchers.
17.10.2019
Ovidio Guzman leaves home. At the request of the military, he asks his brother over the phone to cease fire. He refuses. Drug cartel fighters surround military bases in the city. Exits from the city are blocked to prevent reinforcements from arriving. Thousands of frightened residents are waiting for danger, lying where the shooting caught them — near cars on the streets, in stores.
17.10.2019
Militants are shelling houses where families of military personnel participating in the operation live. Soldiers captured in different parts of the city become hostages in the hands of the drug cartel. Videos shared on social media show groups of helpless soldiers surrounded by militants.
17.10.2019
49 people convicted of serious crimes escape from the local prison. They stop and steal local residents' cars.
Guzman's older brother promises to attack government facilities in neighboring states.
17.10.2019
The military releases Ovidio Guzman and retreats to avoid further casualties. In a few hours, 14 people were killed, including four civilians and two security officers. Another 18 soldiers were injured.
Burning cars on “Hell Thursday” — the day of the armed clash between the Mexican military and police and drug cartel fighters in Culiacán, Sinaloa, Mexico, October 17, 2019
Police on a street in Culiacán on the day the son of former Sinaloa drug cartel leader Ovidio Guzman was arrested, which escalated into an armed confrontation between state police and military personnel and drug cartel mercenaries. Within a few hours, 14 people were killed in the city, including four civilians and two security officers. Another 18 soldiers were injured
Photo:
EPA-EFE/IVAN MEDINA
A wave of violence
The bloody clashes between drug cartels and law enforcement officers in Mexico are nothing new.
A few days before the events in Culiacán, 13 police officers were killed during an attack on a patrol in Michoacán. But the failure of the operation to detain Guzman shocked many: it was not the first time that the drug cartel so openly, in fact live, defied the authorities and won. The “war on drugs”, which has been going on for 13 years, has not changed the situation for the better.
Mexican cartels began to gain momentum in the late 1980s, following the weakening of Colombian drug traffickers. Gradually, Mexicans gained control over the supply to the United States of cocaine from Colombia, heroin and marijuana from Mexico, and synthetic drugs like methamphetamine and fentanyl from Mexico and China.
With the active participation of the United States, Mexican President Felipe Calderon announced the beginning of the “war on drugs” in 2006. To attack the drug cartels, the army was used instead of the police, who were accused, often exonerated, of links to organized crime. Y A few months later, about 20,000 military personnel participated in operations across the country.
In the following years, authorities were able to either arrest or kill dozens of cartel leaders.
Soldiers patrol streets in Tres Palos, Mexico, January 18, 2007. Since 2006, the Mexican army has been actively involved in drug trafficking operations within and outside the country. They have virtually replaced police officers who have discredited themselves with ties to local drug cartels
Photo:
EPA/DAVID DE LA PAZ
But that only made things worse. After the cartel leader is removed, a bloody struggle begins between the contenders for his inheritance. The cartel splits into smaller groups that continue to war among themselves and stubbornly oppose government forces. Other cartels also feel their competitors are weakening and are encroaching on their territory.
As a result, the homicide rate was the highest in Mexico's history. In 2018, 34,000 people died, and in 2019, already 36,000. During the 13 years of crackdown on cartels in a country of 126 million, about 300,000 people have died.
Another 60,000 are missing. Most of them probably ended up in mass graves, which are found almost every day.
Not only their competitors and law enforcement officers are victims of cartels' struggle for territory and drug transportation channels. Drug cartels kidnap people for ransom, forcibly recruit young people, establish their own laws, and severely punish those who resist.
In 2011, 52 people died in Monterrey. They were casino visitors and employees who were set on fire by members of the Los Zetas cartel because the owner refused to pay them for “protection”.
Relatives of those killed in a fire in a casino in Monterrey created a memorial on the first anniversary of the tragedy, Mexico, August 25, 2012. Members of the Los Zetas cartel set fire to the casino building because of the owner's debt. The fire killed 52 people — visitors and employees of the establishment
Photo:
EPA/MIGUEL SIERRA
In 2012, 72 illegal migrants who did not want to become murderers in the service of the same cartel were shot dead.
In 2014, under still unclear circumstances, 43 students who were protesting against the actions of the local authorities disappeared. According to the official version, they were kidnapped by the police and handed over to the local drug cartel.
The victims' relatives also often pay with their lives to demand that the perpetrators be punished. Miriam Rodriguez was killed on May 10, 2017, Mother's Day. The criminals took revenge on her for leading an organization of relatives of drug cartel victims and getting a verdict for the murderer of her 14-year-old daughter.
Because the authorities cannot protect the public, in some states, residents form self-defense groups themselves. In January 2020, all of Mexico was shocked by photos of 19 children between 5 and 16 years old armed with rifles. Self-defense in Guerrero has armed children to fight the gang that kidnapped and murdered ten local residents on January 16.
Women and children with guns guard the Alcozacán community in Guerrero, Mexico, January 14, 2020. The minors took responsibility for protecting the village from gangs on a par with police units.
Guerrero is one of Mexico's poorest and most violent states, officially recording 1,875 murders in 2019 alone
Photo:
EPA-EFE/JOSE LUIS DE LA CRUZ
To help us create more important content for you, please support hromadske on Spilnocoste. Any help goes a long way.
The power of the cartels
Calderon himself explained the difficulties in the fight against drug cartels. “Our neighbor to the north is the largest consumer of drugs in the world and at the same time the largest arms seller in the world.” Drug cartels earn up to $29 billion annually from selling drugs in the US. About 70% of weapons seized from criminals go to Mexico from the United States.
High revenues allow cartels to attract the best professionals. One of the most powerful and violent criminal organizations (until recently), Los Zetas, is formed from former members of elite Mexican troops.
Drug cartels have “their own people” not only at the local level, but also at the highest level of government and law enforcement agencies.
In December 2019, the US arrested former Security Secretary Garcia Luna. He was one of the ideologists of the “war on drugs” who worked closely with American colleagues. Investigators say he helped the Sinaloa cartel avoid prosecution for years in exchange for millions in bribes.
The roots of cartel infiltration can be traced back to the political monopoly of the center-left Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has been in power for 71 years and has generally coexisted with drug traffickers in a mutually beneficial manner.
Cartels punish law enforcement officers who refuse to cooperate with them. In May 2008, three Mexican federal police chiefs were murdered by drug cartels in ten days. The number of victims among local police officers exceeds a thousand people.
The military is leading the detained head of the Sinaloa drug cartel, Joaquin Guzman Loer a, known as “El Chapo”, Mexico City, Mexico, February 22, 2014. The drug lord was detained twice and escaped twice, the second time through the sewers. Since 2016, El Chapo has been serving time in prison, from which he escaped in 2015 through a 1.5-kilometer tunnel under his cell
Photo:
EPA/MARIO GUZMAN
The new president's “hugs instead of bullets”
Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who was elected at the end of 2018, promised to change the situation.
A ruthless critic of Mexico's political elites said the war was over. “We want peace. We're refusing to hunt cartel leaders. Our goal is to reduce homicides.” The President promised to focus on rehabilitating rather than punishing drug addicts, on creating opportunities for vulnerable segments of the population and on overcoming corruption and poverty. Such promises also dubbed him the words: “hugs are not bullets.”
According to many experts, this is a step in the right direction. The researchers argue that authorities should finally address the causes of violence: a toxic combination of poverty, weak state institutions and endemic everyday violence, including within families.
However, this will not bear fruit instantly. Falco Ernst of the International Crisis Group warns that Obrador's refusal to actively curb cartels is a mistake. Now, according to the expert, the state only reacts to the actions of criminals, and the “appetite” of drug cartels is growing with impunity.
Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said that under him, the country will no longer “hunt cartel leaders” and also promised to focus on the rehabilitation of drug addicts, Mexico City, Mexico, July 11, 2018
Photo:
EPA-EFE/JOSE MENDEZ
The failure of the operation to detain Guzman, which seemed to be unauthorized by top management, underscores that the authorities still do not have a clear vision of how to curb the violence right now.
In addition, due to US pressure, the new National Guard has focused on stopping the flow of thousands of illegal migrants from Central America instead of replacing soldiers who are ill-equipped to fight crime. The army continues to duplicate police functions. She is accused of torture and other human rights violations.
The pressure from the Donald Trump administration increased after the brutal murder by a small cartel in November of nine people with dual US and Mexican citizenship: three women and six children between months and 8 years old.
Trump called on Mexico to “wage war on drug cartels and wipe them off the face of the earth.” He promised to recognize cartels as terrorist organizations. This allowed US intelligence agencies to operate in Mexico without any approval.
And, according to Arturo Saruhan, former Mexican ambassador to Washington, the US should, first of all, limit the flow of weapons and drug proceeds to Mexico. And also to increase the detection of drugs coming across the southern border.
The US should also help Mexico reform its law enforcement system. The police are poorly trained, underfunded and demoralized — officers buy their own uniforms and even bullets. The judicial system is cumbersome and slow, with only 2% of crimes being punished.
Family and friends of the victims from the Bavispe Mormon community say goodbye to their families in La Mora, Sonora, Mexico, November 7, 2019. Three women and six children from one of the oldest Mormon communities were shot dead by drug cartel fighters in their cars on their way to visit relatives in Chihuahua on November 5
Photo:
EPA-EFE/LUIS TORRES
Obrador now blames his predecessors for the disappointing statistics.
But with each passing day, his responsibility for the rampant violence is growing, and Mexicans' confidence in the correctness of his policy is falling.
However, the increase in homicides has slowed down slightly in recent months. And raising social standards and introducing scholarships for 2.3 million young Mexicans could eventually have an effect if the economy finally starts to grow.
In addition, Garcia Luna, one of the leaders of the “war on drugs”, who was arrested in the United States, could uncover corrupt networks at the top of the Mexican authorities that prevent effective action against cartels.
Drug cartels in Mexico have strengthened their positions: the pandemic makes it more difficult for the authorities to fight them
The Jalisco New Generation Cartel (CJNG) is a relatively young group that has been active since 2009. Its members are fighting for influence in Guadalajara, Jalisco and Veracruz. The cartel is led by Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, nicknamed “El Mencho”, one of the most wanted drug lords.
By 2018, CJNG had become Mexico's second-strongest cartel.
It was he who, as security officers told the agency, is actively using the epidemic to strengthen control over the drug market. The number of murders in the country has increased to record levels, while there are significantly fewer other crimes due to the fact that most residents now stay at home.
In recent weeks alone, CJNG militants have kidnapped and killed seven police officers, killed ten hours. a guy at a drug rehab center and shot 12 members of a rival cartel. In its struggle for territory and control of drug supply routes, the cartel faced stiff resistance from other groups.
The number of deaths from coronavirus infection in Mexico has exceeded 18,300 people, and the country now has the seventh highest number of deaths in the world. Therefore, the fight against coronavirus is still a priority for the authorities. At the same time, the government does not directly recognize that the epidemic has affected the war against the cartels.
Mexican authorities imposed quarantine restrictions in the country on March 23, when schools, businesses and government agencies were closed. March also saw an increase in the number of murders: about 3,000 were registered in a month. This is one of the highest figures since December 2018.
Not only doctors and military personnel were involved in the fight against COVID-19: according to the Ministry of Security, at least 4,700 National Guard officers were sent to protect hospitals.
At the same time, soldiers who were fighting organized crime were almost paralyzed: to fight the coronavirus, they had to turn their barracks into clinics for the treatment of COVID-19. In addition, according to local officials, there are also problems with the number of police officers: employees at risk (overweight and health problems) have been transferred from patrolling the streets.
One of the security officials in Guerrero also spoke about the lack of police. According to him, if one police officer falls ill, four more are quarantined for two weeks.
Guerrero, like Michoacán and Mexico City, is part of the Tierra Caliente (“Hot Land”) region in the south-west of the country. Even before the outbreak of the epidemic, it had places where neither troops nor police came. There, criminal groups have much more control.
In such places, cartels are partly replacing local authorities and taking over the functions of the state. This is now particularly evident in helping local residents during the pandemic. According to Guerrero residents, paramilitary groups linked to the cartels have imposed curfews in some regions to curb the spread of the coronavirus.
According to Mike Vigil, a former US Drug Enforcement Agency agent, the coronavirus epidemic has only deepened the authorities' problems related to territorial control. In particular, according to him, gaps in power have become more visible. “Unfortunately, drug cartels are filling these gaps,” Vigil summed up.

In 2020, such content also appeared on Tiktok, according to The New York Times. Leon Oliveira, an anthropologist at the Spanish University of Murcia, who studies Mexican criminal gangs, says: “This is drug marketing. They use such platforms for propaganda, mostly hedonistic advertising.”
In November 2020, US tiktok users noticed a one-minute video of a boat chase in their recommendations. Apparently, it was filmed and published by members of the cartel, and the authorities were chasing them.
After that, the Tiktok algorithm began offering viewers similar videos, and so users got “on the side” with the content of the Mexican drug mafia. The video showed expensive cars, bundles of cash, guns, and even tigers as pets. “It's fascinating to watch a movie,” an 18-year-old California user described Tiktoki.
Ioan Grillo, author of El Narco: Criminal Uprising in Mexico, explains that at first, cartels were violent on the Internet, instilling fear by demonstrating torture. But as social media policies tightened, they began to act differently, showing young Mexicans the benefits of joining a cartel: parties, an endless stream of money, beautiful women, exotic pets.
In 2013-2014, American journalists noticed social media accounts under the names of the sons of the famous drug lord El Chapo. Photos of luxury life were posted there, including opulent villas and golden rifles. And in the spring of 2020, British tabloids reported that Jesus Alfredo Guzman, the other son of the head of the Sinaloa cartel, had registered in Tiktok. After publishing several luxury goods videos, his profile was removed.
“A dream, that's what they sell,” The New York Times interlocutors note.
Photos from accounts named El Chapo's sons, 2014
At the same time, according to Falco Ernst, an employee of the International Crisis Group, only some tiktoks have been filmed by the main members of the cartels and sicaria (“murderers”).
And most of the videos are published by “low-level” bandits or just Mexicans who want to live the same way. But, one way or another, the goal of such content is the same: to create a certain image for those who will join the cartel army in the war against law enforcement officers.
Despite the fact that Mexican cartels have been attracting supporters through social media for many years, Tiktok's peculiarity has slightly changed the principle. “The post should be short, engaging and viral. Violence becomes entertainment or even part of music,” says Oliveira.
TikTok deleted many cartel-related videos shortly after The New York Times contacted: service representatives announced a fight against content promoting “illegal activity”. There are a few posts left on Twitter, and the publication described a couple of videos.
In one of them, which has half a million likes, a farmer cuts unripe seed pods in a poppy field, presumably to further produce heroin
Journalists believe that such tiktoks could become another stage in the “glamorization” of the life of a drug cartel member, which allows them to join the ranks. Meanwhile, Mexico recorded a record number of murders in 2019 — almost 35,000 — and authorities are waiting for the record to be updated in 2020. “You can't see this dark reality on Tiktok,” the NYT notes.
Mexican drug fighters are also increasing their presence in Tiktok, where several police bloggers have appeared, covering the everyday life of the war against the cartels.
Italian mafia
In May 2020, a video for local artist Tony Riccio's song “Sì Sto' Carcerato” (“Yes, I'm behind bars”) was released on Italian tiktok.
The text of the composition described the life of the lyrical hero in prison, and it sounded in the signature “neomelodic” manner typical of Naples.
At first glance, this is not unusual if it weren't for the setting in the video: it turned out that he was filmed inside a prison, and not a simple prison, but in the high-security wing of Avellino Prison, 50 kilometers from Naples. Historically, there are criminals associated with the Camorra, the Neapolitan mafia. And Tiktok from there probably recorded the life of one of the mobsters.
Vice's Italian editorial staff spent several months studying the traces of the mafia's presence in Tiktok. Journalists came to the conclusion that many young Camorrists (or people who want to be like them) use the service to show off their way of life and “make themselves known to top management”.
Mafia members gradually began migrating to Tiktok from the more traditional Facebook page.
Of course, it's impossible to say for sure that the users Vice writers found are related to Camorra. Famous mafiosi in Naples are united in clans, and family ties are important for joining them, but in the modern world this rule is fading into the background. In 2019, the Italian Anti-Mafia Authority talked about the Camorra Academy: young criminals form gangs and act in the interests of the Camorra, and the best of them end up in the family.
Many camorrists in Tiktok, writes Vice, belong to such gangs. They show cars on video mobiles, motorcycles, weapons and other luxury goods. Paradies is often accompanied by the song “Paradies” about life in a “harsh neighborhood”.
You can also find the hashtag #paranza, which is how Naples calls “little fish” in the Camorra hierarchy.
Vice also notes other indirect signs that Tiktok users belong to the mafia. For example, an emoji with eyes is the equivalent of the local saying “Those who know the rules of the game are silent”. In another video, the author celebrates his friend's release from prison, calling him “piazza” — in slang, this is a place where people sell drugs.
In the early 2000s, war broke out in Neapolitan's Scampia district, one of Italy's drug trafficking centers. The Amato-Pagano clan allegedly betrayed the Di Lauro clan, for which the former were named “separatists”. In response, they nicknamed themselves Gli Spagnoli (“The Spaniards”), and some of the tiktok videos are signed with Spanish flag emojis.
One of them shows a scooter parade on the clan's historic grounds in Scampia.
The Italian authorities believe that mafia content on social media is an attempt at a kind of rebranding. Recently, traditional Camorra clans have been trying to retire and divert attention, handing over territories to young gangs. As a result, 19-year-old gang leader Emmanuel Sibillo challenged the local boss, after which he was killed. This attracted “negative attention” and the clans are now restoring their overall image.
Marcello Ravveduto, professor of digital history at the University of Salerno, believes that Camorra's arrival in Tiktok makes sense: “We often forget that criminal organizations and social apps have one thing in common: networks.”
And the more you can see the mafia on Tiktok, the easier it is for them to attract new supporters.
Mexican drug cartel fighters ate a competitor's heart
https://static.news.ru/photo/7a3a876a-e780-11ea-b321-fa163e074e61_660.jpg
Members of a drug cartel operating in the Mexican state of Michoacán have resorted to cannibalism to intimidate rival gangs.
Breitbart drew attention to a shocking episode of the war between criminal gangs. Militants from the Jalisco Nueva Generacion cartel released a video of the execution of a member of a rival criminal organization.
They held the man on the ground, cut open his chest and took out his heart. The militants involved in the execution then took turns biting off parts of the organ.
This bloody incident was the latest in a series of videotaped massacres carried out by gangs vying for power in a region in western Mexico. In Michoacán, an alliance of groups known as the United Cartels is at war with the New Generation of Jalisco. Recently, opponents staged a real battle in the city of Tepalcatepec, the capital of the state. The city is considered one of the cartel's key centers for transporting drugs from the coast to other parts of Mexico and to the United States.
News.ru previously posted a video showing militants from a Mexican cartel showing off their weapons, equipment and modern equipment.

The Mexican Cartel War: Life on the Battlefield
A 16-year-old Mexican cousin named Nancy Garcia was picking fruit with his father on a ranch in Michoacán when gunmen came and changed his family's lives forever.
Men kidnapped by drug hitmen are seen at a ranch near the municipality of Sabinas Hidalgo, some 100 km away from Monterrey April 27, 2010 (Reuters/Tomas Bravo).
“They came out of nowhere, pointed their guns at my uncle and took my brother,” Nancy told an OCCRP employee.
The attack on the Garcia family is just one of the kidnappings for ransom in Michoacán, a crime that is becoming increasingly popular here.
Garcia's family members were desperate and asked for help in every way they could, posting ads and writing posts on Facebook. Two days later, the kidnappers got in touch and announced the amount. The family was able to raise money, but it didn't end there.
“The whole family, even my uncle, received calls saying that his daughter had been kidnapped, but it wasn't true. They wanted to intimidate us and get more money,” says Nancy.
Even relatives in California, where the girl lives, received calls.
“To be honest, this situation makes me angry, upset and frightened at the same time. I care about those who live in Michoacán. Especially for my family,” says Nancy.
Migrants who were not released from Mexico under the “Stay in Mexico” program (officially known as “Migrant Protection Protocols”) are waiting in line for a bottle of water at a temporary camp in Matamoros, Tamaulipas. October 28, 2019. (photo: Reuters/Lauren Elliot)
Michoacán is known for the brutality with which it controls the multi-billion dollar avocado industry. This region is also famous for its marijuana and opium production. This business dates back to the 1960s and has only recently lost to amphetamine and fentanyl.
From time to time, in the hunt for quick money, people kidnap for ransom, as is the case with the Garcia family.
This is just one example of PR manifestations of violence and brutality that are increasingly faced by residents of Michoacán and Mexico in general.
The Mexican president is often criticized for his government's too soft approach to the fight against drug cartels amid the brutality that is sweeping the country.
According to experts, this gentleness plays into the hands of at least one crime boss: Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, better known as El Mencho, is trying to take control of his home state. He is now considered to be the head of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes (photo: US State Department)
Falco Ernst, a senior analyst at the International Crisis Group, a nonprofit organization, told OCCRP that El Mencho considers the area “his rightful”. He has been trying to seize power in the region for the past 8 years.
“This is his homeland. This is not a common case of militants seizing territory, it's a matter of personal resentment, Ernst says. “He was nobody when he left here.”
Ernst doubts that El Mencho will be welcomed with open arms.
He spent too much time away from home. His attempts to seize power in the area led to local gangs becoming more active, and some of them joined together as the Michoacan Front to fight back.
Ernst believes that El Mencho significantly killed thirteen police officers on October 14th. He wanted everyone to see it — the press, locals, and other cartels.
The bodies of the police officers were left on the road next to their burnt cars just 12 kilometers from where the drug lord was born.
“What we're seeing now has been happening for several years,” Ernst says. “And I think it's not over yet.”
Relatives of a police officer killed during a cartel attack at a farewell ceremony organized by the state government in Morelia, Michoacán on October 15, 2019. (photo: Reuters/Alan Ortega)
The US Drug Enforcement Administration calls the Jalisco New Generation Cartel (CJGN) the most violent cartel in the world — its list of atrocities is endless.
“Without going into details, CJGN has gone from being a major growing drug threat to Mexico's main active drug threat,” Special Agent Kyle Morey told OCCRP.
The cartel controls 23 out of 32 Mexican states. Morey adds that they “also control all drug routes to the US and continents other than, perhaps, Antarctica.”
Mori has been investigating the CJGN and El Mencho case for several years. He believes that this is not the first time that the drug lord has returned to Michoacán.
“As for drug trafficking, I believe CJGN and El Mencho have controlled Michoacán for the past six years,” Morey said, adding that he cannot comment on rumors about where El Mencho is.
The main question remains: is it possible to put an end to the war between the cartels, and what can the Mexican government do to ensure a normal life for its citizens?
At the end of October, Reforma, a Mexican publishing house, conducted a public survey.
56% of respondents believe that criminals have more power in the country than the government.
The survey was conducted against the background of a failed military operation to capture Ovidio Guzman, the son of the famous drug lord El Chapo.
The police managed to capture Guzman in Culiacán, but were then surrounded by hundreds of armed members of the Sinaloa cartel. Guzman was released and the police had to leave town.
The failed operation, followed by a surge in violence in Culiacán, led to a storm of anger against the Mexican military and government.
According to Ernst, the government's decision not to fight cartels could lead to irreparable consequences in Michoacán. The bandits are checking how far the authorities will allow them to go. And they're not going to stop.
For an ordinary resident, being in an area under the control of a cartel or gang is like living in a war zone.
Any connection to the cartel, no matter how superficial, could cost you your life.
Jenny, an American woman whose family lives in Michoacán, says that her two brothers were kidnapped a year ago.
“One of the brothers was a member of the cartel,” the girl told OCCRP (the editors do not disclose her last name at her request). “When they came for him, he had a brother with him who had nothing in common with these people.”
Both of them have been missing ever since.
“Let's be honest, they're probably dead,” Jenny says.

Carlos is a Mexican businessman who works for an import-export company specializing in the sale of tequila and agricultural and chemical products. But in January 2016, he was far from his home in Culiacán, the capital of Sinaloa.
Two companions accompanied him as he traveled from Shanghai to Hong Kong, Japan, and finally to India.
There they met Manu Gupta, a businessman working in various sectors: chemical and pharmaceutical industries, agri-food products, sand and even machinery.
Two years later  charges were filed for another aspect of Gupta's business interests. On September 25, 2018, he was arrested in Indore, Madhya Pradesh, along with his Mexican counterpart and an Indian chemist. The three men wore masks and gloves and had more than 10 kilograms of fentanyl, a heavy-duty synthetic opioid.
Gupta and his accomplices are accused of planning to send fentanyl on a commercial flight to Mexico hidden in a suitcase. Three men are currently awaiting trial in India. All three denied the charges.
According to the Committee to Protect Journalists, 119 journalists have been killed in Mexico since 2000, making Mexico the most dangerous country in the world for members of the press outside the war zone.
Now 25 international media outlets have come together to continue stories about murdered Mexican colleagues.
Working together in 18 different countries for 10 months, the consortium explored the global networks of Mexican drug cartels and their political connections around the world.
The collaboration was coordinated by Forbidden Stories, a global network of investigative journalists whose mission is to continue the work of reporters who are threatened, censored, or killed.
At the same time, by publishing their stories, the Cartel participants want to send a powerful message to the enemies of the free press: “Killing a journalist won't kill history.”
An analysis of social media posts and public information about the company suggests that Carlos (a fictitious name) fits the profile of a person described in a 2019 DEA report as an independent dealer in precursor chemicals.
This report, obtained by the international hacker group Anonymous and published in the BlueLeaks document dump in June, states that an unnamed person from Sinaloa was sent to “purchase additional large quantities of fentanyl precursor chemicals directly from China” on behalf of the cartel.
Carlos did not respond to Cartel Project's request for an interview.
This case sheds light on the international networks set up by Mexican cartels and the business methods they use to dominate the lucrative fentanyl market.
As bloodthirsty as they may be, Mexican criminal organizations use the same strategies as any other business: they outsource specialists to maximize profits — and they are constantly adapting to changing international norms.
Dominant force
Despite the imprisonment of its best-known leader, Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, the Sinaloa cartel remains the dominant force in the drug trade. An October 2019 Drug Enforcement Administration report describes the group as “a well-known manufacturer and supplier of fentanyl from Mexico to the United States.”
Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid analgesic similar to morphine, but cheaper and 50 to 100 times more powerful.
Fentanyl is increasingly replacing heroin on the clandestine market, causing a record number of overdoses worldwide. In 2018, fentanyl and similar synthetic drugs accounted for nearly half of the 67,367 drug overdose deaths in the U.S. According to the American Medical Association, overdoses rose sharply this year during the coronavirus pandemic, with more than 40 US states reporting increases in drug deaths, especially from synthetic opioids such as fentanyl.
Not long ago, the mountains of Sinaloa and Guerrero were a patchwork of small plantations where farmers made their living growing marijuana and opium poppies. However, these crops are now being replaced by clandestine laboratories that produce batches of synthetic drugs.
At one such lab—just over a few desks in a shrubbery forest near the state capital Culiacan—a cartel chemist and his assistant were working on a new batch of pills.
Both men wore white overalls and respiratory masks. The chemist, a burly born man with a master's degree in biochemical engineering, described the industry's transformation when they worked at an outdoor desk.
Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid analgesic similar to morphine but cheaper and much more powerful. Photo: Forbidden Stories
“Fentanyl is more profitable. You only need one tablet per person. So if we transport 10,000 pills, 10,000 people will take them,” he said.
Stirring the white powder with a plastic spatula, he said, “I know my pill is very strong and addictive. And that's what I want. When a consumer takes one and then needs another dose.”
Fentanyl is extremely profitable to produce: where opium poppy requires acres of land and months of care, this very powerful drug requires only minimal manpower and infrastructure. According to a 2019 DEA report, it only costs $1 to produce each fentanyl tablet.
It can be resold at least 10 times more in the US.
New opportunities
Until recently, most of the fentanyl sold in the US came from She is from China, but that has changed with the introduction of stricter international norms in 2017 and China's repression in 2019. Direct transportation of fentanyl has become more risky, but China remains the main producer of the precursor chemical.
Meanwhile, cartels saw a new opportunity to enter the market as intermediaries.
Thanks to its well-established network, the Sinaloa cartel already had a solid infrastructure to expand the production of synthetic drugs. A memo from the Drug Enforcement Administration, published through BlueLeaks, describes a highly organized network that includes border warehouses and distributors across the United States.
“The profit margin they make by synthesizing and processing the product into its consumable form,” explained Falco Ernst, senior analyst for Mexico at the International Crisis Group in Mexico.
And despite cartels' popular image as vertically integrated organizations, they often turn to independent networks to outsource logistics or launder money.
map
“Cartel brands are disappearing over time. [But] all these [other] networks are staying in place because they're much less visible. They're much more secretive about their operations. They don't go public and are much more protected from market volatility,” Ernst said.
On the other side of the globe, Chinese precursor producers are using similar strategies to avoid getting caught. And as Beijing tightens regulations, some criminal networks are moving some of their businesses to countries with less stringent controls, especially Vietnam and India.
“Things have changed so drastically”
In theory, the sale of precursors is strictly regulated: the International Narcotics Control Board (INCB) maintains a “Red List” of restricted substances.
But there are almost endless opportunities to bypass these controls by tinkering with chemical compounds to produce new substances that go beyond current regulations.
To combat this phenomenon, INCB also maintains an international special checklist of non-scheduled substances, ISSL, to monitor products that are not necessarily controlled substances but are often used illegally.
However, this regulatory system is not perfect: INCB, a non-binding legal entity, relies on companies' goodwill and government audits, which works better in theory than in practice. In fact, a simple Google search reveals the scale of the problem.
When you enter keywords for fentanyl precursors, you quickly get to Pinterest, where Chinese companies exporting fentanyl precursors, many of them to Mexico, post between wedding mood boards and home decor inspiration.
At the top of the page is “4-AP,” an ISSL substance that has recently become a controlled substance in the US. According to the DEA, 4-AP has only one purpose: to produce fentanyl.
Under the guise of a false Mexican identity, the Cartel project contacted three companies, each offering our secret reporters substances known to be used in the synthesis of opioids.
One company offered several 4-AP-like substances that were still available for sale. The supplier suggested using a “special line” for shipping to Mexico.
“We bought some people at Mexican customs, we trusted them a lot, and they helped with all our deliveries to Mexico. So you don't have to worry about customs,” the seller wrote.
In another conversation, the seller explained that one of their “big” customers in Mexico used cargo planes to deliver precursors. “When goods arrived in Mexico, he used his own connections to pick up the goods.
”
Bryce Pardo, a researcher at the Rand Corporation who specializes in drug policy, said that current legislation is simply out of step with today's drug market.
“Our drug control laws are based on a very old system, where everything is based on a single UN convention from 1961. They actually focused on three plants: cannabis, coke, and maca. The situation has changed so much in the past 10-15 years, since China actually got online with its pharmaceutical sector — to the point that we just can't keep up.”

Cartel methamphetamine, Mexico's once-murderous peaceful state
MEXICO (AP) — In the central Mexican state of Guanajuato, the color of methamphetamine or the label on the packaging in an addict's pocket can determine whether he will survive or die.
The Jalisco cartel sells crystal clear methamphetamine for $2.30 per dose. Santa Rosa de Lima's house gang sells cheaper blue methamphetamines for $1.40 . And rival gangs don't accept the competition for control that has turned Guanajuato into one of Mexico's most blood-drenched states.
“This is the right death sentence” if a dealer is caught with the wrong color of methamphetamine, said David Sosedo, a security analyst at Guanajuato. “It's almost like a scenario... mass murders of street vendors. They will attack a funeral where a relative (of the deceased) had some connections to another gang.”
It is unclear whether individual colors are the result of different production processes or whether colors are intentional. It may not be a coincidence that the recently arrested Santa Rosa gang leader has been nicknamed El Azul, or “Blue.”
Both sides also label plasticine envelopes with their own stamps. Jalisco might say “CJNG,” the band's initials, or “Grupo Elite,” or have a skull pattern with a bayonet and gun.
Santa Rosa's symbol is a triangle with a skull and two sledgehammers, a reference to the nickname of another arrested leader.
Sophia Hutt, Guanajuato's security commissioner, said these markings could make the most difference. “This is a brand concept based on a label rather than a color that is not always present.”
In any case, the battle now pits two of the most powerful drug cartels in the hemisphere against each other for control of the state — an industrial and agricultural center that attracts gangs for the same reason as automakers: road and rail networks that lead directly to the U.S. border.
Concerned about the rise of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, the long-powerful Sinaloa Cartel has allied itself with Santa Rosa de Lima and other small local groups in recent months.
Guanajuato, Mexico's sixth most populous state, was home to more than 3,400 homicides in the first nine months of this year, more than any other state in the country.
More police officers died in the line of duty here than in any other Mexican state.
The battle has come to resemble Prohibition-era Chicago, when gunmen shoot houses or stores that compete with drug trafficking or other smuggling.
“This type of mass murder takes place in places that sell drugs or stolen fuel,” Sosedo said. “They'll go into a store, a warehouse, a tire repair shop and kill everyone, destroy the place, throw a hand grenade.”
The Santa Rosa de Lima gang expanded to drugs after it began robbing freight trains and stealing fuel from government pipelines, an activity that drew particular attention from a government furious at the loss of revenue.
When police approached him in July, Santa Rosa cartel leader Jose Antonio Yepez Ortiz, known as “El Marro” or “The Sledgehammer,” made a desperate call for an alliance with the Sinaloa cartel to repel Jalisco's group.
is currently Mexico's fastest growing and most violent criminal organization.
Jalisco has already traveled to at least 20 states, sometimes posting online videos showing columns of heavily armed militants with makeshift armored vehicles, and making vague and often broken promises not to kidnap or extort protection payments from civilians.
Saucedo said that the Sinaloa gang did not want to support Santa Rosa, whose leaders were considered unsophisticated and unreliable gangsters. But “El Marro's arrest caused the Sinaloa cartel to intervene in Guanajuato to prevent Jalisco from taking control.”
“We had a war between two cartels, and unfortunately a third cartel (Sinaloa) is now in conflict.”
Huett, the State Security Commissioner, said Santa Rosa and other local gangs are providing the larger outside group with “firepower, manpower, even with seasoned criminals, murderers to stand up to Jalisco's organization to curb their expansion a little bit.
He also sends weapons and money, as well as his operatives. According to her, 10 militants from Sinaloa have been captured this month.
This would be true for the Sinaloa scenario. In the early 2000s, Sinaloa fought the Juarez cartel for the lucrative border city of Ciudad Juarez, supporting local gangs like Artistas Asesinos and Mexicles against the armed branches of Juarez, La Linea, and Barrio Azteca. These four gangs turned Ciudad Juarez, near El Paso, Texas, into a homicide field between 2008 and 2012.
In Guanajuato, murders have reached similar proportions.
In July, cartel fighters killed 26 people at an unregistered drug rehabilitation center in Irapuato. The attackers shot every man in the center, allowing only women to enter.
At the end of September, gunmen killed 11 people, including four women, at a bar in Jaral del Progreso. Five more people in this city died earlier this month in a shootout at a funeral.
The Jalisco cartel began slaughtering up competing dealers and carefully piling their severed limbs together to support their severed heads, sometimes with a surprised expression, sweat because the victims' eyelids were cut off.
The Mexican Sinaloa cartel, specializing in fentanyl for supply to the US market
- The powerful Sinaloa cartel built an empire by smuggling cocaine through Mexico to the US.
- But the cartel is shifting its focus to a new, stronger drug to keep up with US changing appetites.
- At a lab in downtown Sinaloa, cartel members told Insider how they're working to keep drug users in the US.
- Visit the Insider business section to learn more.
Culiacán, MEXICO — Mexico's powerful Sinaloa cartel has built an empire on cocaine, but in response to changing US demand, it's shifting its focus to a newer, more powerful drug.
While the cartel, known for its jailed thief in law Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, is still a major US cocaine distributor, the organization is betting on fentanyl to meet demand for opioids north of the border while maintaining the cartel in Mexico.
Fentanyl is a powerful synthetic opioid analgesic similar to morphine, but 50 to 100 times more powerful, according to US authorities. Mexican drug cartels are adding fentanyl to heroin to increase its effectiveness and market value.
During a recent trip to Sinaloa, on Mexico's Pacific coast, Insider gained access to a fentanyl lab run by the Sinaloa cartel.
The lab was a rudimentary makeshift tent a couple of hours from Culiacán, the capital of Sinaloa. The setup included a huge pot, a makeshift press, and some lab tools. To get there, it took a highway ride, switching from a car to an off-road pickup truck, and a short walk through a dry forest.
Sinaloa police officers at a clandestine synthetic drug lab in Carrizalejo, Sinaloa, Mexico, July 6, 2018.
RASHID FRIAS/AFP via Getty Images
There were five people in the lab: a cook, three assistants, and an armed sentinel in charge of two-way radio communications.
Everyone was wearing green camouflage uniforms.
They've been running fentanyl and heroin labs since 2019, when the cartel decided to leave marijuana crops and poppy fields aside to meet new demand.
“Our customer base on the other side [of the border] doesn't want this old black chiva anymore,” said the cartel member responsible for the illegal lab, referring to Mexican black tar heroin.
U.S. drug users are “used to fentanyl-enhanced heavy-duty heroin,” the participant added.
According to him, users in the US started asking for fentanyl-enhanced heroin in 2015, but they didn't receive the order and recipes for its preparation until 2019.
“The cook learned from a Chinese man and brought everything useful here as a “cartel”. “He's the only one who knows the recipe,” a cartel member told Insider.
“But a lot of people started to die because we still didn't have the right recipe, and some of them didn't know about the effectiveness of the new product,” he added.
A Sinaloa police officer at a clandestine synthetic drug lab in Carrizalejo, Sinaloa, July 6, 2018.
RASHID FRIAS/AFP via Getty Images
One of those victims was Landon Marsh, the youngest son of Arizona Senator Christine Marsh.
“He bought a street drug mixed with fentanyl and it killed him,” said Marsh, who is now fighting fentanyl in Arizona, defending the use of fentanyl test strips.
“Our country is faced with an opioid crisis. We've lost 8,140 lives since June 2017, and fentanyl-supplemented drugs are a significant factor in this crisis,” Marsh told Insider.
More than 30,000 people in the U.S. overdosed on fentanyl in 2018, making it one of the deadliest illegal drugs in history, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
It was this strategy — mixing heroin with fentanyl — that made the Sinaloa cartel a leading player in a relatively new business.
A leaked DEA report from 2019 called the cartel “a well-known fentanyl producer and trader from Mexico to the US.”
A chemical specialist wearing a protective suit with pills seized at a clandestine laboratory to detect fentanyl in Mexico City, December 12, 2018.
Attorney General's Office/Handout via REUTERS
Mexican authorities reported a 466% increase in fentanyl seizures in 2020, amounting to about 2,400 pounds (1,301 kilograms), compared to 405 pounds (222 kg) in 2019, according to the Mexican Ministry of Defense.
“We have arrested 175 illegal fentanyl laboratories, which is 92% more than in 2019,” Mexican Defense Secretary Luis Crecencio Sandoval said at a recent press conference. Sandoval said 76% of the labs discovered last year were outdoors, such as the one in Culiacán.
But the Mexican cartels quickly adapted.
“We stopped using large reputable labs because the [Mexican] government started with or hit us. A few weeks ago, the military raided this laboratory, but we received a warning about the operation and left with all the valuable material, said a cartel observer.
According to the cook, most of the chemicals used in operations are illegally imported from China and Germany. As soon as fentanyl powder reaches Mexico, it is prepared to be shipped to the US.
“We make 10 to 20 kilograms (22 to 44 pounds) of heroin a day and work most of the week,” the cook said. The usual cost of a 10-kilogram batch can reach $3 million.
Fentanyl and methamphetamine seized from a truck entering Arizona from Mexico are shown at a press conference in Nogales, Arizona on January 31, 2019. Customs and Border Protection/Distributed via REUTERS
On January 29, one of the most active operators of the Sinaloa cartel in the US pleaded guilty in US court to managing a distribution network.
According to US authorities, Ramiro Ramirez-Barreto supplied heroin and fentanyl to Virginia, North Carolina, Texas and California.
Ramirez's court documents say Sinaloa cartel distributors are using “hidden traps in private vehicles, couriers and semi-trailers, trucks and recreational vehicles” to smuggle heroin and fentanyl into and around the US.
Ramirez-Barreto worked with several other US citizens, according to the indictment, reflecting changes in how the Sinaloa cartel fuels US demand and broader changes in the cartel's activities.
Mexican cartels are recruiting US citizens specifically to deliver goods to the US in an attempt to bypass temporary border restrictions that only allow US citizens to travel.
“Ever since the Gringos closed the border to Mexicans, we've started using gringos with US passports to smuggle for us. This hasn't stopped, even during the pandemic,” said a cartel official.
“We're going to produce as much as they want. There's a lot of money in this. If they want stronger drugs, we'll manufacture them and ship them to the other side. You have to give the customer what they ask for,” he said.
Mexican women vigilantes lead the fight against drug cartels
Mexico's Michoacán district has become so lawless that a gang of vigilante women has taken it upon themselves to protect their friends and family.
The state, which is the world's largest supplier of avocados and limes, was recently taken over by the violent Jalisco drug cartel, originating from a neighboring state, so women are resisting, reports the Associated Press.
Women carry assault rifles and set up checkpoints, often while pregnant or with young children, to combat rising homicide rates that have skyrocketed since 2013.
Most women lost family members to the cartel, like Blanco Nava, who told AP that her son Freddy Barrios, a 29-year-old lime collector, was kidnapped by alleged Jalisco cartel gunmen in pickups; she hasn't heard from anything since then.
Another woman said her 14-year-old daughter was kidnapped and hasn't been seen since, saying, “We're going to protect those we left behind, the children we left behind, with our lives. We women are tired of seeing our children; our families are disappearing. They're taking our sons, our daughters, our relatives, our husbands.”
Women are left to fight, as most men are taken to work for the cartels (voluntarily or not).
Armed women known as “La Chola” on the left and “La Hera” who say they are members of a women-led self-defense group that fights off drug gangs were seen driving with firearms on January 14, 2021. Armando Solis/AP
“As soon as they see a man who can carry a gun, they pick him up,” the woman told AP. “They're disappearing. We don't know if they have them (as new recruits) or if they've already killed them.”
Female vigilantes also made a makeshift tank, a “heavy-duty pickup truck with a steel plate welded to it,” AP reports, while women in other cities dug trenches across roads leading to neighboring Jalisco state to apprehend the attackers.

Children play sandbags at a checkpoint set up by their mothers, who are part of a women-led protection group in Mexico, January 13, 2021.Armando Solis/AP
Alberto Garcia refused to join the cartels and was forced to flee. His family members were less fortunate.
“They also killed one of my brothers,” Garcia said. “They beat him up and my daughter-in-law, who was eight months pregnant.”
The vigilantes say they have to resort to this tactic because the government and police don't.
A masked woman who said she was expelled from her community by criminal gangs spotted on January 13, 2021. Armando Solis/AP
Sergio Garcia, a man from the El Terrero lynch group, speak because his 15-year-old brother was abducted and killed by Jalisco. Now he wants justice that the police never did.
“We're here to get justice by hook or by crook, because if we don't do it, no one will do it,” Garcia said.
Mexico's government control is under threat from criminal groups claiming a large territory.
