JUAN ALDAMA, Mexico — This time the killers came early. It was 8:30 a.m. when they surrounded a police station in this rural town. Bullets clashed after blocks. By the time the security forces arrived, Ricardo Barron Guzman was already dead, and the second chief of police was shot dead here in 14 months.
Surrounded by beans and corn fields in Zacatecas, this sleepy city of 13,000 people was once known for the heroes it brought to the Mexican Revolution and the migrants it sent to the United States. The assassination of the police chief in September reflected his new notoriety: Juan Aldama became another front in Mexico's increasingly difficult fight for control of the territory.
This month's arrest of Mexico's former defense minister stunned the nation as US prosecutors claimed he helped the cartel ship thousands of kilograms of heroin, cocaine and methamphetamine to the United States.
But Mexico's crisis goes far beyond the occasional failures that make headlines.

This was once the name of organized crime. A handful of cartels deliver drugs along highways to the United States. As a result of a fundamental shift, today's criminals are infiltrating deeper into the country, infiltrating communities, police forces, and town halls. The vast range of armed groups — perhaps more than 200 — has evolved into a broader range of activities. They not only transport drugs, but they also kidnap Mexicans, take migrants out and turn their businesses from lime producers to mining companies.
“Zacatecas is in the hands of criminals,” said a schoolteacher who heard about the attack on Barron Guzman and who spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation.
“The state government is not in control of the situation.”
Bullet holes pierce a house and grocery store in Juan Aldama after the attack.
It's easy not to notice how much the criminal threat in the country has grown. Mexico is the United States' No. 1 trading partner, a country of bustling factories and quiet beach resorts. But despite 14 years of military operations and $3 billion in US anti-drug assistance, criminal organizations are transforming the Mexican landscape:
- In a secret study conducted in 2018 but not previously published, CIA analysts concluded that drug trafficking groups had gained effective control over about 20 percent of Mexico, according to several current and former U.S. officials.
- The homicide rate has skyrocketed in the past two years to its highest level in six decades; 2020 is approaching another record. Mexico's homicide rate is more than four times higher than that of the United States.
- Hundreds of thousands of people have fled their homes to escape violence; the Mexican Congress is ready to pass the country's first law to help internally displaced persons.
- More than 77,000 people are missing, authorities said this year, far more than previous governments have admitted. This is the greatest crisis of its kind in Latin America since the “dirty wars” of the 1970s and 1980s.
- The State Department is urging Americans to avoid traveling to half of Mexico's states, marking five of them as danger level 4 — the same as Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq.
The Mexican government has denied losing control of any part of the country. But in a little-known passage from his security plan last year, he compared rebel criminal groups with “a level of organization, firepower, and territorial control comparable to what armed political groups had elsewhere.”
President Andrés Manuel Lopez Obrador created a 100,000 strong National Guard to recover territories with little state presence. It's not clear what's going to change. Years of Mexican and American strategy — arresting drug lords, training Mexican police, rebuilding the justice system — have failed to stop the violence.
To describe the crisis, politicians have turned to the language of armed conflict. When nine dual US and Mexican citizens were killed in Sonora last year, President Trump called on the United States to help Mexico “fight its WAR on drug cartels.”
[How the cartel wars in Mexico destroyed the peaceful but dangerous existence of American Mormons]
But the arrest of the ex his Mexican defense minister in Los Angeles this month illustrates the complexity of the situation. Federal prosecutors say General Salvador Cienfuegos collected bribes from the H-2 cartel based in Nayarit.
“Today we don't have an insurgent group in Mexico that says, 'We're going to overthrow the state, '” said Romain Le Court, co-founder of Noria Research, which studies violence and political systems. “There are very, very violent groups in Mexico that are somehow collaborating with the system because they need the system to really survive and thrive.”
The struggle for territorial control looks different in different parts of Mexico.
The northwestern state of Sinaloa, formerly owned by Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, was dominated by a single cartel for many years. Even though the drug lord is in an American prison, the group is holding tight: when the military tried to arrest Guzman's son Ovidio last year, numerous militants besieged the state capital and the authorities released him.
According to Falco Ernst, senior Mexico analyst at the International Crisis Group, in Guerrero, a state roughly the size of West Virginia, at least 40 armed groups are fighting for dominance in cities and businesses ranging from heroin to logging. The situation illustrates the extreme fragmentation of organized crime in some areas.
Zacatecas is an example of a third way. At first glance, the situation seems peaceful. It is dotted with farms and ghost villages, mostly abandoned by migrants in the U.S. The state capital, also called Zacatecas, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is famous for its charming Spanish colonial square and pink stone cathedral.
An empty house in Ojo de Agua, a farming community in Zacatecas. The state has many farms and villages abandoned by migrants in the US.
A woman in Juan Aldam prepares atole, a traditional hot drink based on corn and masa, at a celebration of Our Lady of Sanctuary.
A child sits during a photo shoot for his third birthday in the historic center of Zacatecas, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The police patrol the streets. But in many places they have been outarmed or intimidated. One day this year, for example, a column of 60 heavily armed men in white pickup trucks roared into Valparaiso's central square. “The Jalisco Cartel!” some shouted, as can be heard on video on social media. Mayor Eleuterio Ramos Leal said only about 15 police officers were on duty. He told The Washington Post that challenging the militants “could end in a massacre.”
It's not that drug cartels were the first to appear in Zacatecas. For many years, they've been transporting marijuana and cocaine along roads to the US border. Now the fight “is not about control of the route,” said Ismael Camberos, who until recently served as head of state security forces. “This is control over the territory to engage in all types of illegal activities.”
Four cartels are fighting for control of fentanyl routes through Zacatecas, while small groups rob and extort money from ordinary Mexicans. In northern Zacatecas, where Juan Aldama is located, a faction of the Sinaloa cartel led by Ismael “El Mayo” Zambad entered. Militants were seen riding pickups freely around the area, with the inscription “MZ” on their helmets or assault rifles.
According to Governor Alejandro Tello, criminals threatened more than half of the state's mayors. Gangsters often “force” local officials to cooperate, said Alma Gloria Davila, a state deputy.
“They lock them in the back of a car, carry them, torture them for a while,” she said. “And then they threaten their families.”
But it's not just that armed groups are intimidating authorities. In many communities, cartels have taken over the government from within.
There is no better example than Nayarit. From the elegant five-star resorts of Punta Mita to the trendy surf village of Sayulita, the Pacific coast state attracts Americans.
But far from beautiful beaches, the Sinaloa and H-2 cartels have been fighting for years.
Edgar Veitia brought peace.
The state attorney general was exactly like a penny of a Mexican lawyer with a round chin and a thick mustache, with a gun stuck behind his belt. He said that “organized crime has no place in Nayarit.” In four years, homicides have fallen by 75 per cent.
In fact, Veitia just chose a side. According to US prosecutors, the H-2 gang paid him monthly bribes. In return, Veitia used his corrupt state police to protect shipments of heroin, cocaine, and other cartel drugs.
According to prosecutors, its officers wiretapped, arrested and even killed the gang's rivals.
Veitia pleaded guilty last year to drug charges in New York. The case drew little attention as it was overshadowed by the controversial El Chapo Guzman trial in the same Brooklyn courthouse. But the news of Cienfuegos's arrest this month comes again drew attention to Nayarit. The H-2 didn't just bribe the state's top lawyer; it allegedly corrupted the head of the Mexican army. (Cienfuegos did not plead guilty.)
An image of Edgar Veitia on the phone of a man whose son disappeared in Nayarit. US prosecutors say Veitia took monthly bribes from the cartel when he was Attorney General.
Of course, drug corruption has a long history in Mexico. During decades of authoritarian rule, top federal officials quietly echoed the cartels. State and local governments took turns taking bribes to ignore how heroin or marijuana flowed through their states.
Mexico's democratization changed the equation. Local governments are now more autonomous. Criminal groups are increasingly seeking influence at the municipal and state levels through threats or bribery.
The country's fragile justice system has been unable to control such bribery.
[Former Mexican drug enforcement official accused of taking bribes from the El Chapo Cartel]
The criminals got the message, said Cecilia Farfan-Mendez, a Mexican security expert at the University of California, San Diego. “Impunity makes you feel like you can do what you want to do.”
Mexico's security crisis has arisen in part because of the very efforts to crush cartels.
As part of the US-backed thief in law strategy, Mexican forces killed or captured the leaders of several powerful groups: the Zeta cartels, Beltran Leyva, Juarez, and Arellano Felix. But this approach not only did not put them out of business, but also made them split.
The Mexican government currently recognizes 19 “powerful” criminal groups, including two with a national reach: the New Generation of Jalisco and the Federation of Sinaloa. The International Crisis Group has identified 198 cartels, gangs and regional groups, many of which are subcontractors to larger players. Eduardo Guerrero, head of security firm Lantia Consultores, has 231.
Smaller groups “no longer have the infrastructure needed to export drugs,” Guerrero said. So they're aimed at Mexicans. They steal, extort, steal fuel, sell contraband cigarettes, and sell methamphetamine to teenagers. The big cartels have also expanded to such predatory activity as to pay their increasingly heavily armed paramilitary units.
“They need territorial control not only to transport drugs, but also to extract resources from the population,” said Ricardo Marquez, a former senior Mexican security official.
[Jalisco's next-generation cartel in Mexico paves a bloody path to power]
The drug trade has also diversified. In addition to producing heroin and marijuana, criminal groups produce methamphetamine in “super labs” and press fentanyl in pills. This requires territorial control. “They need more land to hide and disguise these labs,” said a senior U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss current issues.
Criminal groups have also increased their social control. Davila says her hometown of Tacoaleche is symbolic.
Alma Gloria Davila, an MP in Zacatecas, says criminal groups often “force” local officials to collaborate with them, sometimes abducting them or threatening their families.
“It was all about the dream of a pickup truck,” the MP said. Preferably Chevy Cheyenne. It's that migrants who were successful in the United States went home to a city of 12,000 near the state capital.
More than a decade ago, Davila says, Zetas cartel fighters started showing up in trendy pickups. Several local families had money — cattle, bean farms, shops. But many young people thought they had only two options.
“They could either become a migrant and come back in their pickup truck,” Davila said, “or they could get a pickup truck because they were criminals.”
The young people signed up in search of the Zetas — and provided information about who to kidnap. Davila pointed to some victims: dairy farm workers. Store owners. Farmers.
After the government killed or arrested most of the Zeta leaders, local boys switched to other criminal groups or started their own. A similar picture took place elsewhere.
Pick-up at the municipality of Zacatecas in Guadalupe Province, where Davila's hometown is located.
Davila gives advice to two people after someone breaks into their house.
A man in Guadeloupe sells police equipment from his pickup truck. Violence in the area has increased as cartels fight for control of fentanyl transportation routes.
“Unfortunately, young people have become an army of reservists for organized crime,” The Post told The Post  Alfonso Durazo, Director of Public Security in Mexico. Lopez Obrador is so concerned that he has launched a vocational training program for more than 2 million young people.
Mexico has failed to stop the violence for various reasons. According to analysts and former officials, the government and its allies in Washington have sometimes misunderstood the problem.
Roberta Jacobson, U.S.'s ambassador to Mexico from 2016 to 2018, said that the country's cartels are much more complex than authorities originally thought — more like multinationals than criminal groups. Removing leaders was not enough to destroy them.
“We and Mexicans spent too little time on the entire corporate structure,” including financing and transportation systems, said Jacobson, who was the State Department's top Latin American official from 2012 to 2016.
[Five reasons Mexico opposes Trump's plan to label his cartels as terrorist groups]
There was a second miscalculation: the belief that decapitating cartels would split them into gangs that the local police could handle. “The problem is that Mexico doesn't have the capacity at the state or municipal level” to fight crime, said Eric Olson, a researcher at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington.
And groups were often heavily armed and funded by local criminal activity: kidnappings, extortion, prostitution, migrant smuggling. Authorities “can't come to terms with these organizations, which are pretty much mini-armies,” said Stephen Dudley, co-director of research group InSight Crime.
Mexico has failed to transform the justice system created to serve authoritarian governments during decades of one-party rule. The police are poorly trained and equipped. There are no prosecutors, forensic experts and accountability mechanisms. The result? According to the civic group Zero Impunity, only 1.3 percent of crimes in Mexico are solved and reported.
“You must begin the process of rebuilding the entire security and justice chain in the country,” said Guillermo Valdes Castellanos, former head of Mexico's national intelligence agency CISEN. According to his estimates, this could take a generation and require tripling the budget for security and justice.
Although Mexico has increased its spending in these areas, it still accounts for only about 1 per cent of the country's gross domestic product, much less than in most industrialized countries. “Politicians don't care,” Valdes Castellanos said. “They don't understand that this is a problem and that institutions need to be redesigned to solve it.”
The US government has provided $3 billion in aid since 2007 under the Merida Initiative. In recent years, he has focused on institution building, including police training and supporting the restructuring of the Mexican legal system.
“But this is not due to the process of integrated reform” led by the Mexican government, said Alejandro Hope, a security analyst based in Mexico City. And many Mexicans say the United States has not done enough to reduce American demand for drugs or to stop the flow of illegal firearms across the border.
Shortly before Lopez Obrador took office in December 2018, the CIA concluded that drug groups controlled about 20 percent of Mexican territory, according to several current and former officials who spoke on condition of anonymity about the classified document. The agency declined to comment. Such studies are unusual; while the US government regularly maps the locations of rebels in places like Colombia and Afghanistan, it is harder to assess criminals' quiet control over local economies and political systems.
Lopez Obrador focuses on social programs aimed at combating poverty, which is the root cause of crime. Abrazos no balazos, he says: hugs, not bullets. At the same time, he relied heavily on the military to respond to violence, as well as the new National Guard, which had received military training.
Durazo, chief of public safety, notes that there are three times as many guards as the now dissolved federal police. “I don't think it's possible to talk anymore about regions of the country where there is no state,” Durazo said. (This month, Durazo announced he was resigning to run for governor of Sonora.)
And there have been some successes. Lopez Obrador's government has drastically reduced theft from oil pipelines, and car thefts have fallen by almost 40 percent. The Treasury Department has frozen about $525 million in suspicious bank accounts this year, twice as much as in all of 2019.
But murders that have already reached historic highs, etc. borrowed to grow this year despite the coronavirus outbreak in the country. Extortion has also increased. US agents say Mexico's drug trade is booming. “We've never seen Mexico produce this much methamphetamine,” said a senior DEA official.
The massive flow of drugs to the United States is just one of the consequences of Mexico losing control over parts of its territory. The other is displacement.
Brandon, 9, is petting his family dog on the roof of his home in Juan Aldam. His mother, Consuelo, has been concerned about the chaos in the city in recent years.
Consuelo, 35, and her three children are sitting in their bedroom. The family tried to flee to the United States to escape danger in their city.
Consuelo's youngest son is playing with a curtain in their house.
Consuelo, 35, a full-time mother of three, has become concerned in recent years about the chaos in Juan Aldama.
There have been robberies, disappearances, and street drug dealing in their neighborhood. Then one night in July 2019, gunmen ambushed and killed the chief of police. Officers have disappeared from the streets.
“My husband told me: 'We must get out of here, '” she said, provided that her last name would not be disclosed out of concern for her safety. “He said to me, 'Can't you see there's no police? Can't you see they're scared? Who's going to protect us? ”
She heard that the United States was offering asylum to Mexicans at risk. The family stuffed their clothes into their backpacks and boarded a bus to take the 600-mile ride to the Texas border.
Francisco Javier Adame watched the increasing exodus from the nearby village of Ojitos. Some people were quitting low-paying jobs, said Adam, a senior official in the city. But many fled from local rings to kidnap people.
“Look, we don't have anything,” he said. “They'll decapitate you if you don't pay.”
According to researchers at the University of California at San Diego and the University of Texas, by November last year, more than 11,000 Mexican asylum seekers had crossed the border. US officials had never seen anything like it. But far from expanding the asylum system, the US government has tightened it. Many applicants had to wait in Mexico. Consuelo's family is back home.
The number of Mexicans seeking asylum abroad has slowed this year as the Trump administration effectively halted the process during the pandemic. But the pause may be temporary.
Residents of Juan Aldama were amazed by the news last month that another police chief had been shot dead. Barron Guzman had only been at work for a month.
“I think people will keep leaving,” Consuelo said.
A more serious displacement crisis is taking place in Mexico. In some states, like Guerrero, entire communities were deserted as armed groups approached.
In March, for example, militants forced 800 people to leave their homes in three villages in Leonardo Bravo's municipality.
In many other places, residents are leaving quietly, one family at a time.
The state statistical agency estimates that more than 1.In 2018, 7 million Mexicans fled crime, the highest number in nine years, according to surveys. Congress is expected to soon approve Mexico's first aid law for displaced persons, reflecting the growing efforts of civic groups and some officials to shed light on the huge losses caused by Mexico's security crisis.
In Nayarit, scores of people expressed their suffering to the “truth commission” set up by activists to document violations during Veitia's rule. Residents accuse him of using threats and imprisonment to force citizens to hand over property. Mothers demanding justice are protesting in front of the Attorney General's building, putting up photos of their children, who they say have disappeared by the Veitia police wearing masks.
“The criminal group has taken over the institutions of Nayarit for six years,” said Rodrigo González Barrios, a spokesman for the truth commission.
Veitia is serving a 20-year sentence; former Governor Roberto Sandoval has been sanctioned by the US government for allegedly taking bribes from drug traffickers. (He denied wrongdoing).
The besieged residents of Nayarit thought the picture couldn't be darker. Then the country's former defense chief was arrested.
According to González Barrios, drug corruption seems to have reached the very top. “Who can we believe in?”
Prickly branches block the entrance to an abandoned building in Jerez, Zacatecas.
Greg Miller contributed to this report.
The drug cartel destroys enemies with bomber drones
These officers, who all shouted the nickname of their main boss, Nemesio “El Mencho” by Oseguer Cervantes, throughout the footage, reportedly belong to a “special forces” contingent in the cartel's overall force structure.
This video follows CJNG's failed assassination attempt on Mexico City Police Chief Omar Garcia  Harfuha in June. Harfuch was injured in a shootout and two of his bodyguards were killed.
CJNG's growing resources are also reflected in its new air capabilities. In April, it was reported that CJNG dropped improvised explosive devices from small conventional manned aircraft during attacks on members of the Tepalcatepec self-defense militia. The cartel apparently quickly abandoned this tactic after Mexican authorities increased aerial surveillance of the region and have since switched to using miniature drones.
Quadcopters carrying explosives, allegedly owned by CJNG, were also discovered in April in Puebla in the homonymous state southeast of Mexico City. Mexican officials said they believed they were designed to attack the Santa Rosa de Lima cartel in the northwest state of Guanajuato. The discovery of these drones led to raids that found more quadcopters, as well as various electronics and bomb-making materials, including even more C4s.
It is not at all surprising that the CJNG, in particular, has turned to small unmanned systems as a means to carry out various campaigns of violence across Mexico. Mexican cartels, among other criminal groups, are already using them to carry drugs over walls and other obstacles, as well as for surveillance. At least since 2017, there have been more frequent reports that other cartels used small drones with explosives.
The barrier to entry when it comes to building small ATVs with bombs and hexcopter-type drones is generally particularly low. This is something that the War Zone has repeatedly emphasized in the past, which makes this concept particularly attractive to non-state actors.
In 2018, a group opposed to Venezuela's dictatorial President Nicolas Maduro tried to assassinate him at a public rally using a commercially available multi-rotor drone system. This comes years after ISIS terrorists largely brought this concept to the real battlefield in Iraq.
Since then, small drones with various types of homemade munitions have been steadily spreading among terrorists and other armed groups in Iraq and Syria. The Russian Syrian post at the Khmeimim airbase has been regularly attacked by drones since 2018.
In July, authorities in the Iraqi capital Baghdad discovered an unmanned quadcopter with a very specific-looking bomb underneath it in a neighboring area near the heavily fortified Green Zone, where various government buildings and embassies, including the United States, are located. Iranian-backed militias often use these surrounding areas to launch rockets at the U.S. Embassy compound.
These are just a few of the easily accessible examples of this tactic being used. In fact, when it comes to the dangers of using drones to kill criminal gangs, Japanese authorities warned back in 2015 that Yakuza families are doing exactly what CJNG is currently doing in Mexico.
Even larger nation-state militaries are starting to use the relative simplicity of these drone quadcopters as a starting point for more sophisticated weapon systems, including designs that can work together in autonomous swarms. Turkey is now launching the drone system you're all reading about here.
This reality has made the United States, among others, struggle to catch up when it comes to developing countermeasures. The US military is generally exploring a wide range of different anti-drone technologies to combat these lower-level threats, ranging from jammers to directed-energy weapons, including both lasers and high-power microwaves.
“I keep arguing with my Air Force friends that the future of flying is vertical and unmanned,” said W., US Central Command chief General Kenneth McKenzie said at a public event in June.
“I'm not talking about large unmanned platforms the size of a regular fighter plane that we can see and work with like any other platform. I'm talking about one you can go and buy at Costco right now in the United States for a thousand dollars, four ATVs, a rotorcraft or something like that you can launch and fly,” he added. “And with very simple modifications, you can turn it into something that can drop a weapon, like a hand grenade or something else. “Recent activities
CJNG only emphasizes that there is a serious need for countermeasures outside the battlefield to protect VIPs, critical infrastructure and much more from espionage and potentially dangerous harassment, as well as intentional lethal attacks. The need for any mobile equipment The fight against unmanned aerial vehicles as an “emerging requirement” just this week.
If this cartel successfully adds small armed drones to its already significant arsenal and shows that they can be useful on a more regular basis, it could easily lead to the explosion of other criminal groups in the country and abroad that are also using this tactic.
Contact the author: [email protected]
From drones with bombs to drug banks: Mexican cartels
, article
A forensic examination is exhuming human remains found in Huitzuco de los Figueroa, Guerrero, Mexico. (Photo from Pedro PARDO/AFP archive via Getty Images)
NEW YORK — Mexico's increasingly militarized crackdown on powerful drug cartels has left nearly 39,000 unidentified bodies languishing in the country's morgues, a grotesque symbol of the ongoing drug war and rampant violence.
Quinto Elemento Labs, an investigative NGO, found in a recent report that an alarming number of people were simply buried in mass graves without proper autopsies, while others stayed in funeral homes.
The so-called war on drugs has taken the lives of almost 300,000 people in the past 14 years, and another 73,000 are missing.
At the same time, these cartels have yet to be recognized as official terrorist organizations, despite the fact that they boast well-documented arsenals of sophisticated weaponry to compete with most feared militias on battlefields abroad.
Just last month, reports surfaced that Mexico's next-generation Jalisco cartel (CJNG) now owns bomb-carrying drones that The Drive combat zone describes as “small drones like quadcopters carrying small explosive devices to attack enemies.”
“Mexican cartels operate like a sophisticated terrorist group and use sophisticated weapons to kill and intimidate. They use military-grade weapons and pose a serious threat to US national security,” Derek Maltz, former Drug Enforcement Agent (DEA) Chief of Special Operations, told Fox News. “As Mexican cartels expand around the world and increase their revenues, they use the latest and greatest technologies and buy better weapons.”
At the end of July, two dozen explosive-laden quadcopters were reportedly removed from a cartel car in Michoacán. Container-like bombs filled with C4 charges and ball bearings that functioned like shrapnel stuck to the drones.
While cartels have previously used air assets to distribute drugs through border barriers and surveillance, recent discoveries have raised deeper questions about their combat tactics.
“Between 2012 and 2017, Mexican cartels made 850 incursions into the United States using drones,” said Lee Houghton, co-founder and COO of Mexico's Fortress Risk Management, citing government data and intelligence collection. “For the most part, the Sinaloa, Los Zetas and Jalisco Nueva Generacion cartels have surpassed the Mexican and US authorities with their drone fleet.”
Since 2014, according to a Robotics Business Review report, Mexican cartels have learned how to create and use drones for their criminal activities, explaining this by the fact that a drone can carry more than 220 pounds of cocaine. Thus, using drones reduces the risks and costs of drug trafficking.
In addition to the advancing air arsenal, the stockpile of ground weapons is expanding and improving.
In a disastrous and hours-long clash between Mexican police and the infamous Sinaloa cartel over the arrest of Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman's son, the cartel fighters fought back using Barrett 50-caliber anti-tank rifles, a staggering 50-caliber. M2 machine guns were hoisted onto trucks carrying guns, and at least one vehicle with a “makeshift armored turret in the back” was considered “drug tanks” in scenes that reflected the urban combat jungles of Mosul rather than Mexico.
Earlier this month, Mexican authorities also tweeted images of a makeshift tank they dug up while patrolling the rural plains of San Jose de Chila, just west of Mexico City.
“#GuardiaNacional staff found a van with homemade armor allegedly used by a criminal gang in the area,” the Mexican National Guard wrote.
The photos show an enterprising group of scrap metal and glass for use as a bulletproof vehicle, allegedly owned by the Los Viagras cartel, which is currently engaged in a territorial conflict with other regional players.
Homemade armored vehicles are colloquially referred to as “Rhino”, “Batmobile”, “Monster”, or even e “Papemobil”, according to Mexico Daily News. Some of them are additionally equipped with inch-thick steel panels and retain the ability to travel at about 70 miles per hour, hammering nails and oil stains to repel their pursuers from behind.
Houghton stressed that the armored vans used primarily by the CJNG include everything from Ford F150 and 250 to Dodge Ram 1500 to Jeep Wranglers, Hummers and Chevrolet Colorados. He also stressed that, based on extensive intelligence collection, the main cartels own several fragmentation grenades and Molotov pumps.
There are also Russian-made RPG-7 rocket launchers, M2.50 caliber machine guns, M19.30 caliber machine guns, M60 machine guns, RPD light machine guns and M-249 machine guns.
“The most common way to bring weapons into the country is to trade ants, where hundreds of people individually purchase one or more weapons that they deliver to the groups responsible for shipping them to Mexico,” he continued, adding that the infamous Drug Tunnels as a means of drug trafficking north also “have increased over time with lights, ventilation systems and electric train systems.”
At least half of the firearms obtained by the cartels, experts say, are exported from the United States. A 2020 report published by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) shows that weapons are smuggled in small quantities, with cartels providing arms through “straw purchases” that involve recruiting people with “clean” records to buy weapons and then illegally transferring them.
Grillo noted that much of the cartels' skills have recently fallen from their ability to customize and upgrade everything from drones to vehicles to imported weapons—like taking a conventional semi-automatic rifle and turning it into a machine gun or augmenting a simple drone with explosives.
To keep up with air and land, maritime space is also a fast-growing arena for cartels.
Late last year, the world's first drug submarine used for smuggling was seized off the European coast by Spanish authorities, raising questions about how ships risked going thousands of miles undetected. While this particular vessel, not yet fully underwater, has been linked to cartels in Colombia, intelligence reports show that Mexican units have similar capabilities when it comes to self-propelled semi-submersible vehicles (SPSS) or low-profile vessels (LPV).
“This drug trafficking model has been in use since 1993, and cartels have started using it on semi-submersible submarines so that most of the cabin and exhaust pipes are visible above the water,” Houghton explained. “However, there are already new fully submersible models that cannot be detected by infrared systems, radars or sonars, and even when they are capable of transporting large quantities of drugs, their design becomes more complex and, if they are detected, the losses are significant.
Moreover, Johan Obdola, President of Canada's Global Intelligence Organization (IOSI) and former head of the drug enforcement department in Venezuela, said it was difficult to establish the number of drug dealers used for drug trafficking in Mexico.
“We now know that the use of drug submarines and drug traffickers as tactical weapons is being tested in Mexico's Sinaloa and the Jalisco Nueva Generacion Cartel,” he said. “And mostly Cartel del Golf, with support from Colombia, cartels and terrorist groups, including Hezbollah, as well as Al Qaeda and Islamic State militants.”
And while Mexico has dozens of cartels with various gun stores, analysts are increasingly pointing to CJNG as the organization responsible not only for moving about one-third of all drugs from Mexico to the United States — according to official US government figures — but also as using these proceeds to develop a cache of weapons, equipment, and vehicles that pose the biggest threat to Mexico's armed forces.
“Jalisco Nueva Generacion CJNG is becoming the most powerful drug cartel in Mexico,” Obdola warned.
And the cartel itself, of course, does not hide its skills. Over the summer, CJNG released a video of one of its convoys dressed in camouflage trucks, pickups, and SUVs full of installed weapons and armor, as well as heavily armed personnel dressed in tactical gear.
“The Jalisco Nueva Generacion Cartel, or CJNG, is just one example of a cartel that has reorganized its fighters into fully equipped paramilitary units with their own armored vehicles, commercial pickups covered with steel armor plates,” said Miguel Miranda, a global expert analyst in howling new equipment. “The biggest cartels have always held significant stocks of small arms for their fighters. But three different weapons have made the cartels better armed than any local police force they might encounter. We are talking about the RPG-7, an ubiquitous missile launcher that originated in the Soviet Union — a Barrett .50 anti-material rifle manufactured in the United States and a Browning caliber heavy machine gun.

title: Bills Allow Idled Hog Farms to Return Under Old Environmental Standards
author: Gabe Rivin
description: Some hog farms affected by the recent recession could reopen with waste lagoons, though the number may be small. By Gabe Rivin In the North Carolina House and Senate, lawmakers have approved legislation granting a reprieve to inactive hog farms, allowing some older farms to return to operation without meeting newer standards for managing hog […]
text:
Some hog farms affected by the recent recession could reopen with waste lagoons, though the number may be small.
By Gabe Rivin
In the North Carolina House and Senate, lawmakers have approved legislation granting a reprieve to inactive hog farms, allowing some older farms to return to operation without meeting newer standards for managing hog waste.
Lawmakers have included the legislative language in two bills: HB 760, the House’s regulatory reform bill, and SB 513, the Senate’s farm bill. Both bills have been approved in their respective chambers.
The North Carolina Pork Council, the state’s industry group, has pushed for the legislation, arguing that it protects farmers who have suffered from an unstable demand for pork.
![A waste lagoon outside of a hog farm. Photo courtesy N.C. Department of Environment and Natural Resources](https://i0.wp.com/www.northcarolinahealthnews.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Hogs_lagoon.jpg?resize=300%2C172&ssl=1)
“Several years ago, around the time that the economy tanked, a couple of pork production companies went bankrupt, and there were a number of farmers that found themselves without a contract with a pork production company,” said Angie Maier, the director of policy development and communications at the Pork Council. “[They were] without pigs, without the ability to make a living.”
Under current law, if hog farms have been inactive for four or more years and then return to operation, they must meet the stricter environmental standards placed on new farms.
These standards include a ban on the use of anaerobic lagoons, which treat hog waste, and systems that spray the treated waste onto nearby fields.
But upgrading to new, more environmentally protective technology can be prohibitively expensive, Maier said.
The bills before the General Assembly would rewrite these requirements. Under the Senate’s and House’s bills, hog farmers would be allowed a 10-year window of inactivity. After this period, they would be subject to the environmental standards placed on new farms.
Statewide research has indicted hog farms for a number of health issues, including increases to nearby residents’ blood pressure and spikes in harmful air pollutants such as hydrogen sulfide. Residents have complained of headaches, diarrhea, drug-resistant bacterial infections and the nuisance of bad odors, an apparent consequence of living near hog farms that use lagoon and sprayfield systems.
The issue is most pronounced for residents in North Carolina’s eastern counties, where hog farms are densely clustered. Many residents in these counties are poor and racial minorities, a pattern that environmentalists have cited in a legal complaint to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, claiming that North Carolina’s hog regulations are racially discriminatory. The EPA is currently investigating the claim.
However, the bills before the General Assembly could have a limited impact on health, given the overall size of the industry. The Pork Council estimates that only about 20 farms currently would benefit from the legislative provisions.
After the storms
North Carolina’s current swine regulations date back to the 1990s, when lawmakers and residents witnessed the gruesome combination of eastern hurricanes and industrial animal production.
![Drowned hogs in the aftermath of Hurricane Floyd. Photo courtesy UNC-Chapel Hill](https://i0.wp.com/www.northcarolinahealthnews.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/hogs_floyd.jpg?resize=266%2C178&ssl=1)
In 1996, Hurricane Fran flooded eastern North Carolina, killing some 16,000 pigs and carrying away the animals’ waste. Three years later, the public saw more images of pink floating bodies, as Hurricane Floyd hurt the state’s pork industry, drowning about 30,000 hogs and once again carrying away their waste.
The hurricanes, among other issues, led the General Assembly to set strict limits on the pork industry. Beginning in 1997, hog farmers were prohibited from constructing or expanding farms and waste lagoons.
In 2007, the General Assembly passed a law to make the moratorium permanent on lagoons and spray systems. In addition to the moratorium though, the law set additional environmental requirements for new or expanded farms. Under the law, new farms would have to meet environmental performance standards, which called for reduced groundwater contamination and airborne ammonia at farms, among other requirements.
The state’s intention was that “these farms are on the ground, but we think if you’re going to have new farms that you need to meet a higher standard,” said Tom Bean, a consultant with the Environmental Defense Fund. “That’s because lagoon and sprayfield systems were not adequate.”
But the 2007 law left an exception. Farms that already had permits were exempt from these standards.
Numerous farms, then, could still use open-air lagoons and spray systems to manage hog feces, so long as they already had a permit. Yet if a farm sat empty for four or more years, it would lose that  exemption – a potentially costly problem for farmers, and the reason for this year’s bills.
Two sides work together
Environmentalists, including the Environmental Defense Fund, collaborated with the pork industry to shape the legislation, a joint effort that Bean said he appreciated, given the industry’s influence in the General Assembly.
Environmentalists were concerned after House lawmakers approved a version of the legislation with potentially large loopholes. In its original form, the legislation would have allowed an idled farm to reopen without meeting the 2007 standards, so long as it had been idle for five or more years.
![Hogs_map](https://i0.wp.com/www.northcarolinahealthnews.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Hogs_map.jpg?resize=450%2C251&ssl=1)
“It seemed ludicrous to imagine that in a hundred years it would still be possible to repopulate a farm no matter how long it had been out of operation, using technology that was current at the end of the 20th century,” Bean said.
The provision also could have allowed the reopening of farms that throughout the early 2000s received public funds to close, according to Michelle Nowlin, a lecturer at Duke University’s law school. These were farms that had a higher risk of flooding during large storms and hurricanes.
The farms received both state and federal money to close. In addition, some farms received funding through pork giant Smithfield as part of a legal agreement between the company and North Carolina’s state government, seeking a phasing out of open-air lagoons in the aftermath of Hurricane Floyd.
Recognizing these issues, environmentalists and the pork industry struck a deal on the 10-year window. Additionally, under the bills farms could not reopen with lagoons if they had received public funds or settlement funds to close or if they lay within the areas that historically have flooded.
“It is my understanding that all groups are comfortable with the clarifications made forth in this amendment,” said Rep. John Bell (R-Goldsboro), a primary sponsor of HB 760 and the House majority whip, while speaking to the full House.
Bean, of the Environmental Defense Fund, said that he still opposes the new legislation. He also said that the legislation could upset some residents near idled farms.
But the Pork Council sees this year’s legislation as bringing parity to the law.
“If you have two farms that were built in the same year, that are the same size, and everything about them is the same except one has continued to operate and the other one didn’t have animals for more than four years, there’s nothing different about those two facilities,” Maier said. “The law was treating them differently, and for an arbitrary reason.”

title: Are These Pictures of Pigs on a Farm Flooded by Hurricane Florence?
author: Dan Evon
description: Photographs showing a group of pigs on a flooded farm are real, but they were not taken after Hurricane Florence in 2018.
text:
Photographs showing a large number of pigs on a flooded farm were circulated in the wake of Hurricane Florence in September 2018, along with a caption asserting that the pictures showed "The victims nobody talks about":
These images are real, but they do not depict the aftermath of that September 2018 storm. The two aerial photographs were actually taken in September 1999 near a farm in North Carolina after Hurricane Floyd, with the largest image in this collage captured by Rick Dove of the Waterkeepers Alliance:
In September 1999, almost immediately after receiving two strikes from Hurricane Dennis, Hurricane Floyd came roaring through Eastern North Carolina. In his path lay nearly 2,000 factory farm cesspools loaded with hundreds of millions of gallons of toxic fecal waste, wastewater treatment plants, factories and communities, many of which were in the flood plain.
Hurricane Floyd produced some heavy rains. Unsustainable development greatly aggravated the storm's impacts. Most areas received around 10 inches of rain. A few received 20 inches.
The other aerial photograph showing a group of pigs on the roof of a farm structure was taken by photographer Mel Nathason. In addition to creating an "agricultural nightmare" that left millions of animals (including an estimated 30,000 hogs) dead, Hurricane Floyd also flooded "manure lagoons" causing fecal contamination of North Carolina's drinking water:
What happens when storm floods meet vast confined hog-rearing facilities and their lagoons? The Waterkeeper Alliance’s Rick Dove has been taking extraordinary aerial photos like the one above. Typical hog confinements, like the white buildings on the right in that photo, hold about 2,000 hogs each. According to the Environmental Working Group, there are 586,092 hogs in Wayne County and 229 manure lagoons.
Waterkeeper Alliance’s Dove told me that in his recent airplane forays over eastern North Carolina, “Some of those lagoons were so submerged that we didn’t even know they were there when we photographed them.”
[Robert B. Jackson, an environmental scientist at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina] pointed to a 1999 hurricane that flooded hog farms in North Carolina. "Hurricane Floyd came through and flushed the contents of the hog waste lagoons out into the streams and rivers," he said. The result was widespread fecal contamination of drinking water. More than decade after Floyd, North Carolina still has more than 4,000 hog waste lagoons.
We have not been able to pinpoint the exact origins of the two close-up photographs showing a hog in flooded waters but these images were both likely taken in 2008 during a flood in Iowa. Both images are included on the web site of the Kinship Circle, an Animal Advocacy, Education and Disaster Rescue organization that saved hundreds of hogs after a massive flood left some parts of Iowa under 12 feet of water.
Although these pictures didn't originate with Hurricane Florence, North Carolina may be facing similar problems to encountered after Hurricane Floyd. The state has changed some of their farming policies since 1999 to prevent similar agriculture disasters, but manure pits at some hog farms have reportedly failed in the wake of Hurricane Florence:
Flooded rivers from Florence’s drenching rains have swamped coal ash dumps and low-lying hog farms, raising pollution concerns as the swollen waterways approach their crests.
North Carolina environmental regulators say several open-air manure pits at hog farms have failed, spilling pollution. State officials also were monitoring the ongoing threat from the breach of a Duke Energy coal ash landfill near Wilmington.
A similar photograph of drowned pigs was circulated in conjunction with Florence, but this one stemmed from a flood in Vietnam the previous year and had nothing to do with the September 2018 hurricane:

title: Advocacy - Cape Fear River Watch
text:
Advocacy
Advocacy
–
More ADVOCACY items
Our Advocacy Efforts…
Along with support from our partners, members, donors and grantors, we celebrated some major advocacy wins in 2019 and continued our work to protect and improve the water quality for the 1 in 5 North Carolinians who live in the Cape Fear River Basin, North Carolina’s largest watershed.
Here are a few of the highlights:
- We won a multi-year fight against the poorly conceived attempt to reclassify of a portion of the Lower Cape Fear as a swamp!
- Through our lawsuit, represented by Southern Environmental Law Center, we forced toxic polluter Chemours to invest hundreds of millions to clean-up pollution at their site and in OUR river; our legal victory, represented by EarthJustice, ensured that the US EPA doesn’t backslide on a needed overhaul of the Toxic Substances Control Act.
- We conducted more than 20 flights and countless ground patrols documenting pollution and resulting in numerous referrals of waste management violations on swine and poultry farms to the state.
- We worked with partners nationwide to push back on the weakening of the Clean Water Rule.
- We educated and organized members on the waste management permit for swine farms, and continued to push the state for improvements to protect communities impacted by environmental injustice.
- We continued to investigate the extent of coal ash contamination from spills in Sutton Lake and the Cape Fear; stressed the need for the state to adopt a strong Environmental Justice Assessment Tool, and urged the NC General Assembly to vote “no” on numerous bad bills that threaten the Cape Fear Basin.
- We collaborated to submit public comments on numerous proposed projects in our area including the Cape Fear River crossing, the State Port Expansion, the Clean Water Rule and Section 401 of the Clean Water Act, the Southport Power Plant permit, and Hog Waste Biogas.
- Want to help? Strength in advocacy comes in numbers. JOIN TODAY
With your help, Clean Water is possible.

title: RCC Coasts and Ocean Program
text:
RCC Coasts and Ocean Program
The work of the Rachel Carson Council on climate change and environmental justice frequently crosses boundaries; it eliminates the edges between issues. Our work in North Carolina, for example, focused first on huge industrial factory farms (CAFOs) jammed with hogs. Our concern dealt with air and water pollution, methane and climate change, the impact of hurricanes and flooding on CAFOs, and the environmental health and rights of those living around and working in CAFOs who are disproportionately poor, African American, and other people suffering environmental, economic and political injustice. Our work led us to the clear-cutting of forests, the destruction of coal ash pits, off-shore drilling, food insecurity, clean water, clean energy projects, both on and offshore, and ultimately to the ocean.
Like life itself and all species, the issues that concern the Rachel Carson Council ultimately connect to the sea. It is where, as Rachel Carson made us realize, all life began and all life returns. Until recent times, the oceans and our shores seemed too vast to be harmed by human intervention and use. Today, humans, in our arrogant belief that we can subdue and control nature and put it to our use, threaten the entire planet, its land and water, and all its ecosystems, including oceans, bays, inlets and coasts near which some 40% of Americans now live, work and play.
Rachel Carson began her writing and her work around the sea and its edges from the rocky coast of Maine to the beaches and barrier islands of North Carolina and on to the coasts and mangroves of Florida and the Keys. It is what she knew and loved best. But as a trained scientist, writer and advocate she also drew on countless scientific studies, colleagues and environmental organizations around the country and the world that also led her, though she traveled little, to concerns for farm workers in California, mothers and children exposed to radiation in the Arctic, and the growing destruction of marine life .
Given the history, mission and capacity of the Rachel Carson Council, our program on Coasts and the Ocean emphasizes the Atlantic Ocean and its large, heavily populated coastal regions, especially those that Rachel Carson knew, loved and sought to protect and where the RCC believes it can make the most difference.
Two New Right Whale Calves Spotted Off Coasts of NJ, FL Two new right whale calves spotted in two days makes for an exciting start to February for one of our most endangered whale species. Seen hundreds of miles apart, the newest right whales were born to moms Accordion and Cashew. Read more Record Ocean Warming in 2024 is a Warning For Our Planet A new study led by Lijing Cheng, a professor in the Institute of Atmospheric Physics at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, brings this alarming fact into sharp focus. “The broken records in the ocean have become a broken record,” said Professor Cheng, who led a research team of 54 scientists from seven countries. Read more Click here for Past Issues of the RCC Coasts and Ocean Observer Click here for Previous Coasts and the Ocean News
Latest News About Coasts and the Oceans
The two new right whale calves were spotted with their mothers Accordion and Cashew this week, bringing the season’s total calves to nine.
The ocean, which covers 70% of Earth’s surface, is reaching unprecedented high temperatures – not just at the surface but throughout the upper 2,000 meters (6,561 feet).
Sign Up Here to Receive the Monthly RCC Coasts and Ocean Observer and Other RCC Newsletters, Information and Alerts.
Two New Right Whale Calves Spotted Off Coasts of NJ, FL
Two new right whale calves spotted in two days makes for an exciting start to February for one of our most endangered whale species. Seen hundreds of miles apart, the newest right whales were born to moms Accordion and Cashew. Read more
Record Ocean Warming in 2024 is a Warning For Our Planet
A new study led by Lijing Cheng, a professor in the Institute of Atmospheric Physics at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, brings this alarming fact into sharp focus. “The broken records in the ocean have become a broken record,” said Professor Cheng, who led a research team of 54 scientists from seven countries. title: 5.7 Reading
description: We have seen that in order to remain economically viable and feed large numbers of people, modern agriculture in the United States has had to become larger and more mechanized. As agriculture...
text:
Meat Production Methods
We have seen that in order to remain economically viable and feed large numbers of people, modern agriculture in the United States has had to become larger and more mechanized. As agriculture developed to supply meat and poultry to large numbers of people at a low cost, the primary objective became implementing methods that promoted the faster growth of animals. Methods of meat production include concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs), also called feedlots, and free-range grazing. Meat production is less efficient than agriculture; it takes approximately 20 times more land to produce the same amount of calories from meat as plants.
In 2016, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), roughly 150 million animals were slaughtered for beef, pork and lamb, along with billions of chickens, turkeys and ducks. Many of these animals were raised in CAFOs. Concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) are used as a way to quickly get livestock ready for slaughter. They are large indoor or outdoor structures designed for maximum output. They tend to be crowded, and animals are fed grains or feed that are not as suitable as grass. This type of high-density animal farming is used for beef cattle, dairy cows, hogs and poultry, all of which are confined or allowed very little movement during all or part of their life cycle. A CAFO may contain as many as 2,500 hogs or 50,000 turkeys in a single building. By keeping animals confined, farmers minimize land costs, improve feeding efficiency, and increase the fraction of food energy that goes into the production of animal body mass. Keeping animals confined to a small space, which is criticized by some on ethical grounds, ensures that less energy is expended by the animal in activities such as moving around and the increased respiration that will result. The animals are given antibiotics and nutrient supplements to reduce the adverse health effects and diseases, which would normally be high in such highly concentrated animal populations.
In 2016, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), roughly 150 million animals were slaughtered for beef, pork and lamb, along with billions of chickens, turkeys and ducks. Many of these animals were raised in CAFOs. Concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) are used as a way to quickly get livestock ready for slaughter. They are large indoor or outdoor structures designed for maximum output. They tend to be crowded, and animals are fed grains or feed that are not as suitable as grass. This type of high-density animal farming is used for beef cattle, dairy cows, hogs and poultry, all of which are confined or allowed very little movement during all or part of their life cycle. A CAFO may contain as many as 2,500 hogs or 50,000 turkeys in a single building. By keeping animals confined, farmers minimize land costs, improve feeding efficiency, and increase the fraction of food energy that goes into the production of animal body mass. Keeping animals confined to a small space, which is criticized by some on ethical grounds, ensures that less energy is expended by the animal in activities such as moving around and the increased respiration that will result. The animals are given antibiotics and nutrient supplements to reduce the adverse health effects and diseases, which would normally be high in such highly concentrated animal populations.
High-density animal farming has many environmental and health consequences. There is evidence that antibiotics given to confined animals are contributing to an increase in antibiotic-resistant strains of microorganisms that affect humans. Additionally, feedlots generate a large amount of organic waste, which can contaminate ground and surface water. Waste-disposal is a serious problem. An average CAFO produces over 2,000 tons of manure annually, or about as much as a town of 5,000 people would produce. The waste is used to fertilize nearby agriculture fields, but if over-applied, as is usually the case, it can cause the same nutrient runoff problems as synthetic fertilizer. Sometimes animal wastes are stored in lagoons adjacent to feedlots, but during heavy rainstorms (or hurricanes in eastern NC), runoff from these lagoons can contaminate nearby waterways. Animal wastes have also been dumped, either inadvertently or intentionally, into natural waters. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has concluded that chicken, hog and cattle waste has caused pollution along 56,000 km (35,000 miles) of rivers in 22 states and has caused some degree of groundwater contamination in 17 states.
The use of feedlots are less expensive than other methods, which can keep costs to consumers down, but there are methods for animal production that have a lower environmental impact. Not all meat comes from CAFOs. Free-range chicken and beef are becoming increasingly popular in the United States. Some people find it more ethically acceptable to eat a chicken or cow  that has wandered free than one that has spent its entire life confined in a small space. Free-range meat, if properly produced, is more likely to be sustainable than meat produced in CAFOs. Because these free-range animals are not as likely to spread disease as those kept in close quarters, the use of antibiotics and other medications can be reduced or eliminated. The animals graze or feed on the NPP of the land, eating grass during their entire lifecycle with little or no supplemental feeding, so less fossil fuel goes into the raising of free-range meat. Finally, manure and urine are dispersed over the range area and are naturally processed by detritivores and decomposers in the soil. As a result, there is no need to treat and dispose of massive quantities of manure. Organic waste from these animals act as fertilizer. On the negative side, free-range operations use more land than CAFOs do, and the cost of meat produced using this technique is usually significantly higher.
Overgrazing occurs when too many animals feed on a particular area of land. Overgrazing causes loss of vegetation, which leads to soil erosion. This usually occurs in grasslands where overgrazing leaves bare patches where roots no longer hold the soil together. When this is combined with the action of rain and wind, the bare patches become bigger and soil is removed from the area. As soil formation is a slow process, it will take many years for a region to recover. Overgrazing can also cause desertification. Desertification is the degradation of low precipitation regions toward being increasingly arid until they become deserts.
Less consumption of meat could reduce CO2, methane and N2O emissions, conserve water, reduce the use of antibiotics and growth hormones, and improve topsoil. The activities associated with growing, harvesting, processing and preparing food require a great deal of energy. When we consume meat, we also have to keep in mind the amount of energy that went into producing the food for the livestock.
Raising beef requires more resources than growing corn. Let's look at some of the actual numbers.
On farms in the midwestern U.S., a hectare of land yields roughly 370 bushels of corn (150 bushels per acre). A bushel consists of 1,250 ears of corn, and each ear typically contains 80 kilocalories. Assume that a person eats only corn and requires 2,000 kilocalories per day. Although this assumption is not very realistic, it allows an approximation of how much land it would take to feed that person.
The person's food requirement is
2,000 kilocalories/day x 365 days/year = 730,000 kilocalories/year
A hectare of corn produces
370 bushels/hectare x 1,250 ears/bushel x 80 kilocalories/ear = 37,000,000 kilocalories/hectare
730,000,000/year divided by 37,000,000 kilocalories/hectare = 0.02 ha (0.05 acres) of land to feed one person per year
Thus, one person eating only corn can obtain sufficient calories in a year from 0/02 ha (0.05 acres) of land. What if that person ate only beef? It takes about 20 kg of grain to produce 1 kg of beef. So it would take 20 times as much land, or 0.4 ha (1 acre) to feed a person who ate only beef.
What happens if we extend this analysis to a global scale? If Earth has about 1.5 billion ha (3.7 billion acres) of land suitable for growing food, is there sufficient land to feed all 7.7 billion inhabitants of the planet of they all eat a diet of only beef?
7.7 billion people x 0.4 ha/person = 3, 080,000,000 ha
So 3.08 billion ha (7.61 billion acres) would be needed and the answer is no.
