title: Fact Check: Are fans sneaking beer into Qatar stadiums by disguising them as Coke, Pepsi? Viral pics are old
author: Fact Check Are fans sneaking beer into Qatar stadiums by disguising them as Coke; Pepsi Viral pics are old
description: Following Qatar’s recent decision to reverse the original plan for tournament sponsor Budweiser to sell beer to fans attending the FIFA World Cup 2022, there are several people claiming on social media that beer cans are being disguised as soft drink cans and being snuck into the football stadiums.
text:
![](https://akm-img-a-in.tosshub.com/indiatoday/styles/medium_crop_simple/public/2022-11/image_2_1_1.png?VersionId=XMMP99GHG14F6MNEdfTt2B87b8y_7w1M&h=0de9b95a&size=750:*)
Fact Check: Are fans sneaking beer into Qatar stadiums by disguising them as Coke, Pepsi? Viral pics are old
Following Qatar's recent decision to reverse the original plan for tournament sponsor Budweiser to sell beer to fans attending the FIFA World Cup 2022, there are several people claiming on social media that beer cans are being disguised as soft drink cans and being snuck into the football stadiums.
Listen to Story
India Today Fact Check
Both photos are old and not related to the FIFA World Cup in Qatar. No recent incident of people getting caught with disguised beer cans has been from Qatar so far.
From the very beginning, the FIFA World Cup 2022 in Qatar has been at the centre of controversies. Be it the host's orthodox views on homosexuality, or the treatment of migrant workers who constructed the necessary infrastructure for the event, Qatar has continued to make headlines over the past couple of months.
Following Qatar’s recent decision to reverse the original plan for tournament sponsor Budweiser to sell beer around the eight sites, two photos have started making rounds on social media that purportedly show beer cans disguised as soft drink cans.
People who shared these two photos claimed that football fans were sneaking beer inside the stadium by adding fake Pepsi or Coca-Cola covers to the cans.
"Football lovers finding ways to drink alcohol at the Fifa world cup in Qatar. Fans rebrand Heineken beer cans as Pepsi in other to smuggle to the stadiums and other places after last-minute ban on alcohol by Qatari Authorities," read one such post.
Another such tweet read, "Some supporters have obviously found the technique to drink alcohol in stadiums in Qatar."
Some supporters have obviously found the technique to drink alcohol in stadiums in Qatar. ððº pic.twitter.com/KqaLlHsfpy — World Cup Updates (@wc22updates) November 20, 2022
At the same time, some people also claimed that a few fans are nabbed by the administration when they tried to sneak beer inside the stadium using the same technique.
In Qatar fans who are not allowed to enter the stadium with beer at the World Cup are being caught trying to enter the stadium with Pepsi stickers in this form. It should be noted that Qatar prohibits any alcoholic beverages. pic.twitter.com/JfRViRffTR — Der-daba (@derdaaba8) November 23, 2022
A website called Dimsum Daily also reported hat football fans were purchasing silicone can covers to disguise beer cans as Coca-Cola after alcohol sale at Qatar World Cup stadiums was banned. The story featured one of the viral photos.
AFWA's investigation found that both photos are old and not related to the ongoing FIF World Cup in Qatar.
AFWA PROBE
Upon reverse-searching the first photo — Heineken cans covered with fake Pepsi wrapping — we came across multiple news reports from 2015. One such report from the Newser published on November 13, 2015, featured the same image.
Per the report, a smuggler was held by Saudi Arabia's custom department, who allegedly tried to smuggle 48,000 cans of Heineken beer — all disguised as Pepsi cans. Reportedly, the man got busted while transporting the can into Saudi Arabia via the Al Batha border. Alcohol is banned in Saudi Arabia.
We also found the archived version of a tweet made by the official account of the Customs Department of Saudi Arabia from November 11, 2015. The tweet contained the same image, making it clear that it had nothing to do with this ongoing World Cup.
When we reverse-searched the second photo and found it on various social media sites. Some shared it as early as six months before the World Cup began. For instance, an Instagram user shared this photo on June 9 with the caption, "Just little things like this."
The same photo was also shared by a Twitter account on June 7. A Dailystar report, however, mentioned that this photo was shot in the UK this summer.
We also searched for news reports to make sure if any similar incidents had been reported from Qatar recently and found any credible ones. Although we could not pinpoint the exact date or place where this Coca-Cola-wrapped beer can photo was shot, we are more than sure that neither is related to the ongoing FIFA World Cup in Qatar.
Please share it on our at 73 7000 7000
You can also send us an email at factcheck@intoday.com

title: The mystery of Cathedral of Salamanca’s astronaut figure, isn’t what people think it is
author: Leman Altuntas; Leman Altuntas
description: There is a photograph of an “astronaut” carved in a 16th century Spanish cathedral in Salamanca. Known as the Catedral...
text:
There is a photograph of an “astronaut” carved in a 16th century Spanish cathedral in Salamanca. Known as the Catedral Nueva, the entrance façade of this cathedral features a strange modern figure who appears to be an astronaut wearing a helmet.
This picture, circulating the internet, could easily cause someone to pause and even rethink their position on the validity of ancient aliens.
However, this spacesuit, complete with tubes and boots, shows an accurate depiction of what a man in space would be outfitted with. And the picture is not fiction or fabrication.
The Catedral Nueva, or ‘New Cathedral’ is not new at all, as is the way of many churches in European cities. It’s a building project that started back in 1513, and was interrupted by various events, including the Lisbon earthquake of 1755.
Cathedral of Salamanca is actually two churches joined together, one dates back to the 12th‒13th centuries, while the newer one dates back to the 16th century.
Salamanca’s biggest and loveliest surprise is its enclosed Main Square. Dating from the 18th century, it’s a marvel of sandstone that seems to have survived intact, rather like the Place de Vosges in Paris. Up to 150 years ago, they would have had an unsettlingly fine view of the bullfights that took place in the plaza below. A bull’s head in stone still protrudes over one of the exits from the square to signal the fact.
![View of Cathedral of Salamanca, Castilla y Leon region, Spain.](https://arkeonews.net/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/View-of-Cathedral-min.jpeg)
Salamanca is one of three university cities close to Madrid that attracts visitors interested in culture and particular places of veneration.
As with most pictures that circulate the internet making weird claims, there is a deeper story behind the carving on Catedral Nueva and it doesn’t involve aliens at all.
According to reports, the astronaut carvings were included only recently; in fact they were only included in 1992, and not the 12th or 16th century.
While it is true that Catedral Nueva’s construction began in 1513, under the order of King Ferdinand, married to the famous Queen Isabella, there was no such carving at the time of the project’s completion.
![](https://arkeonews.net/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/famous-astronaut-carved-stone-salamanca-cathedral-facade-spain-min.jpeg)
One of the artists, Jeronimo Garcia, who was responsible for working on the project, decided that he would add a personal touch to the work and decided to include two sculptures that were modern in creation.
The explanation for why an astronaut was selected was because it was a symbol of the 20th century when one of the greatest accomplishments of mankind was achieving space flight and landing on the Moon.
That is not all, as the artist even included figure of a dragon eating an ice-cream, a lynx, a bull, a stork, a rabbit, and a crayfish.
It can be fun to look into concepts like the ancient astronauts theory, but most of the time, there are far more plausible explanations than the idea that aliens once roamed the Earth, inspiring people to carve statues of them into cathedrals.
image_caption: Caption not found;astronaut depiction in Salamanca cathedral

title: Astronaut Carving Found on Ancient Spanish Cathedral
author: Dan Evon; David Mikkelson
description: Rumor: Photographs show the figure of an astronaut carved into the wall of a 12th century Spanish cathedral.
text:
Erich von Däniken's 1968 book Chariots of the Gods? posited that elements of the religions and technologies developed by some of Earth's oldest civilizations were actually the products of extraterrestrial visitations by space travelers whom those ancient Earthlings welcomed as gods. Among the types of evidence von Däniken offered in support of his thesis was his interpretations of ancient artworks as depicting extraterrestrial beings and forms of technological activity that were not realized until the 20th century (such as astronauts and vehicles traveling through air and space).
Chariots of the Gods? has long since been dismissed by most scientists and archaeologists as containing far more pseudoscience than actual science, but fascination with some of the ideas it expressed remains — as evidenced by the example reproduced above, which claims that a cathedral wall in Spain dating from the 12th century bears the mysterious, unexplainable likeness of an astronaut carved by a stonemason over 900 years ago:
Here is a Mystery! See if you can suggest an answer
In the Spanish City of SALAMANCA the Cathedral there was built in 1102
I have asked my work colleagues if this item is TRUE ... and they assure me that it is INDEED (and nobody has an answer)
There is a small detail carved into the masonery which amazes everyone that sees it...
Can You Suggest how a 20th Century Astronaut came to be carved by a 12th Century Stonemason?
First off, the example errs a bit in identifying the astronaut carving as adorning the wall of a cathedral built in 1102. The city of Salamanca in Spain is home to two adjacent cathedrals: The "Old Cathedral" (Catedral Vieja), begun in the 12th century, and the "New Cathedral" (Catedral Nueva), begun in the 16th century. The figure in question is part of latter, not the former. Still, finding this carving of an astronaut on the wall of a cathedral constructed between 1513 and 1733 would be quite remarkable, as the figure anticipates with amazing accuracy a form of technology not realized until centuries later.
Unfortunately for Chariot buffs, however, the origins of the carving are neither ancient nor mysterious. The astronaut figure dates not from the 12th century or the 16th century or even the 18th century, but from 1992, and we know both who put it there and why: The New Cathedral was undergoing restoration work during that period, and one of the artisans engaged in the project chose to engage in a bit of tradition by "signing" his work with a contemporary symbol representative of the 20th century: an astronaut.
A Portuguese article about the restoration of Salamanca's New Cathedral explains (as best we can translate it into English) that:
The restoration of the Cathedral of Salamanca in 1992 integrated modern and contemporary motifs, including a carved figure of an astronaut. The use of this motif was in the tradition of cathedral builders and restorers including contemporary motifs among older ones as a way of signing their works. The person responsible for the restoration, Jeronimo Garcia, chose an astronaut as a symbol of the twentieth century.

title: Parliament Is Becoming The House Of 'Sleepists'
author: Zimkhitha Mathunjwa
description: MPs sleeping on the job is sadly not a new thing, with many tweeps saying that our MPs get paid to snooze.
text:
![](https://img.huffingtonpost.com/asset/5c7e900b20000003046ebfaf.jpeg?ops=scalefit_720_noupscale)
South Africa's Parliament has a knack for napping parliamentarians and the situation does not seem to be getting any better. It almost seems as if there is an unspoken rule that naps are mandatory as a means of rejuvenation to run the country.
The term "sleepists" was coined by Dr Mbuyiseni Ndlozi of the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF). MPs sleeping on the job is sadly not a new thing, with many tweeps saying that our MPs get paid to sleep.
MPs used to sleep in parliament... Thats true. 'Ba gola ba robetse'...they earning salaries while sleeping. #EFFManifesto
— Abuti Neo (@Neo_ChiX) April 30, 2016
@City_Press@andiMakinana :MPs don't deserve salary increase their salaries are already too high they are just sleeping in parliament.
— Cornelius Moshane (@corneymosh) March 11, 2016
It seems the EFF did South Africa a solid in ensuring that all sleepists are called out on their shenanigans and step up to doing what they were called to do.
Here are some of the instances where MPs have taken a quick nap on the job:
@ANCMPS As opposed to sitting in parliament and sleeping like many ANC MPs do? cc @jsteenhuisenpic.twitter.com/UR6xZwTrlF
— I am an African 🇿🇦 (@Clint_ZA) November 23, 2015
And of course, our eternal fave -- Dr "People's Bae" Ndlozi has ensured that Parliament is not a house of sleepists...
It isn't enough that ministers sleep [on the job] during the Parliamentary proceedings, but it seems our very own Number One -- President Jacob Zuma -- has also dozed off in Parly.
It is unacceptable for our public servants to fall asleep on the job. Naps are great -- but not at work, folks! It is time for Parliament to stay awake and fulfill its mandate.

title: Large crowds gather in downtown Toronto for ‘mega march’ in solidarity with Ukraine - Toronto | Globalnews.ca
author: Hannah Jackson; Brittany Rosen
description: Crowds carrying Ukraine flags and signs gathered at Yonge and Dundas Square, and marched towards Nathan Phillips Square in solidarity with the people of Ukraine.
text:
Large crowds gathered in downtown Toronto on Sunday for a “Mega March” in support of Ukraine, and condemnation of Russia’s attack on the country.
Crowds carrying Ukraine flags and anti-Vladimir Putin signs gathered at Yonge and Dundas Square, and marched towards Nathan Phillips Square in solidarity with the people of Ukraine.
Toronto police temporarily closed a portion of Yonge Street and Dundas Street West to allow the demonstrators to march.
However, in an update Sunday afternoon, Toronto police said Yonge Street and Dundas Street West had both reopened. Bay Street remained closed.
In a post on Facebook, the organization said Ukraine is under a “relentless attack from Russia.”
“We cry out to everyone who cares about democracy and freedom to come out in support and in solidarity with Ukraine,” the post reads.
Peter Schturyn, President of the Ukrainian-Canadian Congress, said the goal of the march is to “rally all Canadian Ukrainians, along with the Toronto community (to) stand together (and) stand for our brothers and sisters in Ukraine.”
“We’re out here wanting Russia to stop its useless, senseless, horrific war with a nation that wants nothing but peace,” he said.
Schturyn said the demonstrations in Toronto are going to continue “until every inch of Ukrainian territory is back in Ukrainian hands.”
“They’re fighting until the very end, and so are we,” he said.
- Accused took the wheel ‘minutes’ before fatal Ontario boat crash, court hears
- Ford plans to table law to eliminate internal trade barriers, pushes Ring of Fire work
- Man arrested after allegedly random fatal attack against unhoused person in downtown Toronto
- Ontario man says he is owed $60K for 14 months of unpaid rent
Schturyn said the “tide of the war is changing.”
“The pendulum is swinging back,” he said. “Ukrainians are fighting harder than ever before.”
He said the “whole country is up in arms, standing shoulder-to-shoulder.”
“And they’re going to win.”
![For news impacting Canada and around the world, sign up for breaking news alerts delivered directly to you when they happen.](https://globalnews.ca/wp-content/themes/shaw-globalnews/images/skyline/national.jpg)
Get breaking National news
Schturyn said what Ukraine needs immediately is a no-fly zone to be declared over its airspace.
“It’s not unprecedented, the West has done that for other countries,” he said. “They’ve done if for Libya, they’ve done it in former Yugoslavia. They’ve done it once for Israel.”
Ola Holyk is an elementary school teacher in Mississauga. She and several of her students attended the march on Sunday.
“We all believe in peace, we all feel that Ukraine is part of our heritage, it’s where our grandparents came from, it’s where our parents came from, and we feel it’s really important to be here to stand with Ukraine and to stop the aggression that Russia is bringing on to Ukraine.”
She said she felt she needed to stand up for what she believes in.
“And peace is what we believe in. And peace is at the forefront of all of this,” she said.
“We need to teach our children kindness and we need to teach our children that when it comes to things like this — this is wrong — and through the power of being together and uniting together we are a stronger force.”
Speaking at Nathan Phillips Square, Consulate General of Ukraine in Toronto Oleksander Shevchenko, said it is difficult to watch the invasion of Ukraine from afar.
“But what warms my heart is what Canada is doing to support Ukraine, to support Ukrainian people and (the) Ukrainian military in this time of hardships,” he said.
Shevchenko thanked Toronto Mayor John Tory and Ontario Premier Doug Ford, and the rest of Canada for the “great support” that has been shown.
“It’s very important to know that Canada is ready to provide assistance,” he said.
Shevchenko called on the Canadian government to support and accommodate any Ukrainian refugees who seek asylum in Canada.
Those protesting against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine have gathered in Toronto since Thursday, holding Ukrainian flags and singing the national anthem.
Earlier on Sunday, the federal government announced it has closed Canada’s airspace to all Russian airlines.
The federal government also announced it will be sending an additional $25 million worth of protective gear to Ukraine.
The move comes after Ottawa imposed sanctions on a number of Russian individuals and entities, including on Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Canada has also said it will match all donations to the Red Cross’s Ukraine Humanitarian Crisis Appeal up to $10 million.
The Ontario government has announced it will be donating $300,000 in humanitarian aid to Ukraine.
The money will be donated to the Canada-Ukraine Foundation and used to “support humanitarian purposes” including “providing medical aid, emergency shelter and food security” in Ukraine.
![Click to play video: 'Ontario Premier Doug Ford condemns Russian attack on Ukraine'](https://i2.wp.com/media.globalnews.ca/videostatic/news/hih3 6ivqgk-vcji3dz7l1/DOUGIE_PIC_FEB24_UKRAINE.jpg?w=1040&quality=70&strip=all)
The province said it will also be “ready to assist” anyone fleeing the country who may require settlement services.
On Thursday, the Ukraine flag was raised at Toronto City Hall in solidarity with the Ukrainian people.
In a video posted to Twitter Thursday afternoon, Toronto Mayor John Tory, said if there was “unprovoked military action taken against one of our provinces,” Canada would “expect the rest of the world to line up and support us.”
“That’s why I’m here as mayor of Toronto to express my solidarity with Ukraine,” he said.
“And also at the same time to raise this flag to show solidarity with our wonderful Ukrainian community — our Ukrainian Canadian community here in the city of Toronto.”
Tory attended the march on Sunday.
https://twitter.com/JohnTory/status/1498050346375127040?s=20&t=N0Wl0CtLIs7c5DnkYZBZPQ
In a tweet, the mayor said Toronto “stands in firm solidarity with Ukraine and the local Ukrainian-Canadian community.
Also in attendance was Canada’s Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland.
https://twitter.com/cafreeland/status/1498050242624823298?s=20&t=N0Wl0CtLIs7c5DnkYZBZPQ

title: Is This Farmer Being Executed for Not Working with Castro?
author: David Mikkelson
description: A photograph of a man kneeling before a priest was widely shared on Twitter and Facebook.
text:
In August 2020, social media users circulated a photograph meme said to depict a priest giving the last rites to a Cuban farmer who was being executed because he "refused to work for the Castro regime":
This image was indeed a Pulitzer Prize winner for United Press International (UPI) photographer Andrew Lopez in 1960, who snapped a series of four photographs of a man executed by a Fidel Castro firing squad, of which this picture was one. However, some of the other accompanying details in this meme are not quite accurate.
Fulgencio Batista was the military dictator of Cuba from 1952 until the end of 1958, when he was overthrown by forces led by Castro and his allies during the Cuban Revolution. This photograph does not depict a "farmer [who] refused to work for the Castro regime," but rather a member of Batista's army who had been charged as a war criminal by the victorious revolutionaries a few weeks after they finally ousted Batista.
The UPI caption for this picture read as follows: "Father Domingo Lorenzo performs last rites for Cuban Army Cpl. Jose Cipriano Rodriguez on Jan. 17, 1959. Rodriguez, who had served in Fulgencio Batista's army, was executed by firing squad after being found guilty for the deaths of two brothers. His tribunal lasted just one minute."
A UPI account of the circumstances behind the photograph, which was published in May 1960 when Lopez was awarded the Pulitzer Prize, stated that Rodriguez's trial lasted two hours rather than four minutes (although deliberations afterwards lasted only a minute), and it made no mention of Ernesto “Che” Guevara, a Castro lieutenant, being personally involved in the case (although Guevara reviewed the appeals and firing squad sentences of those convicted as war criminals in post-revolutionary Cuba):
Andrew Lopez, veteran United Press International photographer, felt like crying when he took his Pulitzer Prize-winning photographs of a Cuban war criminal kneeling before a priest, with an impatient firing squad watching.
Lopez was awarded the prize for a series of four photographs of Cpl. Jose (Pepe Caliente) Rodriguez preparing to die.
"When you have a man kneeling, being given spiritual consolation by a priest who is holding a cross in his hand as the victim presses forward to kiss it, there's no question," Lopez said.
"It was packed with emotion. I felt like crying myself," he said.
Rodriguez was sentenced Jan. 17, 1959, after a two-hour trial in San Severino fortress near Matanzas, Cuba. The tribunal conferred for one minute before finding him guilty, Lopez said. Rodriguez was marched from the trial room and taken down a flight of stairs to the courtyard.
"When I saw him marching down the stairs I went in front of him and into this huge, open air, dungeon-like area," Lopez said. "I started to make pictures.
"When Pepe Caliente fell to his knees as a priest held up a cross for him to kiss, the scene was one that will be hard to forget. I honestly felt like crying ...
"While all this was going on, the firing squad in the background impatiently was waiting for this scene to end so they could perform their duty."
The condemned man received a 24-hour stay just before sentence was to be carried out, but he was shot the next day.

title: No, photo shows corporal in Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista’s army receiving last rites, not farmer
author: Makinia Juma Sylvia; Makinia
description: A graphic shared on Facebook shows a black-and-white photo of kneeling man, clasping a small crucifix, while a man dressed as a priest in a long black robe bend...
text:
A graphic shared on Facebook shows a black-and-white photo of kneeling man, clasping a small crucifix, while a man dressed as a priest in a long black robe bends down to speak to him. Heavily armed men look on.
Text above the photo reads: “This picture won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960. It shows a priest giving the last rites to a Cuban farmer, owner of his land. He refused to work for the Castro regime. He died by a firing squad after a ‘trial’ by Che Guevara that lasted 4 minutes. You will never see this picture on a T-shirt.”
The caption refers to the photos of Che Guevara often reproduced on t-shirts. Guevara was an Argentinian communist who was prominent in the Cuban revolution of the late 1950s and other leftist guerilla campaigns in South America.
The graphic is also shared here and here. It was flagged as possibly false by Facebook’s fact-checking system after it was posted in South Africa.
But is this the true story behind the photo?
Photo won 1960 Pulitzer prize
An online search for the phrase “photo that won Pulitzer prize in 1960” reveals that the image did win the Pulitzer Prize for photography in 1960 – or rather, the photographer Andrew Lopez won the prize for the photo.
The Pulitzer prizes are prestigious annual awards in 21 different categories across journalism, literature and music given out almost exclusively to US citizens.
The caption to the photo on the Pulitzer website says that the man in the photo was a former corporal of “Batista’s army”. He was receiving his last rites before his execution, a Catholic ritual performed by a priest before death.
Fulgencio Batista was a dictator who ruled Cuba twice, for the second time between 1952 and 1959. An army under Fidel Castro and Guevara fought and eventually won against Batista’s rule.
These details about the photo were repeated on the Pulitzer Prizes Facebook page on 1 December 2016 when they republished the photo. The caption adds that the photo was taken “moments before he is to be executed by a Fidel Castro firing squad”.
Tribunal lasted ‘just one minute’
According to United Press International (UPI), who Lopez worked for, the famous photo was taken on 17 January 1959. They also add details about the man executed, Jose Cipriano Rodriguez.
UPI say: “Rodriguez, who had served in Fulgencio Batista's army, was executed by firing squad after being found guilty for the deaths of two brothers. His tribunal lasted just one minute. UPI photographer Andrew Lopez won the 1960 Pulitzer Prize for a series of four photos from the scene, including this one.”
None of the sources we found mentioned that Guevara was directly involved in Rodriguez’s tribunal. And Rodriguez was a senior military officer, not a farmer. But he was executed by Cuban communist forces, after they defeated Batista’s army.
Republish our content for free
For publishers: what to do if your post is rated false
A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as “false”, “altered”, “partly false” or “missing context”. This could have serious consequences. What do you do?
Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.Publishers guide
Africa Check teams up with Facebook
Africa Check is a partner in Meta's third-party fact-checking programme to help stop the spread of false information on social media.
The content we rate as “false” will be downgraded on Facebook and Instagram. This means fewer people will see it.
You can also help identify false information on Facebook. This guide explains how.

title: Power & Politics: Making Laws. Making Laws One of the most important things Parliament does is make laws. Before one can be made, someone has to have. - ppt download
description: Unusual Laws in France it’s illegal to call a pig Napoleon.
text:
Download presentation
Presentation is loading. Please wait.
Published byAgatha Neal Modified over 9 years ago
1
Power & Politics: Making Laws
2
Making Laws One of the most important things Parliament does is make laws. Before one can be made, someone has to have the idea: whatever could have led them to some of these?
3
Unusual Laws in France it’s illegal to call a pig Napoleon.
4
Unusual Laws in Ohio it’s illegal to get a fish drunk.
5
Unusual Laws In Kentucky it is illegal to carry a concealed weapon more than six feet long.
6
Unusual Laws in England all men aged over 14 must do two hours of longbow practice a day.
7
Unusual Laws in Vermont a married woman must get her husband’s written permission before she may wear false teeth. “Darling, I found them...”
8
Unusual Laws in York it’s legal to murder a Scotsman inside the city walls, but only if he’s carrying a bow & arrows (like this one).
9
Unusual Laws in London it’s illegal to flag down a taxi if you have the plague.
10
Unusual Laws in Florida unmarried women who parachute on Sundays can be jailed.
11
Unusual Laws in San Salvador drunk drivers may be put in front of a firing-squad.
12
Unusual Laws in Lancashire if a police officer on the seashore has asked you not to incite a dog to bark, & you do, you’re breaking the law.
13
Unusual Laws in Indonesia the penalty for masturbation is decapitation.
14
Making Laws so how does an idea become law in the UK? Let’s find out.
15
1. Drafting the Bill at the beginning the new law is called a draft bill. It has to be drafted (written) very carefully in case any mistakes make it impossible to enforce later.
16
2. First Reading at the First Reading the government tells everyone in Parliament that this is what they intend to do.
17
3. Second Reading this time the bill is explained; Parliament is able to debate reasons for & against passing it, & a vote is taken on whether it should be dropped or carry on its way through the process.
18
4. Committee Stage a group of MPs then examines the bill in detail & suggests changes (which both the House of Commons & the House of Lords must agree on).
19
5. Report Stage the Committee prepares a report on the bill & explains any changes that have been made.
20
6. Third Reading the bill is read for a 3 rd time in Parliament; changes may be made, & there is another vote to see if the House wants the bill to become law.
21
7. The other House a bill passed by the House of Commons must be passed by the House of Lords as well, & vice versa; changes must be agreed by both Houses too.
22
8. Royal Assent the Queen must also agree to the bill, & when she does, it becomes law. it may take place immediately, or be delayed to get people used to the new idea & make necessary preparations.
23
Current laws a few of you please suggest some laws we have now; they’ll go on the board, & we’ll see if you think them fair or unfair (& to whom).
24
Task now, in 3s or 4s, get together to create six laws of your own, three sensible & three more unusual… one group member needs to make sure everyone gets their say. consider why your law is needed (what problem is it trying to solve?) consider what problems / loopholes there could be with your law consider what punishment there should be for breaking your law
25
one group’s ideas: Sensible laws: compulsory National Service raise minimum wage more time at school to replace homework microchip babies at birth death for murderers/paedos to free up prison space study fashion at school Not-so sensible laws: compulsory kisses on Valentine’s Day legal to drive a car at age 14 dogs give permission to go kayaking every Tuesday & Thursday no parents’ evenings
26
another group’s ideas: Sensible laws: don’t microwave your hamster obese people to be fired no motor vehicles to be used on a Sunday no bestiality anyone can run for Prime Minister drug addicts to be executed Not-so sensible laws: don’t make explosives for your animals all ugly people to be shot everything in shops is to be free condoms to be worn on the head go to the toilet on Tuesdays only
27
The vote each group may now present one bill the rest of us will vote on whether or not to make it into law
28
We need… three sensible laws three silly laws in a PowerPoint (ideally) illustrated (take pictures from the Web) save to two computers (in case someone in your group’s away next week)

title: Cuban man pictured receiving blessing before being killed was a soldier, not a peasant
author: Pedro Prata
description: Image won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960, but it circulates out of context on the networks
text:
A photo showing a Cuban soldier from the defeated Fulgencio Batista regime moments before he was shot circulates on social media out of its original context. On Facebook, the image was posted with a caption stating that the man portrayed is a peasant who was killed while refusing to work for the Fidel Castro regime. A version of the post was shared 10,000 times. Identical posts were also found on Twitter and were checked by agencies from other countries.
“That photo won the Pulitzer (Prize),” the caption of the post reads. “A priest giving the last blessing to a Cuban peasant, landowner, who refused to work for the Fidel Castro regime, and who was convicted by “Che”, without the right to defense, to die by shooting. You'll never see that picture on a communist's t-shirt.”
! [] (https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/NS5UT4QDXBIOHLJ46XN7SUAF3A.jpg?quality=80&auth=2c720c5bd3acab6d47932774d1e7d37274013d5180792ffa4e0cffc8705cfba6&width=380 768w, https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/NS5UT4QDXBIOHLJ46XN7SUAF3A.jpg?quality=80&auth=2c720c5bd3acab6d47932774d1e7d37274013d5180792ffa4e0cffc8705cfba6&width=768 1024w, https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/NS5UT4QDXBIOHLJ46XN7SUAF3A.jpg?quality=80&auth=2c720c5bd3acab6d47932774d1e7d37274013d5180792ffa4e0cffc8705cfba6&width=1200 1322w)
Google's reverse search engine allows you to identify the first time the image was published. The survey led to the Pulitzer Prize, the highest honor in journalism in the United States.
The registration earned photographer Andrew Lopez, from United Press International (UPI), the award in the Photography category in 1960. Lopez was part of a group of photojournalists who received authorization from Fidel Castro to freely record whatever they wanted. He decided to photograph the trials and executions of former combatants from Fulgencio Batista's defeated army.
The man in the photo is Jose Cipriano Rodriguez, according to the UPI news agency's website. The caption of the photo states that he was executed on January 17, 1959 for killing two men from Castro's army. His trial lasted one minute.
! [] (https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/CXYNBBBVSBMCRK7JIJBZRVI75M.jpg?quality=80&auth=1b168cf9e658f6f7e95b407b16e1a769fd812b6e7e36330b141ee4f0b267972b&width=380 768w, https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/CXYNBBBVSBMCRK7JIJBZRVI75M.jpg?quality=80&auth=1b168cf9e658f6f7e95b407b16e1a769fd812b6e7e36330b141ee4f0b267972b&width=768 1024w, https://www.estadao.com.br/resizer/v2/CXYNBBBVSBMCRK7JIJBZRVI75M.jpg?quality=80&auth=1b168cf9e658f6f7e95b407b16e1a769fd812b6e7e36330b141ee4f0b267972b&width=1200 1322w)
The photo is also available in the Getty Images collection. None of the sites where Verifica found the photograph indicate whether Che Guevara was involved in the execution of Rodriguez.
The Cuban Revolution began as a nationalist guerrilla in 1959. Led by Fidel Castro, it overthrew the dictatorial government of Fulgencio Batista, which began in 1952 through a military coup.
Cuba is an island in the Caribbean very close to the territory of the United States. For this reason, the Americans followed the island's political changes with tension. The United States broke relations with Cuba and tried to overthrow its government in 1961, without success. The rivalry with the United States ended up making Cuba an ally of the Soviet Union during the Cold War period.
This content was also checked by the agencies Lupa, from Brazil, Polygraph, from Portugal, Maldita.Es, from Spain, and Bolivia Verifica, from Bolivia.
This rumor was verified because it appears among the main suspicious content that circulates on Facebook. Estadão Verifica has access to a list of potentially false posts and to data about their viralization as a result of a partnership with the social network. When our checks find that information is misleading, Facebook reduces the scope of its circulation. Social network users and page administrators receive notifications if they have published or shared posts marked as false. A notice is also sent to anyone who wants to post content that has been previously flagged as untrue.
A prerequisite for participating in the partnership with Facebook is to obtain certification from the International Fact Checking Network (IFCN), which, in the case of Estadão Verifica, occurred in January 2019. The international association of fact checkers requires certified entities to sign a code of principles and to make commitments in five areas: non-partisanship and impartiality; transparency of sources; transparency of funding and organization; transparency of methodology; and open and honest corrections policy. Commitment to these practices promotes more balance and precision at work.

title: No, the man in the photo is not a “Cuban peasant” shot by order of Che Guevara who “refused to work for the Castro regime"·Maldita.es - Journalism so they don't sneak it in
description: A photo of a supposed “Cuban peasant” who would be receiving “the last blessing” from...
text:
A photo of an alleged “Cuban peasant” who would be receiving “the last blessing” from a priest before being shot by order of Che Guevara for refusing to “work for the Castro regime” is circulating on the networks. According to the accompanying text, the image would also have been awarded the Pulitzer Prize in 1960. However, although it is true that he won that award, it is a hoax that he was a peasant or that he was shot for that reason: both the author of the image and the priest who appears in it, as well as the United Press International (UPI) and Getty Images agencies, the organizers of the Pulitzer Prizes and the Bohemia Magazine assure that the man shot, named Jose Cipriano Rodríguez, had been a corporal in the Army of which Fulgencio Batista was president of Cuba and not a “Cuban peasant” who refused “to work for the Castro regime”.
According to the Pulitzer Prize organization, Rodríguez was executed for “war crimes”, while Getty Images and the Cuban magazine Bohemia indicate that he was killed after being accused of murdering two brothers.
! [] (https://maldita.es/app/uploads/2020/09/Cuba3.jpg)
The photo, taken by photographer Andrew López, won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960, as can be seen on the official website of the award. There they explain that the man who appears kneeling in the image was actually a corporal in the Batista Army “executed by a firing squad” of Fidel Castro. This was also indicated by the organizers of the Pulitzer Prizes in a 2016 Facebook post.
The man was a soldier in the Batista Army who was “sentenced to death for war crimes”, according to the Pulitzer Prizes
In that Facebook post, another image is included in which the convict already appears in front of the wall, whose caption states that he had been “sentenced to death for war crimes” and that the trial had lasted “exactly one minute”.
! [] (https://maldita.es/app/uploads/2020/09/Che1-1024x383.jpg)
The image also appears in the archive of the Getty Images agency, where it is located in the Cuban city of Matanzas on January 17, 1959. In the description, they point out that the corporal was called José Cipriano Rodríguez and that he had been convicted “for the deaths of two brothers”, while the priest is identified as Domingo Lorenzo.
The author of the photo and the priest who appears in it say that the shot was a corporal
After searching for information about the religious, we found that he gave his version of what happened in a column published on ABC on November 22, 1962, which is available in his archive. There, Lorenzo explains that the man was called José Rodríguez (although he also names him “Pepe Caliente”) and that he had been “a corporal in the Army of General F. Batista Zaldivar”.
The priest admits that he never knew “what they accused him of, because in the midst of that shouting you couldn't hear the charges against him”, but that in any case he was sentenced to “death by shooting” by Castro commander William Gálvez, who ordered that the execution be carried out at that very moment, although he ended up delaying it the next day since there were “many women” present.
According to Domingo Lorenzo, the commander demanded that the photographers “hand over all the reels of their cameras with the negatives” and that “all but one American delivered them”, referring to Andrew López. You can read the priest's full testimony here.
In an excerpt from the book Picture This! The Inside Story and Classic Photos of UPI Newspictures, López clarifies that he did deliver a reel but that he kept the one containing the photos of Pepe (referring to 'Pepe Caliente'). In any case, the photographer also identifies the prisoner as a corporal and assures that, although the trial itself lasted two hours, it took only a minute for the three judges of the court to sentence him to death. The full extract is available on the website of The Downhold Project, an initiative dedicated to disseminating historical information about the United Press International (UPI) agency, for which Andrew López worked.
The press at the time also described 'Pepe Caliente' as a member of Batista's Army
As can be seen in this article in which they review the life of López and other award-winning photographers, UPI itself also points out that 'Pepe Caliente' had been part of Batista's Army. This is also indicated by the Cuban magazine Bohemia, which in its edition of February 1, 1959, included an article on the trial and execution of Corporal José Rodríguez. In the text, they specify that Rodríguez had been part of the squad of the Cuban municipality of Jovellanos and that “he was found convicted of numerous crimes.” In addition, Bohemia points out that the man shot confessed to the murder of two brothers, something that Maldita.ES has not been able to verify independently.
! [] (https://maldita.es/app/uploads/2020/09/Captura-de-pantalla-2020-09-01-a-las-13.29. 48.png)
In short, the photographer who captured the image, the priest, the UPI and Getty Images agencies, the organizers of the Pulitzer Prizes and the Bohemia Magazine state that the man in the photo who was shot was a corporal in Fulgencio Batista's Army and not a “Cuban peasant” who refused “to work for the Castro regime”.
First publication date of this article: 08/10/2020

title: It is false that the man in this photo was a Cuban peasant who refused to work for the Castro regime and who was shot by order of “Che” Guevara - Checked
author: TOBIAS RENGIFO AND
description: A photograph of a man kneeling receiving a priest's blessing in front of a group of armed men is circulating on social networks. The text that
text:
It is false that the man in this photo was a Cuban peasant who refused to work for the Castro regime and who was shot by order of “Che” Guevara
! [] (https://chequeado.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/PORTADA-Fusilamiento.jpg)
- The kneeling man was an Army corporal during the Fulgencio Batista dictatorship in Cuba and not a “Cuban peasant”. This was stated by the priest of the image, the Pulitzer Prize page and the international agency Getty Images.
- The man in the photo, identified as José Cipriano Rodríguez, was sentenced to shooting after being convicted of the death of two brothers in a trial before a military court, according to the international agency Getty Images.
- The image is by photographer Andrew López and won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960.
A photograph of a man kneeling receiving a priest's blessing in front of a group of armed men is circulating on social networks. The text that accompanies the image states: “This photo won the Pulitzer Prize 1960. A priest giving the blessing to a Cuban peasant who owned his land, who refused to work for the Castro regime... was shot without the right to defense by order of 'Che Guevara' in a 'trial' that lasted 4 minutes. You'll never see this picture on a t-shirt...” However, it is false that the man shot was a “Cuban peasant” who refused “to work for the Castro regime”.
A reverse search for the photograph shows that the photo actually won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960. However, the description of the image captured by photographer Andrew López indicates that the award-winning series consists of four photographs of a corporal, former army of Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista Zaldivar, who was executed by a firing squad of former Cuban leader Fidel Castro. The main image shows the convict receiving the last rites.
The 1959 photo also appears in the international agency Getty Images along with the following description: “In this Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph, Corporal José Cipriano Rodríguez holds a crucifix as he kneels before Father Domingo Lorenzo here on January 17, shortly before Rodríguez was executed. He was found guilty of the death of two brothers in a trial before a military court.”
The Spanish fact-checking site Maldita tells this story after the publication of a column published in the ABC newspaper on November 22, 1962. There, Domingo Lorenzo explains that the kneeling man was called José Rodríguez (although he also names him “Pepe Caliente”) and that he had been “a corporal in the Army of General F. Batista Zaldivar”.
The priest admits that he never knew what they were accusing him of because “between that shouting you couldn't hear the charges being made against him”. He adds that he was sentenced to “death penalty by shooting” by Castro commander William Gálvez, who ordered that the execution be carried out at that very moment, although he ended up delaying it the next day since there were “many women” present.
In addition, according to Domingo Lorenzo, the commander demanded that the photographers hand over all the rolls of their cameras with the negatives and that “all but one American delivered them”, referring to Andrew López.
In an excerpt from the book “Picture This! The Inside Story and Classic Photos of UPI [United Press International] Newspictures”, López clarifies that he did deliver a roll but that he kept the one containing the photos of Pepe (referring to 'Pepe Caliente'). There, the photographer assures that, although the trial itself lasted two hours, the three judges of the court took only a minute to sentence him to death.
This check is part of Facebook's Third Party Fact-checking initiative in Argentina. In the case of photos and videos, we work with images that are rigged or taken out of context and we always analyze the images together with the text with which they were presented.
image_caption: phony;phony

title: Photo does not show a peasant receiving extreme unction in Cuba, but a soldier
description: It is false that a 1959 photo that circulates on social networks shows “a priest giving the last blessing to a Cuban peasant” sentenced to death for refusing to “work for the Fidel Castro regime”. The man receiving the extreme anointing was a military man. Information about the image is available on the Pulitzer website, the world's leading journalism prize.
text:
It is false that a 1959 photo that circulates on social networks shows “a priest giving the last blessing to a Cuban peasant” sentenced to death for refusing to “work for the Fidel Castro regime” (see here). The man receiving the extreme anointing was a military man. Information about the image is available on the Pulitzer website, the world's leading journalism prize.
On Facebook, posts with the false claim totaled just over 3,000 shares as of late Wednesday afternoon (9) and were marked with the FALSE seal on the social network's verification tool (see how it works).
FALSE
This photo won the Pulitzer Prize. A priest giving the last blessing to a Cuban peasant, landowner, who refused to work for the Fidel Castro regime, and who was convicted by “Che”, without the right to defense, to die by shooting. You'll never see that picture on a communist's t-shirt.
It is not true that a photo that circulates on social networks shows “a Cuban peasant, landowner, who refused to work for the Fidel Castro regime”, receiving extreme anointing from a priest after being convicted by Che Guevara, as Facebook posts say. The person who appears kneeling in the image, which dates back to 1959, is a soldier, according to the Pulitzer Prize website.
The award is mentioned in the post with the false claim. In fact, the image earned the photographer Andrew Lopez of the UPI news agency a Pulitzer in 1960. However, the caption of the photo on the award website clarifies that the man blessed by the priest was a member of the troops of Fulgencio Batista, the ruler deposed by the Cuban Revolution of 1959.
The soldier was executed by revolutionaries led by Fidel Castro. But in the information available on the Pulitzer website, there is no mention of Ernesto “Che” Guevara.
The same photo of Lopez can also be found in the archives of the Getty Images image agency, containing some additional information: the man on his knees was Corporal José Cipriano Rodríguez, who allegedly killed two people. The priest was called Domingo Lorenzo. Nor is there, however, any mention of Che Guevara.
A check of the same image carried out by the Spanish site Maldita in early September also cites an article published in November 1962 by the ABC newspaper, also from Spain, which includes an interview with Father Domingo Lorenzo. The priest told the newspaper that the victim of the execution was a corporal named José Rodríguez, a member of the Baptist Army.
The circulation of this piece of disinformation is not new. Almost a year ago, Agência Lupa checked it out. Versions of the false allegation also circulated in April in Portugal and in May in Bolivia. In Brazil, Estadão Verifica also checked this content.

title: Che Guevara | ColombiaCheck
text:

Questionable
In reality, he is a former soldier in Batista's army and he was convicted of murder. It falsely circulates on networks that he had a four-minute trial for refusing to work for Fidel Castro...

title: The man who appears in these photos is not a 'peasant' before he was shot by order of Che Guevara
description: In reality, he is a former soldier in Batista's army and he was convicted of murder. It falsely circulates on networks that he had a four-minute trial for refusing to work for Fidel Castro.
text:
Questionable Questionable Questionable Questionable Questionable Questionable Questionable
Questionable
For at least a year, a couple of photographs (1 and 2) have been circulating on social networks showing a Catholic priest giving him the blessing and talking to a man who is in the middle of a group of soldiers. The images are described by many users as the moment before the shooting of a “Cuban peasant by order of Che Guevara” for refusing to work for the Castro regime.
The scenes circulate separately, but in almost all versions the explanation added by the users matches:
“This photo won the Pulitzer Prize in 1960. A priest giving the last blessing to a Cuban peasant, owner of his land, who refused to work for Fidel Castro. He was shot without the right to defense, by order of Che Guevara, in a 'trial' that only lasted 4 minutes. Of course, you'll never see this photo on a t-shirt.”
The last sentence refers to the iconic photograph taken in 1960 by the Cuban Alberto Korda and which today is part of popular culture.
However, at Colombiacheck, we describe these types of publications as misleading, since the man who appears in the images was not a peasant, but José Rodríguez, a former soldier in the army of the dictator Fulgencio Batista, who was overthrown on January 1, 1959. In addition, he was not convicted for not wanting to work for Castro, but, allegedly, for murder.
Publications that link the images to the shooting of a peasant have circulated especially in Latin America and Spain. And according to CrowdTangle, a social media monitoring tool, these types of posts have had more than 39,000 interactions in the last year.
In Colombia, they have been disseminated by Facebook pages and groups such as Gustavo Petro: Communist Enemy of Democracy and the Constitution, Realidad Colombia Libre and Herbin Hoyos-Oficial. Some have been shared more than 1,000 times.
The images out of context were also published by Andrés Felipe Arcos, a Uribista Twitter user with more than 22,900 followers who was a contractor for the Ministry of the Interior.
We did a reverse search of the images with the Google tool and found that they are indeed part of a series of photos awarded the Pulitzer Prize in photography in 1960. The author is Andrew López, a Spaniard who at the time was part of the team of the news agency United Press International. In fact, the two photos that went viral are the only ones available on the Pulitzer Prizes page.
But in the description of the award-winning images, there is no reference to the shooting of a peasant. Instead, it is written that López was awarded “for his series of four photographs of a corporal, a former member of the army of the dictator Batista, who was executed by a Castro firing squad, the main image showing the convict receiving the last rites”.
In 2016, United Press International published an article about the stories behind the photos with which its reporters had so far won the Pulitzer Prize. In the description of López's, it was specified that it portrays the moment when priest Domingo Lorenzo performed a rite before the shooting of José Cipriano Rodríguez, on January 17, 1959 (a few days after the triumph of the Cuban Revolution).
According to the article, Rodríguez “had served in Fulgencio Batista's army [and] was executed by firing squad after being convicted of the death of two brothers.”
United Press noted that the former military trial lasted “only a minute.” But our colleagues at Check Your Fact, in the United States, found that López explained in an interview published in May 1960 by the American newspaper St. Louis Post-Dispatch that: “Rodríguez was sentenced after two hours of trial in the San Severino fortress near Matanzas, Cuba. The court met for one minute before finding him guilty.”
Colombiacheck also found a record of the shooting of Rodríguez in Archivo Cuba, a project dedicated to collecting information on deaths and disappearances attributed to the Cuban Revolution, in which more than 11,000 documented cases appear.
In the case, one of the photos of Andrew López appears and explains that he was a member of the Armed Forces during the Batista regime and was “executed for allegedly having committed acts of torture and murder.”
With this information, we describe as questionable the publications that relate two photos taken by the Spaniard Andrew López to the shooting of a Cuban peasant for refusing to work for the Castro regime.
It is true that she was awarded the Pulitzer Prize and corresponds to a religious ritual before a shooting, as explained in the publications, but the person was allegedly convicted of  assassinated and was a former soldier in Batista's army.

title: Does This Photograph Show a Polar Bear Taking Public Transit in Russia?
author: Dan Evon
description: Is this "a normal day in Russia," or a bizarre circumstance anywhere in the world?
text:
A photograph purportedly showing a polar bear taking public transportation in Russia is frequently shared online with humorous captions such as "just a normal day in Russia":
This image has also been shared with punny captions such as "The Polar Express," "The bus was unBEARable," "Auditioning for the new Coca-Cola bear," and "Kindly bear with us as we get this aggressive passenger of the bus."
This picture is a genuine photograph in the sense that it was not digitally manipulated, but it does not, as often claimed, capture a real polar bear exiting a bus in Russia.
What this picture actually shows is a puppet known as "Paula the Polar Bear" exiting a tram in the Czech Republic city of Brno during a "Save the Arctic" campaign by Greenpeace. (The name of Rakovecká, a street in Brno, can be seen on the bus sign.) Two activists are actually operating this puppet from the inside as other Greenpeace members inform the public about matters such as climate change and arctic drilling.
The Greenpeace Czech Republic Facebook page shared an image of Paula the Polar Bear in Liberec in October 2014:
The Brno news outlet Centrum News reported in 2015 that this realistic polar bear puppet had frightened a few passers-by as it walked through the supermarket in Židenice (translated via Google):
On Friday afternoon a city police patrol quickly responded to a supermarket in Židenice, where a polar bear, according to a caller, was walking around.
The policemen in Bubeníčkova Street actually saw a furry white animal, but it was only a costume used by ecological activists.
The bear costume was very realistic, so some of the passers-by were fooled. Two people were hidden inside the life-sized costume.
Paula the Polar Bear has made appearances in cities all over the world. Here, for example, is a video of Paula the Polar Bear visiting the Canterbury Cathedral in England:
The Paula the Polar Bear puppet was also used in a short film starring Jude Law to promote Greenpeace's "Save the Arctic" campaign:
“I came up with the concept after having been asked by Greenpeace to judge a short VW film competition they were running and being taken on a guided tour of the building, when I was duly shown around their warehouse and spotted a life-sized suit of a polar bear called Paula hanging from a pole -- a relic from a play called ‘Greenland’ at the National Theatre in London,” says Michael.
“After a brief conversation with Head of Greenpeace UK, John Sauven, about their up-and-coming Save the Arctic campaign, I took some pictures of the bear and started thinking about how I could tell her story, and a simple idea came to me: what if, because we had made her homeless, this polar bear had traveled so far in search of food that she would be living on the streets of London.
“I thought that the obvious parallels with the homeless in any major city might make her issues more obvious to us city dwellers, especially as we live thousands of miles away.”
The stunning polar bear costume was operated by puppeteers from London’s Broadway and West End production ‘War Horse’ who rehearsed the bear’s articulations. A team of post-effects artists from London’s Moving Picture Company worked on face manipulation.
A short film documenting the making of "The Homeless Polar Bear" provides a better look at how Paula the Polar Bear is operated:

title: poem about greenpeace mascot paula the polar bear – these days of mine
description: Posts about poem about greenpeace mascot paula the polar bear written by Dianna
text:
It’s time for poetry again with Pam and her kitties, Teddy and Angel Sammy, at Two Spoiled Cats.
This is the photo they gave us for our inspiration today:
Here’s my poem:
Paula, The Polar Bear
This is Paula, the polar bear,
she’s a celebrity and been everywhere.
She rides the tram and goes to the mall,
but she’s not what you think, after all.
She’s just a puppet with two folks inside;
soft and cuddly, with a serious side.
Her cause really isn’t all that strange:
it’s all about drilling and climate change.*
She’s been known to give folks quite a scare,
until they meet Paula, the polar bear.
~These Days Of Mine~
* Paula was created by the group Greenpeace. For more info on this picture, click here.

title: Brad Pitt Interview Magazine
author: Dontaira Terrell
description: Brad Pitt tries on many different hats, plus gets personal in the latest Interview Magazine.
text:
Brad Pitt is having a serious moment right now — oh wait, it's called his entire life. No, but seriously, after years out of the spotlight, the megastar is making some kind of comeback. First, he books a mysterious and sexy Chanel ad. And, now, he's Interview magazine's main man.
Well, we have no complaints. But we do have one question: Is this the same Brad we know and love in these five crazy photos? A dreadlocked, bleached-beard, ripped-sweater-wearing Rasta type wasn't the only character Pitt donned for the shoot; in fact, he posted in a variety of completely different outfits, from a casual pirate to a Scarface-style gangster complete with gold chain and pistol. He's nothing if not versatile. Oh, and by the way, the interview is pretty interesting, too. (Interview via Styleite)
Hit the slideshow and tell us: Are you ready for Brad's comeback? Or, in your book, has he never left?

title: Want to see Brad Pitt with dreadlocks and a pencil moustache? Of course you do
author: James Cartwright
text:
Want to see Brad Pitt with dreadlocks and a pencil moustache? Of course you do
- Words
- James Cartwright
- —
- Date
- 15 October 2012
If you’re female, male, old, young, or anything else in between you’ll undoubtedly be acquainted with Brad Pitt and his perfectly chiseled features. Without wishing to go all Brian Sewell on you, he’s a handsome devil. To prove this long-accepted fact he’s been photographed in a most striking and unusual fashion for the latest Interview magazine to accompany his feature by Guy Ritchie. Shot by the notorious Steven Klein in a number of extraordinary guises (bizarrely including a dreadlocked hippie) these are the most striking photos of Pitt that we’ve ever laid eyes on, and prove beyond doubt that however you dress him up, he’s a damn fine specimen of a man.

title: 'The family is first': Brad Pitt opens up about his children as he transforms into dreadlocked Rasta man for Interview magazine
author: Daily
description: Sat down with Snatch director Guy Ritchie
text:
'The family is first': Brad Pitt opens up about his children as he transforms into dreadlocked Rasta man for Interview magazine
He earned his stripes in Hollywood as a cowboy hitchhiker and has been nominated for an Oscar as a man who ages in reverse.
Now, Brad Pitt has transformed into a dreaded Rasta man for Interview magazine.
The 48-year-old star, photographed by Steven Klein, whips his head back in one image, accompanying his interview with Snatch director Guy Ritchie.
![Dreaded: Brad Pitt sports the new look in a photograph shot by Steven Klein](https://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2012/10/09/article-2215227-156D72F0000005DC-388_634x733.jpg)
Dreaded: Brad Pitt sports the new look in a photograph shot by Steven Klein
Wearing a ripped sweater, and with a full goate, the actor shuts his eyes and appears to be adrift in his own world.
Other photographs shot by Klein show Hollywood's golden boy as a rake, a drifter and a hitman.
Speaking to Ritchie, the Fight Club star reveals he's becoming more selective with his film roles to focus fatherhood.
'I want it to be worthy enough of a story to leave the family, you know? They’re everything,' he says of his six children with Angelina Jolie. 'The family is first.'
![Chameleon: The 48-year-old actor slipped into several different characters for the shootine](https://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2012/10/09/article-2215227-156D72EC000005DC-881_634x815.jpg)
Chameleon: The 48-year-old actor slipped into several different characters for the shoot
The actor said he feels accomplished enough in his career to be more discerning, admitting he feels now he can 'jump into anything and lay something down that's quality.'
![Covered: The star features in Interview magazine's October/November 2012 issue](https://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2012/10/09/article-2215227-156D72E8000005DC-948_306x397.jpg)
Covered: The star features in Interview magazine's October/November 2012 issue
The actor shares Maddox, 11, Pax, eight, Zahara, seven, Shiloh, six, and four-year-old twins Knox and Vivienne with Jolie, says it's also important he doesn't 'embarrass' his brood.
But he's worked long enough to know exactly the type of person he might allow to pull him away from his role as a dad and future husband.
'...As I get older, it's about the company that I keep,' Pitt says.
'That's the most important thing to me - that if I'm gonna spend however long it takes to make a movie, give up 14 hours a day for however many weeks or months, then it's very important for me to know that I'm working with people who I respect and enjoy and that we're going for something together.
'That's it, really.'
Brad is next set to star Andrew Dominik film Killing Them Softly.
But the crime thriller, he says, is really meant to take a more serious look at American politics.
'We're at a particularly ugly time when we're at such a divide in America, but that divide is not there because everyone is trying to figure out what’s best for the people,' he explains.
'It’s there because one side is trying to win out over the other side.'
Killing Them Softly is set for a crime thriller is set for a November 30 release.

title: Huge protests in Brazil as far-right presidential hopeful returns home
author: Dom Phillips
description: Demonstrations held against Jair Bolsonaro’s extremist stance ahead of election
text:
The homecoming of Brazil’s far-right presidential frontrunner Jair Bolsonaro from hospital was upstaged this weekend by huge demonstrations as concerns over his authoritarian tendencies grew.
Bolsonaro flew from São Paulo to his home in Rio de Janeiro on Saturday, three weeks after being stabbed during campaigning, while tens of thousands of women filled the streets in cities across Brazil to protest against his extremist positions ahead of the 7 October election.
The G1 news site reported anti-Bolsonaro protests in all Brazil’s 27 states grew out of a Facebook group called Women United Against Bolsonaro which nearly 4 million people have joined. Pro-Bolsonaro demonstrations took place in 16 states, the site said. The piauí magazine website called the demonstrations “historic” and printed a photo of an enormous crowd in São Paulo which organisers claimed half a million attended, though police did not provide an estimate.
Profile
Who is Jair Bolsonaro?Show
![](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/8cb6040e8830a6aa1aa29474c00ab5d64bf44d29/0_0_3406_3406/3406.jpg?width=620&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=47f05c9474dd1169d78464d3d73e370c)
Biography
Born in Glicério in São Paulo in 1955 to parents of Italian descent, he served in the army from 1971 until 1988, when he was elected as a city councillor in Rio de Janeiro for the Christian Democratic party. In 1990, he became a federal congressman for the same party. He has since been affiliated with a number of political parties. On 22 July, he was officially nominated as the presidential candidate of the Social Liberal party.
Policies
Bolsonaro espouses populist and nationalist views that often stray into far-right territory. A vocal opponent of same-sex marriage, abortion, immigration and other progressive causes, he has defended the death penalty and the 1964-85 military dictatorship. On foreign policy, he has said he wants to improve relations with the US. Economically he says he is pro free market and privatisation.
Political style
Deliberately provocative and polarising. He has praised Gen Pinochet, expressed support for torturers and called for political opponents to be shot, earning him the label of "the most misogynistic, hateful elected official in the democratic world”. In his bid to capitalise on Latin America’s lurch to the right, he paints himself as a tropical Donald Trump: a pro-gun, anti-establishment crusader set on "draining the swamp" and cracking down on violent crime.
Controversies
On top of repeated calls for a return to dictatorship, he has made equally inflammatory attacks on women, black people, gay people, foreigners and indigenous communities. Earlier this year, he was charged by the attorney general with inciting hate speech.
Support and first round victory
Bolsonaro has a devout following among some conservative voters, who admire his promises to get tough on rampant violent crime, and won 46% of the vote in the election's first round.
In Rio the huge crowds that filled the city centre were notable for their diversity – with women of all ages, many of whom had brought children, male and LGBT demonstrators, chanting “not him”, an anti-Bolsonaro hashtag that has become a campaign slogan shared by celebrities like Madonna.
Many demonstrators expressed concerns over Bolsonaro’s declaration in a television interview on Friday that he would not accept any election result he did not win because of his endorsement of the military dictatorship which ran Brazil for two decades.
![Jair Bolsonaro sits on a plane at the airport in São Paulo.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/3f24e0b2b2464f2e099afd8391685ea73e220721/0_336_2942_1765/master/2942.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)
Flavia Carvalho, 40, a civil servant, carried a “not him” banner designed around an Adolf Hitler cartoon. “He is preaching fascism,” she said. Others said they were protesting against the sexist, racist and homophobic views Bolsonaro has expressed.
“He is sexist. He is misogynist. He is racist,” said Ana Paulo Gonçalves, 24, a teacher. “He wants to go back to the military dictatorship,” said her sister Christine, 29, a designer.
Bolsonaro, a former army captain and veteran lawmaker, currently leads polling for a first-round vote on 7 October. Running second is Fernando Haddad, a former mayor of São Paulo who took the place of formidably popular former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva after Lula’s candidacy was barred because he is serving a prison sentence for graft. Bolsonaro and Haddad are expected to face off in a run-off vote on 28 October.
Making adept use of WhatsApp and social media, Bolsonaro has built support across Brazil, attacking Lula’s Workers’ party for its involvement in a huge graft scheme and espousing a hardline approach to law and order. His views have resonated with Brazilians angry and fearful over endemic corruption and rising violent crime. Supporters stage drive-by demonstrations, racing through towns across Brazil in convoys of cars and motorbikes, wavi ng flags and blasting horns.
![People gather during a demonstration against Brazil’s presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/19132783a75d5487023dbc96b5677cb33300fa3f/0_264_3500_2100/master/3500.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)
The divisions Bolsonaro provokes in Brazil were evident in a video of him boarding Saturday’s flight from São Paulo. While some passengers regaled him with chants of “legend”, others yelled “fascist” and “not him”.
In a television interview broadcast on Friday, Bolsonaro suggested Brazil’s armed forces could intervene if his main rivals, the leftist Workers’ party, “committed a foul” in the election.
“I don’t accept an election that is not me being elected,” Bolsonaro told reporter José Datena, adding that Brazil’s electronic voting system could be defrauded by the Workers’ party, but providing no evidence.
Bolsonaro enjoys widespread support among police and the military. His vice-presidential candidate, Gen Hamilton Mourão, unnerved Brazilians recently when he said in a situation of “anarchy”, a president could declare an “auto-coup”. Both men praise the military dictatorship that ran Brazil from 1964-1985, torturing and executing opponents.
“I lived [during] this phase,” said Maria do Carmo, 84, who was protesting in Rio and saw relatives imprisoned by the military regime. “It was terrible.”
On Sunday, the Folha de S.Paulo newspaper called on both leading candidates to make a commitment to democracy, accusing Bolsonaro of “stimulating paranoias of manipulation” and criticising the Workers’ party for its attacks on the justice system for Lula’s imprisonment it calls politically motivated.
image_caption: Aerial view of a demonstration against presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro. Photograph: Miguel Schincariol/AFP/Getty Images;  ;

title: Protests against Bolsonaro gather thousands in Brazil and abroad
author: Jair Messias Bolsonaro
description: Acts against the candidate were led by women under the slogan #Elenão, created by a Facebook group. There were demonstrations in several cities in Europe
text:
Protests against Bolsonaro gather thousands in Brazil and abroad
Acts against the candidate were led by women under the slogan #Elenão, created by a Facebook group. There were demonstrations in several cities in Europe
By Writing
Updated on Sep 29, 2018 at 11:12pm - Published on Sep 29, 2018 at 5:23pm
Act against Bolsonaro in Largo da Batata, in São Paulo (Alice Vergueiro/Folhapress)
Continue after advertising
On the same day that he was discharged from the hospital, Jair Bolsonaro (PSL) was the target of demonstrations against his campaign for the Presidency of the Republic that brought together thousands of people in dozens of Brazilian cities and abroad. The two biggest protests against the candidate brought a crowd to Cinelândia, in the center of Rio de Janeiro, and to Largo da Batata, in Pinheiros, in the western part of São Paulo.
The event in the capital of São Paulo brought together demonstrators from various parties, from the PSDB to the PSTU, and three vice-presidential candidates - Manuela D'Ávila (PCdoB), Kátia Abreu (PDT) and Sônia Guajajara (PSOL) -, in addition to the presidential candidate Marina Silva (Network). None of them got into the sound car, which was occupied only by women.
“There's the PT, there's the Network, the people of Ciro (Gomes), of (Guilherme) Boulos, it's important that they're all here. The guy brought us together. Thank you, Bolsonaro!” , joked Angela Martins, a 65-year-old university professor who was there.
Aerial view of the demonstration against presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro in Largo da Batata in São Paulo — 29/09/2018 (Miguel Schincariol/AFP)
The demonstration brought together 150,000 people, according to the organizers - the Military Police did not estimate. There were no serious incidents, but the protest completely or partially paralyzed traffic on important roads such as Rebouças and Paulista avenues.
Demonstrations were also held in at least 15 cities in the interior of São Paulo. The largest concentrations were in Campinas — about 2,000 people, according to the PM — and São José dos Campos — also 2,000 people, but according to the organizers. There were also protests in other important municipalities such as Ribeirão Preto, São José do Rio Preto, Piracicaba, Bauru, São Carlos, and Marília.
Demonstrators take part in an act against Bolsonaro in Cinelândia Square, Rio de Janeiro — 29/09/2018 (Mauro Pimentel/AFP)
It continues after the advertisement
In Cinelândia, there was no estimated audience, but the crowd occupied the entire square and surrounding streets. “Here there are white, black, homosexual people, people who are fathers and mothers of families and who are very diverse. And that type of candidate (Bolsonaro), that type of politics, doesn't represent this Brazilian culture that has all this diversity,” said Beatriz Lorena, a 33-year-old teacher.
In Brasilia, the event brought together about 5 thousand people, according to the Military Police. The demonstrators occupied three of the five lanes of the northern runway of the Monumental Axis.
In Salvador, singer Daniela Mercury protested singing in an electric trio that circulated around the city with a track that read “Women against Bolsonaro”. In Juiz de Fora (Minas Gerais), where Bolsonaro was stabbed to death on September 6, anti-Bolsonaro demonstrators marched through the downtown streets.
Demonstration at Boca Maldita, in Curitiba — 29/09/2018 (Cassiano Rosário/Futura Press/Folhapress)
Across the country, there were also events in Curitiba, Goiânia, Porto Alegre, Vitória, Florianópolis, Belo Horizonte, Natal, João Pessoa, Recife, Fortaleza, Aracaju, Palmas, Campo Grande, Manaus, Belém, and Cuiabá.
It continues after the advertisement
Demonstrators protest against Bolsonaro in Santiago, Chile — 29/09/2018 (Martin Bernetti/AFP)
Exterior
Around the world, demonstrations against Bolsonaro took place in cities in the United States, Canada, Argentina, Chile, Spain, France, Portugal, Germany, Italy, France, and Switzerland.
Demonstrators protest against Jair Bolsonaro in Union Square in New York (Miguel Barbieri/VEJASP)
In New York, there was samba on the street, with posters in Portuguese and English. The protest brought together men, women, and children of all ages. See video below:
It continues after the advertisement
In London, the demonstration commemorated the assassination of city councilwoman Marielle Franco (PSOL-RJ) in March in Rio de Janeiro.
In Paris, around 250 people protested in the Republic Square in the center. The demonstrators, mostly Brazilian women between the ages of 20 and 40, carried signs in Portuguese, French and English with messages such as “Never Bolsonaro” and “Not him”. In Lyon, there was also a protest (see video below).
In Germany, the main concentration was in Berlin, where posters in Portuguese, English and German predominated, criticizing the candidate.
It continues after the advertisement
In Portugal, there were events in Lisbon, Coimbra and Porto. Many women alluded to their disenchantment with the future and the perspectives surrounding gender politics. Similar demonstrations took place in Vienna, Milan, and Barcelona.
Women's protest against Bolsonaro in downtown Recife, Pernambuco — 29/09/2018 (Veetmano Prem/Fotoarena/Folhapress)
'Powder barrel Powder'
The women's offensive was launched in early September by the Facebook group “Women United Against Bolsonaro”, a call “against the advancement and strengthening of sexism, misogyny, racism, homophobia, and other types of prejudice”. The group brings together more than 3.8 million people.
In an interview with the newspaper O Estado de S. Paulo published this Saturday, the group's creator, civil servant Ludimilla Teixeira, from Salvador, stated that she “only lit a match in the powder keg” with the creation of the group. She says she was thrilled to see singer Madonna pose on social media with the group's message. “I cried when I saw it.”

Women represent 52% of the electorate and can define the election. That is the hope of 20-year-old student Jessica Zaine, who marched through São Paulo with a sign that read: “Who could imagine that a woman's right to vote won in 1932 would save Brazil in 2018?”
(With Estadão Content, Agência Brasil, France Presse and Reuters)
