(photo: AFP);

title: Protests against Bolsonaro take place in at least 62 cities; acts in favor, in 27
author: Evolution Journal
description: Protests against Bolsonaro take place in at least 62 cities; acts in favor, in 27 -
text:
Demonstrators take to the streets in 26 states and the Federal District against candidate Jair BolsonaroJornal Nacional--: --/--: --
Demonstrators take to the streets in 26 states and the Federal District against candidate Jair Bolsonaro
Demonstrators in at least 62 cities took to the streets during acts against presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro (PSL) this Saturday (29). The movement, called #EleNão, was launched on social media, with the support of artists, during the month of September.
In response to the movement, Bolsonaro supporters also gathered at events across Brazil to demonstrate support for the presidential candidate. 27 cities held acts in favor of Bolsonaro.
In Rio de Janeiro, demonstrators against the candidate gathered in Cinelândia, in the center, in the early afternoon. Initially, the rally was in front of the Cine Odeon.
At 17:00, some of the demonstrators left Cinelândia and marched through the streets of downtown Rio. The event closed around 21:00 p.m. There is still no audience estimate.
Anti-Bolsonaro demonstrators gather in downtown Rio — Photo: Reproduction/GloboNews
Protest against Bolsonaro occupies Cinelândia, in the center of Rio — Photo: TV Globo
Bolsonaro's supporters were concentrated on Avenida Atlântica, in Copacabana, South Zone of Rio, at the height of Post 5. The Military Police followed the demonstration.
At 18:50, the Rio Operations Center reported that the runways, which had been occupied since 14:00 by the demonstrators, were released.
In Rio, supporters of Jair Bolsonaro gathered at Copacabana Beach, in the South Zone — Photo: G1
Demonstrations in favor of Bolsonaro take place in 16 states Jornal Nacional--: --/--: --
Demonstrations in favor of Bolsonaro take place in 16 states
The demonstrators began to gather in Largo da Batata, West Zone of São Paulo, around 14:30 for the “Women against Bolsonaro” event.
The event organized by social networks was also supported by left-wing parties and movements. Artists performed in a sound truck and stalls sold t-shirts with the hashtag #EleNão.
Anti-Bolsonaro demonstrators walk along Avenida Rebouças in São Paulo — Photo: Nacho Doce/Reuters
The expression was also on flags accompanied by slogans such as “dictatorship never again”, against sexism, racism, and exploitation.
Around 6:00 p.m., the group started hiking. The runway on Avenida Rebouças, in the direction of Paulista, was even completely closed.
The demonstrators arrived at Avenida Paulista shortly before 8 pm and around 20:40 the organizers declared the end of the event and called for the public to disperse peacefully.
The organizers estimate that the event brought together 500 thousand people. The Military Police says it will not estimate the number of people participating.
Aerial photo shows demonstration against candidate Jair Bolsonaro in Largo da Batata, in the West Zone of São Paulo — Photo: Miguel Schincariol/AFP
Anti-Jair Bolsonaro demonstrators gathered in Largo da Batata, in São Paulo — Photo: Roney Domingos/ G1
The São Paulo demonstrators in favor of the PSL candidate began to gather around 10 am in front of the Pacaembu Stadium, in the West Zone of São Paulo. They planned to take a motorcade through the North Zone and reach Ibirapuera Park, in the South Zone. There was no estimated number of participants until 1 p.m.
During the morning, demonstrations against and in favor of the candidate took place in 40 cities in 12 Brazilian states.
Cities in different countries around the world, such as New York, London, Lisbon, Barcelona and Mexico City also had demonstrations against Jair Bolsonaro, in greater or lesser proportion, this Saturday.
See below how the acts were carried out by the Brazilian states this afternoon:
In favor of Bolsonaro: The event began at 16:17 local time (19:17 Brasília time) at the entrance to the University neighborhood and continued through the streets of the capital to the Arena da Floresta. There is no estimate of the number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The act took place during the afternoon on the Maternity Channel, in front of the Rio Branco Urban Terminal. The event began at 16:20 local time (18:20 Brasília time). The organization estimated an audience of one thousand people, and the Military Police says that there are 500 to 800 people present at the event. The demonstration must last until 19:00 Acre time (21:00 Brasília time).
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration brought together thousands of people on the Ponta Verde waterfront, in Maceió. Independent people and members of social, trade union and political movements with banners and posters began a walk at 16:00 from Praça Gogó da Ema, in front of the old Alagoinha, to Post 7, in Jatiúca. The organization of the movement says that 3 thousand people participate in the event. The Military Police did not provide an estimate of participants.
Anti-Jair Bolsonaro demonstrators gather on the Ponta Verde waterfront, in Maceió (AL). — Photo: Derek Gustavo/G1
In favor of Bolsonaro: The event began at 16:00 at Praça Parque do Forte, in the central region. The organization did not estimate the number of parties occupants. The Military Police, on the other hand, estimated that a thousand people attended the event.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally took place at 16:00 in Floriano Peixoto Square, in the city center. The organization says that 2,000 people attended the event. According to the Military Police, there were 1,500 demonstrators.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 16:00 in Largo São Sebastião, in downtown Manaus. According to the organization, 3,000 people attended the demonstration. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The act of the “Women United against Bolsonaro” movement began at 14:30 and began to disperse at 18:30. The group focused on Campo Grande Square, in the center of the city, and took a walk along the Victory Corridor, bound for the Barra Lighthouse. Organizers said that 10,000 people attended the event. According to the Military Police, the demonstration has about 5 thousand people.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration began at 17:00 at Praça do Coreto, in the Historic Center. The “All Against Hate” event was organized by university students and the city's population. The Military Police and the organizers did not disclose the number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: People started to concentrate around 15:00 and went hiking at 16:30. The organization estimates that more than 5 thousand people are at the event. The Military Police did not disclose the number of participants.
Demonstrators against candidate Jair Bolsonaro in Fortaleza (CE) — Photo: Kilvia Muniz/Sistema Verdes Mares
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators held an act until the beginning of the afternoon. The group toured the main streets of the Center, from the Plaza de la Coluna da Hora to the Plaza de Cuba.
Against Bolsonaro: The act took place during the afternoon at Praça do Giradouro, which provides access to two other important cities in the south of Ceará, Crato and Barbalha. The organizers estimated the presence of 3,000 people. The Military Police did not release an audience survey.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally on the lawn of the Esplanada dos Ministério, in front of the Plano Piloto bus station, began around 14:30pm. Women spoke in an electric trio and set out on a hike at 15:30 to Funarte, passing through the TV Tower. The Military Police reports that there are 7,000 demonstrators. The organization has yet to release an estimate.
Demonstrators protest against candidate Jair Bolsonaro during an event at the Monumental Axis in Brasilia — Photo: Sérgio Lima/AFP
Against Bolsonaro: The concentration of the demonstrators began at 14:00 in the Pope's Square in Vitória. The participants are expected to go out on a march towards the Plaza of Wishes. The organization has not yet announced the number of demonstrators. The Military Police reported, at 16:20pm, that there are 2,000 people at the scene.
Anti-Jair Bolsonaro demonstrators gather at Pope's Square in Vitória (ES) — Photo: Leandro Tedesco/ TV Gazeta
In favor of Bolsonaro: A march left the Kléber Andrade stadium, in Cariacica, Grande Vitória, at 14:45 this Saturday. The group went on to Campo Grande, where it arrived around 15:40 p.m. The organization did not say the number of participants. The PM also failed to send an estimate.
Motorcade of Jair Bolsonaro supporters in Cariacica, Grande Vitória (ES). — Photo: Leandro Tedesco/TV Gazeta
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered at Marca Tempo Square, in the city center, at 15:00. The event was expected to end at 16:30 in Getúlio Vargas Square, also in the central region. The organization estimates that a thousand people attended the event.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 12:30 in Praça Tenente Diomar Menezes, in the city center. According to the organization, 300 people attended the demonstration.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration began at 16:00 in the Praça do Ancião, in the center of the city. The protest was expected to take place until 19:00 and end in Ipiranga Park. There is no estimate of the number of demonstrators.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered in downtown São Luís, on Avenida Beira-Mar. The organization says 15,000 people attended the event. The Military Police announced that there were 4,000 demonstrators.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration was concentrated at Praça Ulisses Guimarães, on Avenida Historiador Rubens de Mendonça (CPA), in Cuiabá. Independent people and members of social, trade union, and political movements with banners and posters gathered at 16:00 p.m. Even with heavy rain, the group remained on site. The Military Police followed the protest from afar but did not send an estimate of the number of participants. The organization of the movement counted more than a thousand people at the demonstration.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 15:00 at Praça Cuiabá, in the city center. The organization estimates that 4,000 people participated in the event. The Military Police did not release an estimate. The demonstration ended around 8 p.m.
In favor of Bolsonaro: A motorcade took place around 17:00 on Rua Porto Carreiro, in the central region of the city. The Military Police estimates that 15,000 people participated in the motorcade. The organization He didn't release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered at the Antonio João Square, in the city center, from 15:30 to 16:00. According to the organization, there were 1,500 participants. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began around 14:00 at Praça Sete, in downtown Belo Horizonte. Demonstrators gathered at the monument called Pirulito, closing the intersection of Afonso Pena and Amazonas Avenues. Then they went to Praça da Estação, accompanied by an electric trio. The event continued on site until 6:30 p.m. The Military Police did not release an estimate of participants. The Frente Brasil Popular Minas reported that it was leading the organization of the event with another 25 carnival blocks and 40 organizations, such as collectives, unions, and parties. According to the Frente Brasil Popular Minas, the protest brought together more than 100,000 people.
Protesters against candidate Jair Bolsonaro gather at Praça Sete, downtown Belo Horizonte (MG) — Photo: Playback/TV Globo
Against Bolsonaro: Demonstrators have been gathering at Halfeld Park, in the center, since 11 a.m. Then, they followed several streets in the city center and went to Praça Antônio Carlos. The organization estimates that 30,000 people are participating in the event. The Military Police did not provide numbers.
Anti-Bolsonaro demonstrators gather in downtown Juiz de Fora (MG) — Photo: Mônica Cury
In favor of Bolsonaro: There was a motorcade leaving Cônego Vitor Square around noon. The cars drove through central streets. The motorcade ended around 2 p.m. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 14:00 at Tubal Vilela Square, in the center. The demonstration was expected to end around 16:00 after a march. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally took place at 16:30 in Praça do Barco. The organization says 700 people attended the event. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The 'honking' through the city center took place around 16:00 and ended at 18:00. The organization says that 300 people attended the event. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered in front of the UFPA campus from 16:30 to 19:00. The organization states that 500 people attended the event. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
In favor of Bolsonaro: There was a motorcade leaving Icoaraci, but the organization did not indicate the route. The event began at 17:00. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally took place at 16:00 at the São Brás Market. People took a hike to the Davi Miguel Amazon Culture Village, in the Pedreira neighborhood. The organization reported that 15,000 people are participating in the demonstration. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered at 17:00 at the Orla de Itaituba. The event was expected to end at 21:30pm. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 17:00 in the City Hall Square with a walk scheduled to the Pátio Marabá Shopping Center. A thousand people attend the demonstration, according to the organization. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
In favor of Bolsonaro: Supporters of the presidential candidate gathered at 17:00 at the Silas Brum Cultural Biblical Events Square. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration began at 17:00 at Praça Monsignor José Gregário (Praça da Matriz). People must still walk along the city's waterfront during the protest. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 17:30 in the Rotary Square. The demonstration was expected to end at 21:30pm. The organization says 300 people attended the event. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally took place around 16:00 in the central region, near the Boca Maldita Confectionery. The event ended at Santos Andrade Square around 19:30 p.m. There were about 50,000 people, according to the organization. The Military Police estimated 5,000 demonstrators.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The demonstration began at 13:00 in Salgado Filho Square and ended at 17:00 in Cathedral Square. There is no audience estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 14:00 in Renato Celidônia Square, next to the city hall. According to the organization, 4,000 demonstrators were at the scene. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally took place in Peace Square, in the Bancário neighborhood. The event started at 15:00 and ended around 20:00. According to the organization, it is estimated that 20 thousand people participated. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The event began around 16:00 at Independence Square, in the João Pessoa Center, and ended around 17:30. By 8:30 p.m., the organization and the Military Police had not released an estimated number of participants.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The rally began at 17:00 and, around 18:00, a motorcade left the neighborhood  Bivar Olinto towards Terreiro do Forró, located in the Brasília neighborhood. A section of the BR-361 was banned. Until 18:30, an estimated number of participants had not been released and by 20:20 the group was concentrated in Terreiro do Forró.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered starting at 14:00 in front of the INSS. The event is expected to end around 17:30 at the city's Ground Zero. The Military Police reported that the demonstration brought together 700 people.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally in Derby Square, in the center of the capital, began at 14:00. The march against Bolsonaro began at 16:00 p.m. The number of demonstrators is estimated at 15,000 people, according to the event's organization. The Pernambuco Military Police does not provide an estimate of the number of people attending events.
Demonstrators march in downtown Recife (PE) against Bolsonaro. — Photo: Marina Meireles/G1
In favor of Bolsonaro: The event in favor of the presidential candidate also began at 16:00 on Avenida Marechal Castelo Branco, North Zone of Teresina. The demonstrators made a motorcade passing through neighborhoods in the region. The organization believes that at least 500 vehicles, including cars and motorcycles, participated.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered at Praça da Liberdade, in the center of the capital, at 16:00 and walked down Avenida Frei Serafim to Francisco das Chagas Júnior Square. According to the organization, 5,000 people attended the march. The demonstration closed at 19:00 followed by performances by local artists.
Against Bolsonaro: The protest began around 15:00 at the intersection of Bernardo Vieira and Salgado Filho avenues. The nearby intersections were closed by the Municipal Traffic Department. The protest ended around 6 p.m. According to the organizers, there were 10,000 people. The Military Police did not release an estimate of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration took place at Flag Square around 15:00. There is no estimated number of participants.
In favor of Bolsonaro: Drivers took part in a motorcade in favor of the presidential candidate. Then there was a concentration of demonstrators in the square in front of the Erechim city hall. The Erechim Military Brigade reported that 5,000 vehicles were in the motorcade in favor of Bolsonaro. The organization did not release an estimate of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The #EleNão demonstration takes place this Saturday afternoon (29) at Redenção Park, in Porto Alegre. The event has the presence of candidates and is peaceful so far. The Military Brigade did not disclose the number of people at the event. The organization reported that 20,000 people attended the event.
AGAINST BOLSONARO: The demonstration began at 3 p.m. People walked along the city's main avenue to the so-called democratic corner, in the center. There are about 100 people, according to the Military Brigade.
Against Bolsonaro: An act against the presidential candidate has taken place near the Pelotas Public Market since 16:00. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration took place at Praça Saldanha Marinho around 14:00. There is no estimated number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators left Avenida Presidente Vargas, which is the city's main avenue, and walked to the city center, in Praça do Barão. The protest began at 4 pm and ended at 6 pm. There is no estimate of the number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 15:00 at Praça Porto Rocha. In the city, the demonstration was called the “Regional Act Against Fascism”. According to the organization, there are about 150 demonstrators.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The demonstrators gathered during the afternoon at Praça da Igreja do Saco, on the corner of BR-101 and Alberto Torres. According to the event organization, around 200 people are at the venue.
Against Bolsonaro: The act against the presidential candidate took people to São Salvador Square, in the center of the city. There are about 400 people, according to organizers.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration began at 13:00 with approximately 60 people at Praça Veríssimo de Melo, in the center.
Against Bolsonaro: Demonstrators took part in the “Women against Fascism” protest, which began around 15:00 p.m. The demonstrators gathered at Dermeval Barbosa Moreira Square, in the city center. Then they continued walking to the city hall. Traffic on Avenida Alberto Braune, the main avenue in the center, was in half a lane. There is no estimate of the number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The “Women Against Bolsonaro” demonstration began at 17:00 in Dom Pedro Square, in the city center. The demonstrators, mostly women, used banners and posters. There was also a sound car. There is still no audience estimate.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The motorcade started at 14:00 in front of the Áncora Neighborhood Citizenship Center. Approximately 300 vehicles participated in the motorcade.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began at 11 am at Praça José Pereira Câmara. Approximately 50 people attended the protest.
Against Bolsonaro: The #EleNão movement started around 15:00 and is scheduled for It was going to close at 6:00 p.m. The demonstrators are concentrated in the Alternative Space, a place devoid of physical activities. According to the Military Police, there are 500 people at the scene.
Against Bolsonaro: The act of the #EleNão movement was concentrated at 16:00 with cultural presentations and the preparation of posters. The protest is expected to end at 8 p.m. According to the organization, 500 people did not participate in the event.
In favor of Bolsonaro: Bolsonaro's supporters made a motorcade, which started in the neighboring municipality of Gaspar and reached Blumenau. The Military Police estimates that 460 cars and a thousand people participated in the event.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators began their walk at Dr. Blumenau Square and continued on XV de Novembro Street. The Military Police reports that 150 people participated in the event.
Against Bolsonaro: In the capital, the concentration of anti-Bolsonaro demonstrators was in Largo da Catedral. Then they marched along Avenida Beira-Mar Norte. According to the organization, 30,000 people attended the event. For the PM, there were 10,000.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally began at 15:00 on Avenida Adélia Franco, in the Jardins neighborhood. According to the organization, 5 thousand people are participating in the demonstration. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstrators toured São Bento, Portugal and Nove de Julho streets, ending at Praça Santa Cruz. According to the organization, the event brought together 1,500 people. The Military Police reports that there were a thousand participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The demonstration gathered around 14:00 at Praça Rui Barbosa. Then, the demonstrators marched to the Railway Station along the Calçadão da Batista de Carvalho and then returned to Praça Rui Barbosa. The event ended around 17:30 p.m. There is no estimate of the number of participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally of the protest began around 15:00 in João Abraão Square, where demonstrators stayed until 17:00. According to the organization, 150 people participated in the event. The Military Police reports that there were 50 demonstrators.
Against Bolsonaro: The act began at 15:30 in Largo do Rosário, in the center of the city, and ended at 17:45 in Largo do Bom Jesus. The organization estimates that 1.8 thousand people attended the event. The Military Police reports that there were 200 participants.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The motorcade started around 15:00 on Avenida Egisto Franceschi, in the Alto da Colina neighborhood. During the event, people followed other streets in the neighborhood. The Military Police says that 25 trucks, 300 cars, and 100 motorcycles are participating in the motorcade.
In favor of Bolsonaro: A motorcade started around 12:30 on Rua Amazonas. The event was attended by at least a thousand drivers, the organization said.
Against Bolsonaro: Demonstrators protest against the presidential candidate at Ponte Torta, in the city center. The event began at 16:00 p.m. According to the organizers, around 200 people are taking part in the demonstration.
Against Bolsonaro: The march began at 14:00 in Praça da Matriz. The demonstrators toured Rua XV de Novembro and Avenida 25 de Janeiro. Then they returned to the square around 17:00 when the event ended.
Against Bolsonaro: The event began around 16:00 at Skatistas Square. Afterwards, people marched along Avenida Saldanha Rodrigues. The event ended at 17:30 p.m. According to the organization, 500 people attended the event. The Military Police does not report the number of demonstrators.
Against Bolsonaro: The protest against Bolsonaro began around 11:30am. The event ended around 16:00 on the Esplanada do Theatro Pedro II, in the city center. The organization estimates that 2.2 thousand people are participating in the demonstration.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The motorcade of cars and motorcycles was concentrated on Avenida Presidente Kennedy. She followed streets and avenues to Praça Dalva de Oliveira. The organization says that 2,000 vehicles were in the motorcade. The Military Police did not release an estimate.
Against Bolsonaro: The event brought together demonstrators at Independence Square in Santos. The organization estimates that 3,000 people are at the demonstration. The Military Police reports that there are a thousand participants.
Against Bolsonaro: The act has taken place in front of the São José do Rio Preto City Hall, on Avenida Alberto Andaló, since 16:00. The group will also walk past the Municipal Market on Rua 15 de Novembro and go to the Nelson Castro Amphitheater, on Avenida Duque de Caxias, where a collective and symbolic hug will be held.
Against Bolsonaro: The rally began at 15:00 in Coronel Fernando Prestes Square, in the city center. The group then went around the block (streets of Penha, Monsignor João Soares and Braguinha) shouting “not him”. There is no estimated number of participants.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The rally began at 14:00 at Praça Cidade das Flores, in the central region. The organization estimates that a thousand people participated in the event. The Military Police announced that the protest had 500 participants.
Against Bolsonaro: A demonstration against the presidential candidate It is taking place in Matriz Square. According to the Municipal Civil Guard (GCM), around 200 people participate in the peaceful act. The organizers have not yet released the audience estimate. People began arriving at the place around 15:00 and marched through the city streets accompanied by an electric trio.
Against Bolsonaro: People gathered at Praça Santa Terezinha around 3 p.m. There was also a march in the streets near the square. There is no estimated number of participants.
In favor of Bolsonaro: The motorcade started at 10:30 on Rua Estados Unidos. Closing next to Athlete's Park, around 13:00 p.m. According to organizers, the manifesto brought together approximately 2,000 cars
In favor of Bolsonaro: People gathered at Praça dos Girassóis, in the central region, starting at 15:00. The motorcade is expected to follow Avenida Teotônio Segurado, which crosses the city from north to south, and heads towards the Ayrton Senna Gymnasium, in the southern region of Palmas.
Against Bolsonaro: The act began around 16:00 at the Indigenous Peoples Square, from where the demonstrators left for the Legislative Assembly, in Praça dos Girassóis. There is no estimated number of participants.

title: Brazil with 2 days left in a polarized presidential election, the favorite extreme right
author: Capital fr; AFP
description: Brazil will experience the first round of a polarized presidential election on Sunday as never before with, for the first time, a far-right candidate in a position...
text:
Brazil will experience the first round of a polarized presidential election on Sunday as never before with, for the first time, a far-right candidate in the position of favorite: ex-army captain Jair Bolsonaro, an apologist for dictatorship.
For weeks, all the polls have predicted the qualification in a seat for the 2nd round on October 28 of the 63-year-old deputy, under the colors of the small Liberal Social Party (PSL). Credited until now with some 32% of voting intentions, Jair Bolsonaro rose by three points in a poll published on Thursday (35%).
If the polls are more reliable than in the last elections, the left-wing candidate Fernando Haddad, 55, of the Workers' Party (PT) should come in 2nd position (at 22% in the last poll on Thursday), just four weeks after replacing ex-president Lula, who was ineligible because he was imprisoned for corruption.
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2Fcap.2F2018.2F10.2F05.2Fbc6e66db-7d65-4ce2-82e7-2622d15bb13f.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
Bolsonaro, seriously injured in an attack in the middle of the countryside, insists that he will be elected in the first round, an option that some analysts no longer rule out, without however considering it very likely.
While the presidential election may push Brazil into an unknown era, the elections of governors and assemblies of the 27 states, 513 deputies of the Lower House and two-thirds of the 81 senators also scheduled for Sunday should not radically transform the political landscape.
The president who succeeds conservative Michel Temer on January 1, for four years, will have a colossal task to extract the largest country in Latin America from the doldrums.
An outbreak of violence that has claimed more lives in seven years than in war-torn Syria, an economy at half-mast with 13 million unemployed, widening deficits and inequalities, discrediting political elites and persisting corruption are eating away at Brazil.
“I have never seen such a polarized election,” said Geraldo Monteiro, an analyst at Rio de Janeiro State University, about the presidential election. “There was no real debate of ideas.”
- Virulent anti-PT feeling -
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2FAFP.2F2018.2F09.2F25.2F8fa3225e-2dcf-493e-b0f9-0bce4829a491.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
Bolsonaro places “God above all.” He intends to stem the violence by liberalizing the carrying of arms and extra-judicial executions of “bandits” by the police. He wants to cleanse the country of its “corrupt elites”, appoint six general ministers and boost the economy with an ultra-liberal program. He is against abortion and equal pay for men and women.
Spared by corruption scandals, he draws his strength, increased tenfold by social networks, from his anti-system posture -- even though he has been a deputy for 27 years -- and from a virulent anti-PT feeling.
“This pro-Bolsonaro vote that you will find in every social class is a vote to reject institutional politics,” said Joao Feres, a political scientist at the Institute of Political and Social Studies in Rio.
Regardless of the fact that he admits to being an economic jerk, the markets have ended up choosing sides. In recent days, both the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange and the Real have picked up steam with very good polls.
Haddad, on the other hand, wants to “make the people happy again” as under Lula's two growth mandates (2003-2010), through social policies, the end of the freeze on public spending and gun control.
- 'Voting out of fear or anger' -
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2Fcap.2F2018.2F10.2F05.2F3516b572-142b-4ba9-a677-e0572bcfee1e.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
Paradoxically, the two leading candidates are the subject of the strongest rejection among the 147 million Brazilian voters.
Through his insults, Bolsonaro has alienated a majority of blacks, women, homosexuals and defenders of human rights.
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2Fcap.2F2018.2F10.2F05.2F69da6cca-6714-4c5f-9451-2879fc5b0dc4.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
Haddad is the recipient of the fierce hatred that Lula inspires on much of the right, center, business and wealthy classes.
Although the PT won the last four presidential elections, its history with the country ended very badly with the resounding dismissal in 2016 of Dilma Rousseff, who put an end to 13 years of a petty reign considered responsible for Brazil's current plagues.
Between the extreme right and the left, more measured voters will express themselves “more”. Fear or anger rather than conviction”, predicts Mr. Monteiro, who expects “an even more radical second round, perhaps with violence”.
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2Fcap.2F2018.2F10.2F05.2Fc7dcd40d-7509-4171-94f7-6f4ae0054e8e.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
! [] (https://www.capital.fr/imgre//scale/http.3A.2F.2Fprd2-bone-image.2Es3-website-eu-west-1.2Eamazonaws.2Ecom.2Fcap.2F2018.2F10.2F05.2Feeeab0f9-4d7e-45fb-ac08-e9710e0444d8.2Ejpeg/400xauto/background-color/ffffff/quality/70/picture.jpg)
The first round should confirm that the polarization was fatal to the three other major candidates.
Ciro Gomes (PDT, center left) still hopes, despite his 11%, to play the role of outsider. The PSDB candidate Geraldo Alckmin (8%) will have embodied the unexpected collapse of the center. As for the environmentalist Marina Silva (Rede), who had won more than 20 million votes in the last two presidential elections, she collapsed by 4%.

title: A Wet Plate Portrait of Greta Thunberg
author: Michael Zhang
description: Greta Thunberg exploded into the public consciousness last month after the 16-year-old Swedish climate activist gave an impassioned and scathing speech to
text:
A Wet Plate Portrait of Greta Thunberg
Greta Thunberg exploded into the public consciousness last month after the 16-year-old Swedish climate activist gave an impassioned and scathing speech to world leaders at the UN Climate Action Summit in New York. Earlier this month, wet plate photographer Shane Balkowitsch got 20 minutes with Thunberg at Standing Rock and used the time to make 2 wet plate portraits of her.
“I heard that Greta was going to Standing Rock,” Balkowitsch tells PetaPixel. “I reached out to my friends down there and wanted to see if she could come to my studio. Her schedule was too tight for a trip to Bismarck, so I offered to take my portable darkroom and chemicals and gear to Standing Rock, [saying] ‘if I can get 15 minutes, we could immortalize Greta in the historic photographic process of silver on glass’ — this picture would outlast all other photographs ever taken of her or will ever be taken of her.
“I got the word Monday afternoon that I could have 15 minutes of her time if I traveled to the reservation and take her portrait, so that is what I did.”
When Balkowitsch arrived at the agreed-upon location, he set up for the shoot in the open and waited for Thunberg to arrive.
“I knew [Thunberg and her father] were pressed on time,” Balkowitsch says, “so after they saw the first plate come to life in the fixer I looked at them and said, ‘can we do one more’, and her father said ‘Certainly,’ [and] that is when I made ‘Standing For Us All,’ a now iconic image of her standing at Standing Rock in the field.”
Here are the two portraits that resulted from the 20-minute shoot:
![](https://petapixel.com/assets/uploads/2019/10/Greta-Tintin-Eleanora-Ernman-Thunberg-10-8-2019-3328-Low-Resolution-636x800.jpg)
You can find more of Balkowitsch’s work on his website, Facebook, and Instagram.
P.S. Here’s an interview Balkowitsch gave Michael Comeau of On Portraits. Interesting fact: Balkowitsch never owned a camera before he jumped into the world of wet plate photography.
Image credits: Wet plate photos by Shane Balkowitsch. Behind-the-scenes photos by Chad Nodland.

title: Behind TIME's Cover Photo of Greta Thunberg, 2019 Person of the Year
author: Michael Zhang
description: TIME today announced that teen climate activist Greta Thunberg is its 2019 Person of the Year. The 16-year-old becomes the youngest individual ever to
text:
Behind TIME’s Cover Photo of Greta Thunberg, 2019 Person of the Year
TIME today announced that teen climate activist Greta Thunberg is its 2019 Person of the Year. The 16-year-old becomes the youngest individual ever to receive TIME’s annual honor.
“When TIME asked me to photograph Greta, I was thinking how can I make a portrait that combines gentleness and at the same time courage,” Arbugaeva tells TIME. “How do I capture the intense, focused gaze inwards as well as outwards, which I feel is characteristic of Greta. It was not an easy task.”
The photographer started off by creating a mood board with references from Botticelli, Monet, Norse mythology, tarot cards, and Romantic period art. She then scouted Lisbon for a couple of days before settling on a rocky beach found near the Portuguese city.
Arbugaeva held the photo shoot on December 4th.
![](https://petapixel.com/assets/uploads/2019/12/unnamed1-800x600.jpg)
![](https://petapixel.com/assets/uploads/2019/12/TIME-POY-BTS2-600x800.jpg)
“As she stood for a photograph, the sky colored golden pink creating beautiful light, ocean tide was rising and waves were raging around her,” Arbugaeva tells TIME. “Greta stood tall and strong without moving, just a few strands of her hair fluttering in a gentle breeze. She looked straight ahead into the ocean she just crossed.
“At this moment it felt as if all nature elements and forces aligned to create the magic—the most treasured gift for a photographer.”
“Meaningful change rarely happens without the galvanizing force of influential individuals, and in 2019, the earth’s existential crisis found one in Greta Thunberg,” says TIME Editor-in-Chief and CEO Edward Felsenthal regarding Thunberg’s selection. “Thunberg has become the biggest voice on the biggest issue facing the planet—and the avatar of a broader generational shift in our culture that is playing out everywhere from the campuses of Hong Kong to the halls of Congress in Washington.
“This was the year the climate crisis went from behind the curtain to center stage, from ambient political noise to squarely on the world’s agenda, and no one did more to make that happen than Thunberg.
“For sounding the alarm about humanity’s predatory relationship with the only home we have, for bringing to a fragmented world a voice that transcends backgrounds and borders, for showing us all what it might look like when a new generation leads, Greta Thunberg is TIME’s 2019 Person of the Year.”

title: Greta Thunberg’s North Dakota photo is at national library
author: The Associated Press
description: A photo of Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg at a Native American reservation in North Dakota has been archived at the Library of Congress in Washington. Photographer Shane Balkowitsch preserved the image on a glass plate and titled it “Standing For Us All.”
text:
Greta Thunberg’s North Dakota photo is at national library
![Climate activist Greta Thunberg visits the Standing Rock](https://img.apmcdn.org/7d7d3151f22adfca739965db422600e5d0f585ee/normal/84a5b2-20191202-thunberg01.jpg)
Go Deeper.
Create an account or log in to save stories.
Like this?
Thanks for liking this story! We have added it to a list of your favorite stories.
A photo of Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg at a Native American reservation in North Dakota has been archived at the Library of Congress in Washington.
Shane Balkowitsch, who took the photo, preserved the image on a glass plate and titled it “Standing For Us All.” Balkowitsch told the Bismarck Tribune that it’s his “most important work to date.”
The photo shows 16-year-old Thunberg looking into the distance during a visit to the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. It was preserved using a method known as “wet plate collodion,” which involves wetting glass with various chemicals before inserting the plate into a camera and developing the photo.
![Climate activist Greta Thunberg visits the Standing Rock](https://img.apmcdn.org/40c36c0265f3613f2173c799b2015a34d95a43d4/normal/3a01ba-20191202-thunberg02.jpg)
“I wanted to give nature its due respect on the plate,” Balkowitsch noted.
Turn Up Your Support
MPR News helps you turn down the noise and build shared understanding. Turn up your support for this public resource and keep trusted journalism accessible to all.
The photographer said the image “wasn’t supposed to happen,” but it’s the one that Thunberg chose to share with the world. Thunberg posted it on Twitter when she left North America on Nov. 13.
Balkowitsch had heard Thunberg would be at the reservation and made plans to meet her there, since she wasn’t able to come to his studio. He recalled being told he only had 15 minutes.
Library of Congress visitors can request to view the plate. Balkowitsch said the plate will outlast any other printed photograph of Thunberg because it's made using silver, which does not fade over time.
"This plate will be here long after her and I are gone," he said.
Another image, a close-up Thunberg’s face, will be featured at the Swedish History Museum in Stockholm.

title: Photographer Immortalizes Greta Thunberg in Powerful Wet Plate Portraits
author: Jessica Stewart
description: “There is a presence and a maturity about her that is very hard to explain.”
text:
Climate change activist Greta Thunberg is just 16 years old, but has already captured the attention of the world—and a nomination for a Nobel Peace Prize. With her aim to spotlight environmental crisis, it's no surprise that she decided to pay a visit to Standing Rock, where indigenous groups are fighting the Dakota Access oil pipeline. It was here that she also met with Shane Balkowitsch, a wet plate photographer who has been taking powerful portraits of Northern Plains Native Americans. The sacred grounds at Standing Rock provided the perfect backdrop for Balkowitsch to immortalize the teen activist.
It was a brief encounter, with Balkowitsch given just 20 minutes at the conclusion of a special ceremony to take the portraits. Thunberg had just been honored with the Lakota Native American name Maphiyata echiyatan his win which translates as “woman who came from the heavens”—given to her by tribal leaders to acknowledge her important work. For the photographer, who has four children of his own and is quite concerned about the state of the planet, the moment was unforgettable.
“Up to the moment that we met I really could not get my arms around how this child was able to grab the attention of the world in such a short amount of time,” Balkowitsch tells My Modern Met. “After meeting her and spending a little personal time with her, I now understand. There is a presence and a maturity about her that is very hard to explain. She is very soft-spoken but she seems to be present in every single moment. There is an intent in her being that is not seen every day.”
Balkowitsch had been told that there would only be time for one portrait, but after seeing the beautiful first exposure, everyone immediately agreed to a second photograph. After positioning her in an open field, he took what is now called Standing For Us All. It's an evocative portrait that captures the strength of Thunberg's character and the wisdom beyond her years that she displays as she tirelessly works to invoke change.
Wet plate photographer Shane Balkowitsch recently had a portrait session with Greta Thunberg.
Take a look behind the scenes of his photo session with the climate activist at Standing Rock.
Shane Balkowitsch: Website | Facebook | Instagram
My Modern Met granted permission to feature photos by Shane Balkowitsch.

title: Photographer Cancels Photo Mural of Greta Thunberg After Boycott Threats
author: Michael Zhang
description: Wet plate photographer Shane Balkowitsch has canceled plans to put up a mural of his portrait of climate activist Greta Thunberg after locals threatened
text:
Photographer Cancels Photo Mural of Greta Thunberg After Boycott Threats
Wet plate photographer Shane Balkowitsch has canceled plans to put up a mural of his portrait of climate activist Greta Thunberg after locals threatened to boycott the business in the building.
The portraits have received quite a bit of attention, and the portrait above, titled “Standing For Us All,” was donated by the photographer to the Library of Congress.
Balkowitsch then came up with the idea of displaying it as a 7-foot-tall mural on the side of a building in downtown Bismarck, North Dakota.
![](https://petapixel.com/assets/uploads/2020/02/murallocation-800x435.jpg)
![](https://petapixel.com/assets/uploads/2020/02/GRETA11.jpg)
Even though the project would have been funded by Balkowitsch himself, it seems many residents weren’t fond of the idea.
After securing permission from the building’s owner and bakery tenant as well as an approval recommendation from the city planning staff, Balkowitsch got the idea featured by local news station KFYR-TV.
The station also shared the story on its Facebook page, but that’s when things started getting contentious.
The Facebook post was soon flooded by North Dakotans expressing displeasure about the planned mural. Most of the 1,200 comments published thus far seem to be critical of the idea.
Other comments mentioned boycotting the business, Brick Oven Bakery, or vandalizing the mural once it was put up. Unwilling to put the business at risk for the mural, Balkowitsch and the bakery quickly withdrew their mural application.
The photographer says that the mural was more about art and history than politics.
“There was no motivation other than install a very important piece of history that was captured here in North Dakota, in Bismarck — but I guess Bismarck doesn’t want it,” Balkowitsch tells The Bismarck Tribune. “I feel for the bakery. I can’t have some business being threatened for my work.
“It’s a picture of a 17-year-old girl; that’s all it is to me. Her message and stuff, that’s her message. As an artist, it’s my duty to capture the history surrounding her, and the fact that she came to North Dakota, and the reservation down at Standing Rock.”

title: Greta Thunberg reflects on living through multiple crises in a 'post-truth society'
author: Oliver Whang
description: In an interview with National Geographic, the teen climate activist considers the successes of the youth climate movement and the challenges it will face.
text:
Greta Thunberg reflects on living through multiple crises in a 'post-truth society'
In an interview with National Geographic, the teen climate activist considers the successes of the youth climate movement and the challenges it will face.
![greta thunberg environmental activist](https://i.natgeofe.com/n/37853497-a35e-44b7-b77d-f6959e6a8879/01_greta-tintin-eleanora-ernman-thunberg---greta-10-8-2019--3327--high-resolution-.jpg)
This portrait is titled “Greta.”
Since her first sit-in outside the Swedish parliament building more than two years ago, Greta Thunberg’s fundamental message has been clear and unchanging: The climate crisis is humanity’s greatest existential threat and we need to treat it as such. That message inspired millions of young activists to protest for change and led to a series of viral speeches that have defined Thunberg’s global fame. She was Time’s 2019 Person of the Year and was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize two years in a row.
Now, though, in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic—a global crisis of a much different nature—and the looming threat of the U.S. backing out of the Paris Agreement, the 17-year-old activist is back at school in Sweden. National Geographic spoke with Thunberg via Zoom about how her activism has changed over the past year, and how her message might survive an increasingly complex world. (This interview has been lightly edited for length and clarity).
Oliver Whang: A lot has happened in the past half year or so. How has your work changed since the coronavirus hit?
Greta Thunberg: Well, we have moved from lots of physical things, meetings and strikes and so on, to doing it digitally. But, I mean, since we are a movement of people who don't fly because of the environmental impact, we haven't had to change that much in the way we work. And then every country, every local group, differs. Because we are a very decentralized movement. We are not run top-down, but every local group decides on their own what they're going to do. So it's been different from city to city, from country to country.
Oliver Whang: Have any of those countries or cities adapted in a way that's been really successful?
Greta Thunberg: Yeah. Some do weekly digital strikes, which have been successful. And many have done symbolic actions. Some have put up signs or shoes outside the parliament buildings to symbolize that we should be here, but we are home. So there are lots of creative ways people have adapted.
Oliver Whang: Do you feel like the climate change crisis has been kind of forgotten in the middle of all this other stuff?
Greta Thunberg: Well, that's a very poignant narrative because, yes, of course, as have all other issues. In an emergency like this, you have to expect that other things are going to be put on hold, as they have been.
Oliver Whang: One thing that's been striking to me about the worldwide response to the coronavirus pandemic is that a lot of countries and companies have made really big moves. Stimulus bills were passed and companies are developing vaccines quickly. Do you see this kind of response as inspiring some kind of action towards addressing the climate crisis?
Greta Thunberg: Well, we shouldn't be comparing different crises, but it does show that we can treat a crisis like a crisis. And that it will probably change the way we perceive crises and crisis response. And it really proves that the climate crisis has never once been treated as a crisis. It's just being treated as a public and important question, like a political topic. Which it is not, because it's an existential crisis.
Oliver Whang: But has the response to the coronavirus given you more hope? As in, we can have a similar response to the climate crisis?
Greta Thunberg: It confirmed what I already knew. That once we treat the climate crisis like a crisis, we can change things and we can achieve things.
Oliver Whang: Here in the U.S., an election is coming up and our country is scheduled to withdraw from the Paris Agreement on November 4th. Our president has been promising to do this for years—he says that the accord is unfair to America. And there are a lot of people, not most of the people in the U.S., but a lot of them, who agree with the president and agree with that decision to withdraw from the accord. What would you say to those people?
Greta Thunberg: Nothing. Just as I always do, refer to the science. Because people have been trying to impact these people for so long, and they haven't succeeded. So why should I? Why should I be any different? If they don't listen to and understand and accept the science, then there's really nothing that I can do. There's something much deeper that needs to change them.
Oliver Whang: What might that deeper thing be?
Greta Thunberg: That we live in a post-truth society today, and that we don't care that we have lost empathy. We have stopped caring for each other in a way. We have stopped thinking long-term and sustainable. And that's something that goes much deeper  than just climate crisis deniers.
Oliver Whang: So do you think in order to address the climate crisis, we might need like a cultural shift or a paradigm shift rather than just passing carbon taxes and legislation, influencing leaders and developing technology?
Greta Thunberg: Well if I say that, then people will take that quote out of context and say that I want a revolution or something. But I mean the climate crisis is not the only problem here. It is just a symptom of a larger crisis. Like the loss of biodiversity, acidification of the oceans, and loss of fertile soil, and so on. And these things will not just be solved by stopping our emissions of greenhouse gases. The earth is a very complex system. If you take one thing and put it out of balance then that will have an impact on things beyond our comprehension. And that goes for equality as well. Humans are part of nature, and if we are not doing well, then nature is not doing well, because we are nature.
There are no arguments left. There are no excuses left. Now, it's just, either you try to minimize the crisis or just completely deny it, or you try to distract.Greta Thunberg
![](https://i.natgeofe.com/n/923d25f7-2a1f-4711-a800-91a2cdfc0a28/02_greta-tintin-eleanora-ernman-thunberg---standing-for-us-all-10-8-2019--3328--high-resolution----additional-editing.jpg)
Thunberg poses for a photo, “Standing For Us All.”
Oliver Whang: Does it bother you that you might be missing all these people who maybe accept that climate change is a thing and that it's a crisis, but prioritize joblessness or access to food or other domestic issues over the climate crisis? Do you feel like you're missing them?
Greta Thunberg: No, it doesn't bother me. We have not been made aware of the climate crisis—the climate crisis has never been treated as a crisis, so how can we expect people to care about it? Since we are not aware of even the basic facts, how can we expect people to want climate action? And so that is something that needs to change. We need to understand that we are not fighting for separate causes. We are fighting for one and the same cause even though it might not seem like it. It's the fight for climate justice, social justice. Whatever is the issue, it’s the fight for justice.
Oliver Whang: Do you think that we've made any significant progress towards addressing the climate crisis since you started protesting more than two years ago?
Greta Thunberg: It depends on how you see it. In one way, yes. It feels like the debate has shifted and more and more people are starting to slowly understand the climate crisis more and prioritizing it. But on the other hand, it has still never once been treated as a crisis. And the emissions are still rising. So it depends on how you see it.
But I mean we can't expect that this one movement will change the world. If we think that is the case then we have not understood the climate crisis. People are like, ‘Has your movement failed since you have not accomplished your goals?’ But, I mean, what are our goals? We don't have any goals. Our goal is to do as much as we possibly can to be a small part of a very big shift. To be one of countless of activists who push in the same direction from different perspectives. And that is our goal. We can't expect one movement or one initiative, one solution, to change everything, or to put us in the right direction. Because the climate crisis is very complex. It's not just that simple.
Oliver Whang: Was there anything that you did or that other youth climate activists have done that you think has been particularly successful? Or any sort of manifestation of what you've done in policy or in the economy that you think is an example of your success?
Greta Thunberg: Yes, we have many. Especially local examples. But I think the biggest thing that we have accomplished is to put the focus on the science. We just say, ‘We don't want you to listen to us, we want you to listen to the science.’ This not a question about politics, this is not our opinion. We don't want the emissions to reduce, it's what the science says is needed if we are to stay in line with our commitments. We don't want things to be like this. But unfortunately, that's where we are. And we will continue to push for people to listen to the science.
Oliver Whang: Do you ever have any doubts about your work? Do you ever doubt yourself or what you've been doing?
Greta Thunberg: No, because I know it's the right thing to do. We are at a time now where we must step out of our comfort zones. I feel like I have a moral duty to do what I can, since I'm a citizen. And that makes me part of something and it is my duty, my moral duty, my moral responsibility, to do everything I can.
Oliver Whang: And that's never been in question for you?
Greta Thunberg: No. I mean, I don't want to be an activist. I don't think any climate activist does it because they want to. We do this just because no one else is doing anything, and because we need to do somethin g. Someone needs to do something, and we are somebodies.
Oliver Whang: I'm curious if you feel like your moral duties or your responsibility has changed as you’ve become this more recognized name.
Greta Thunberg: Well, yes. Of course everyone has a responsibility, but the bigger your platform, the bigger your responsibility. And the bigger your power, the bigger your responsibility. The bigger your carbon footprint, the bigger your moral duty. So of course, as I've gotten a bigger platform that also comes with a bigger responsibility. I must use these channels, or whatever you would call them, to educate, to spread awareness.
And the things, all the resources I have, they will disappear one day. I mean, I won't be this person for a long time. Soon people will lose interest in me and I won't be so-called “famous” anymore. And then I will have to do something else. So I'm trying to, as long as I have this platform, use it.
Oliver Whang: How do you see yourself proceeding from here? Do you want to go to university? Do you have any plans?
Greta Thunberg: Well, I don't really know. I just do what I want to do at the moment. And right now, I just started gymnasium (Editor’s note: “gymnasium” is the Swedish equivalent of high school). And there I will be for the following three years. And unless I want to do something else, I mean, we will see. The world changes from day to day. So you just have to adapt, I guess.
Oliver Whang: How do you plan on sustaining this movement? Are there specific things we need to do that are different from what needed to be done two years ago or one year ago or eight months ago?
Greta Thunberg: I mean, it's very complex. But right now we have kind of hit the wall. There are no arguments left. There are no excuses left. Now, it's just, either you try to minimize the crisis or just completely deny it, or you try to distract. We just need to start treating the crisis like a crisis and continue to lift up the science, but now everyone's blaming each other and we are stuck in a loop. We won't get anywhere unless someone breaks that chain, so to speak. Someone needs to do something. I mean, of course, many people have to do lots of things, but unless someone with a big platform or big responsibility does something to start treating the crisis like a crisis—for instance, the media—then we won't be able to move from here.

title: This just in: Greta Thunberg is not a time traveller
author: CBC Kids News
description: A vintage photo of kids working at a gold mine in Yukon has led to some funny Twitter theories about Greta Thunberg and time travel.
text:
This just in: Greta Thunberg is not a time traveller
Vintage photo sparks wild theories online
Look closely at this 121-year-old photo of three kids mining gold in Yukon and what do you see?
Wait a second, is that Greta Thunberg?
We hate to break it to you, but “that is not Greta Thunberg,” said James Stack, a reference librarian at the University of Washington, where the photo came from.
Stack said they have the negative and the original print in their collection, which is named after the photographer who took the image back in 1898, Eric A. Hegg.
The resemblance is all just a strange coincidence.
But that didn’t stop the time traveller theories from picking up steam on Twitter!
Stack — who said he answered the phone all morning on Thursday, fielding questions about the Greta look-alike — isn’t the only one who’s skeptical of the time traveller theory.
Some said if Greta was truly a time traveller, she wouldn’t bother going out of her way to find green modes of transportation in 2019.
The 16-year-old climate activist has made a point of travelling across the world in a sustainable way.
She’s currently hitching a ride from the U.S. to the UN Climate Change Conference in Spain on a sailboat operated by a couple of Australian YouTubers.
Others said the time traveller theory simply didn’t go far enough.
Some of the real keeners wanted to discuss the environmental impact of time travel technology.
Apparently, this isn’t the first time a celebrity has discovered a doppelgӓnger from the past.
Doppelgӓnger is a German word for look-alike.
CBC Kids News reached out to Greta to see what she thought of the doppelgӓnger theory.
We haven’t heard back yet.
But Fridays For Future International, the group that helps organize school strikes worldwide, did respond.
The girl in the old picture “really looks like Greta,” said the authors of the email, Bengt and Lena, but there are “so many people all over the world” who have look-alikes.
Why shouldn't Greta have “one or several” look-alikes, too?
That said, Bengt and Lena wrote that Greta and the Fridays for Future volunteers believe it is important to listen to science.
“As far as we know there is no scientific evidence for the existence of so-called time travellers,” they said.
image_caption: Tweet from Cool History shows black and white photo of kids in nature surrounded by tools with caption: Three children operating rocker at a gold mine on Dominion Creek, Yukon Territory, ca. 1898;Caption not found

title: Shane Balkowitsch makes portraits of 2019 Nobel Peace Prize nominee Greta Thunberg
author: All-About-Photo Com; Shane Balkovich
description: All About Photo.com | Photography article: 'Shane Balkowitsch makes portraits of 2019 Nobel Peace Prize nominee Greta Thunberg'.
text:
On Tuesday, October 8, North Dakotan wet plate collodion artist Shane Balkowitsch
had the chance to make several portraits of Swedish environmental activist and 2019 Nobel Peace Prize nominee Greta Thunberg during her visit to North Dakota in support of indigenous groups fighting Dakota Access oil pipeline. Many in the Standing Rock tribe consider the pipeline a threat to the region's clean water and to ancient burial grounds. The shoot took place at Standing Rock, ND where Thunberg was being honored by tribal leaders for her work to fight climate change. During the closing ceremony, Thunberg was bestowed with a Lakota Native American name Maphiyata echiyatan his win which translates as woman who came from the heavens.
![Shane Balkowitsch](https://www.all-about-photo.com/images/articles/ART-559-1.jpg)
Greta Thunberg, Standing Rock, North Dakota, October 8 © Shane Balkowitsch
![Shane Balkowitsch](https://www.all-about-photo.com/images/articles/ART-559-3.jpg)
Greta Thunberg, Standing Rock, North Dakota, October 8 © Shane Balkowitsch
Shane Balkowitsch's shoot with Greta Thunberg coincides with the publication this month of his first monograph Northern Plains Native Americans: A Modern Wet Plate Perspective (Glitterati Editions) which presents a selection of images from his long-term photographic project which aims to capture 1000 wet plate portraits of Native Americans. Following in the footsteps of Edward S. Curtis and Orlando Scott Goff, Balkowitsch pays homage to his home state and its Native American heritage and culture. His photographs highlight the dignity of his subjects, depicting them not as archetypes, but individuals of contemporary identities with historical legacies. In our image-saturated world informed by automation and digital speed, Northern Plains Native Americans offers a fresh perspective on the photographic imagination.
In his essay in the book, Balkowitsch writes about this Victorian photographic method which dates back to the nineteenth century. Each image contains not only the moment it was taken, but the time in which it was taken. People are willing to hold their breath, focus their eyes and still their thoughts for the 10 seconds necessary to make an exposure. Each exposure contains a piece of eternity. In essence, people willingly give me a little part of their lives to be photographed in collodion.
About Shane Balkowitsch: ![Shane Balkowitsch](https://www.all-about-photo.com/images/articles/ART-559-4.jpg)
Beautiful Evening Star Woman Margaret Yellowbird-Landin, Sahnish Hidatsa Assiniboine, 9 August 2017, Plate No. 2419 © Shane Balkowitsch
Artist Shane Balkowitsch is a self-taught large format photographer. As one of the fewer than 1,000 wet plate collodion artists practicing around the world, Balkowitsch carries on the tradition of the Victorian photographic method, which dates back to the 19th century. Based in Bismarck, North Dakota, Balkowitsch established the first natural light wet plate studio constructed in the entire country in over 100 years, the Nostalgic Glass Wet Plate Studio. His works are held in prestigious institutions, including the State Historical Society of North Dakota and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.
![Shane Balkowitsch](https://www.all-about-photo.com/images/articles/ART-559-5.jpg)
Warrior Spirit Elijah Landin, Arikara Hidatsa Dakota, 3 August 2016, Plate No. 1943 © Shane Balkowitsch

title: Climate Change activist Greta Thunberg captured on 'wet plate' by North Dakotan artist Shane Balkowitsch
author: Katy Cowan
description: Activist Greta Thunberg captured on 'wet plate' by North Dakotan artist Shane Balkowitsch.
text:
American "wet plate collodion" artist Shane Balkowitsch recently had the chance to make several portraits of Swedish environmental activist and 2019 Nobel Peace Prize nominee Greta Thunberg during her visit to North Dakota in support of indigenous groups fighting the Dakota Access oil pipeline.
Greta Thunberg © Shane Balkowitsch. Via Creative Boom submission. All images courtesy of the artist.
Many in the Standing Rock tribe consider the pipeline a threat to the region's clean water and ancient burial grounds. The shoot took place at Standing Rock, ND where Thunberg was being honoured by tribal leaders for her work to fight climate change.
During the closing ceremony, Thunberg was named 'Maphiyata echiyatan his win' which translates as 'woman who came from the heavens'.
Greta Thunberg © Shane Balkowitsch
Shane Balkowitsch's shoot with Thunberg coincides with the publication this month of his first monograph, Northern Plains Native Americans: A Modern Wet Plate Perspective, published by Glitterati Editions. It presents a selection of images from his long-term photographic project that aims to capture a thousand wet plate portraits of Native Americans.
Following in the footsteps of Edward S. Curtis and Orlando Scott Goff, Balkowitsch pays homage to his home state and its Native American heritage and culture. His photographs highlight the dignity of his subjects, depicting them not as archetypes, but individuals of contemporary identities with historical legacies.
In his essay in the book, Balkowitsch writes about this Victorian photographic method which dates back to the nineteenth century. "Each image contains not only the moment it was captured but the time in which it was taken, too. People are willing to hold their breath, focus their eyes and still their thoughts for the 10 seconds necessary to make an exposure. Each exposure contains a piece of eternity. In essence, people willingly give me a little part of their lives to be photographed in collodion."
As one of the fewer than 1,000 wet plate collodion artists practising around the world, Balkowitsch carries on the tradition of the Victorian photographic method, which dates back to the 19th century. Based in Bismarck, North Dakota, Balkowitsch established the first natural light wet plate studio constructed in the entire country in over 100 years. Discover more at sharoncol.balkowitsch.com.
Elijah Landin © Shane Balkowitsch
Margaret Landin - Honoring Sky Woman © Shane Balkowitsch
Synsir and Jayceon © Shane Balkowitsch
Dakota Goodhouse © Shane Balkowitsch

title: How Terry Gilliam used covert screenings to release 'Brazil'
author: Arun Starkey
description: After 'Brazil' was released in Europe, Terry Gilliam came into conflict with the studio before the US release, so he used covert screenings in his favour.
text:
![‘Brazil’ Terry Gilliam](https://faroutmagazine.co.uk/static/uploads/1/2023/02/‘Brazil-Terry-Gilliam-1140x855.jpg)
‘Brazil’: Terry Gilliam, covert screenings and a very public battle with Universal Pictures
Although Terry Gilliam has produced many memorable movies, including the likes of Time Bandits and 12 Monkeys, his masterpiece is undoubtedly the 1985 effort Brazil. A sharp satire of modern life set in a dystopian future where bureaucracy and surveillance keep humanity enslaved, it is a spiritual successor to George Orwell’s distinguished warning against authoritarianism – 1984.
Brazil follows the story of Jonathan Pryce’s low-ranking bureaucrat, Sam Lowry, who endeavours to break free from the chains of the system whilst and find a mysterious woman who keeps appearing in his dreams. As well as having clear Orwellian themes, Gilliam’s film is also noted for its Kafka-esque stylings and absurd essence, with the depiction of a dystopian future one of the most terrifying in cinema.
One fascinating aspect of Brazil‘s story is Gilliam’s tense battle with the studio, Universal Pictures, over the US release. Although the movie had already been distributed in Europe via 20th Century Fox in February 1985, Universal demanded a shorter version with a more straightforward ending for the US audience. “Listen, Sid,” Gilliam reportedly said in response to Sidney Sheinberg, the chairman of Universal. “The film we made is the film we all agreed to make. If you want to make another film, you have my support. Just put your name on it.” Understandably, the comment caused a stir.
Not stopping there, Gilliam went public with what Universal Pictures were attempting to do to his film, telling journalists who were sympathetic to his cause. In a stroke of genius, he also placed an advert in Variety that directly asked Sheinberg when he would release Brazil. However, both actions violated a gag order in his contract with the studio, which strangely restricted him from criticising their business operations in public. Famously, Sheinberg would also speak publicly about the dispute, running a counter advertisement in Daily Variety offering to sell the movie.
However, his opponent was Terry Gilliam, a member of the anti-establishment troupe Monty Python, and he would not back down. Duly, he opted to show the movie in clandestine screenings for local critics and film schools, which violated Universal’s contracted right to sole distribution. He and producer Arnon Milchan even debated renting cinemas in Mexico and ferrying Americans across the border in buses. Luckily for the pair, who only wanted their unadulterated cut of Brazil shown in America, the covert screenings would help turn the tide against Universal.
The Los Angeles Film Critics Association named Brazil ‘Best Picture’, with their sister organisations in New York, Washington, Boston, and Chicago all doing the same. Understanding that the Brazil Gilliam and Milchan wanted to release was a hit, Universal changed their stance and released it in all its original glory in December 1985. It eventually won two BAFTAs and was nominated for two Oscars.

title: ‘Brazil’ Doc Takes You Behind the Scenes of Terry Gilliam’s Beautiful Dystopian Epic — Watch
author: Michael Nordine
description: The 28-minute featurette, which features interviews with the film's cast and crew, begins with a simple question: "What is 'Brazil?'"
text:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
Try as imitators might, there’s no film quite like “Brazil.” Terry Gilliam‘s dystopian sci-fi whatsit endures as a classic of more than one genre, which is typical of the “12 Monkeys,” “Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas” and “Time Bandits” director. A behind-the-scenes documentary features a series of interviews with Gilliam along with his cast and crew discussing the cult classic; watch it below.
READ MORE: ‘Back to the Future’: See Vintage Behind-the-Scenes Footage From the Blockbuster Trilogy’s 1990 Documentary
The 28-minute featurette begins with several principals being asked a simple question with few simple answers: “What is ‘Brazil’?” Star Jonathan Pryce (most recently seen as the High Sparrow “Game of Thrones”) has the most succinct answer: “It’s half a dream, and half a nightmare.” (Tom Stoppard’s is good, too: “It’s the myth of the free man in an unfree society.”) The rest of their discussions are similarly (and fittingly) heady, but lively as well.
READ MORE: Gene Wilder Opens Up About Making of ‘Willy Wonka’ and ‘Young Frankenstein’ – Watch
In more recent news, it was announced during Cannes this year that Gilliam is once again working on “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote,” this time with Michael Palin, Adam Driver and Olga Kurylenko as the three leads.
