title: detection – Another dot in the blogosphere?
description: Posts about detection written by Dr Ashley Tan
text:
Posts Tagged ‘detection’
Twisted Wired
Posted April 12, 2024on:
I like reading Wired for its well-written and informative articles about technology. But there are exceptions. One was a recent article that focused on Turnitin’s ability to detect AI-generated or assisted writing.
To its credit, Wired was transparent in its second paragraph:
Turnitin is owned by Advance, which also owns Condé Nast, publisher of WIRED.
It can be difficult to be critical of a parent company. So I was not surprised when it made this blanket statement:
A study published in October found that Turnitin was among the most accurate of 16 AI language detectors in a test that had the tool examine undergraduate papers and AI-generated papers.
It failed to also mention that one other tool, Copyleaks, was just as accurate. In fact, the researcher declared in his paper:
Three detectors – Copyleaks, TurnItIn, and Originality.ai – have high accuracy…
And:
Overall, the detectors that require registration and payment are only slightly more accurate than the others.
I would place less weight on the Wired article’s backing of Turnitin because it quoted only parts of the research paper that backed its stance.
In an effort to provide balance, the article also reported how Vanderbilt University [source], Northwestern University [source, see last paragraph], and Montclair State University [source] stopped using Turnitin’s AI detector. Why? Its use risked false positives and bias against learners of English language.
Readers should only take this paragraph seriously:
Detecting the use of gen AI is tricky. It’s not as easy as flagging plagiarism, because generated text is still original text. Plus, there’s nuance to how students use gen AI; some may ask chatbots to write their papers for them in large chunks or in full, while others may use the tools as an aid or a brainstorm partner.
That statement was honest about how people use emergent technologies. Yes, some users will break the rules and the technologies will help them do so. But that is what technologies do — they help us make new rules and create conditions for us to self-regulate.
![](https://ashleytan.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/pexels-photo-4458554.jpeg)
Smart, not brave
Posted August 21, 2023on:
Some might consider Vanderbilt University’s (VU) decision to disable Turnitin’s artificial intelligence (AI) detector to be brave. It was not. It was about making an informed decision.
Their full statement is worth the read. Here is one excerpt:
When Turnitin launched its AI-detection tool, there were many concerns that we had. This feature was enabled for Turnitin customers with less than 24-hour advance notice, no option at the time to disable the feature, and, most importantly, no insight into how it works. At the time of launch, Turnitin claimed that its detection tool had a 1% false positive rate, but in April, Turnitin updated that number to 4% after wider usage and testing (2023). To put that into context, Vanderbilt submitted 75,000 papers to Turnitin in 2022. If this AI detection tool was available then, around 3,000 student papers would have been incorrectly labeled as having some of it written by AI. Instances of false accusations of AI usage being leveled against students at other universities have been widely reported over the past few months, including multiple instances that involved Turnitin (Fowler, 2023; Klee, 2023). In addition to the false positive issue, AI detectors have been found to be more likely to label text written by non-native English speakers as AI-written (Sample, 2023).
VU was not just citing numbers and backing those up with narratives and prior research. In the rest of the statement, it also:
- examined how “Turnitin gives no detailed information as to how it determines if a piece of writing is AI-generated or not”
- was concerned about giving student and student-generated data to a company “with unknown privacy and data usage policies”.
It advised its faculty to:
- clearly communicate expectations and guidelines on AI use
- use guidelines by APA and MLA on citing AI
- reformat assignments if necessary, e.g., in-class work or “focusing on current issues that AI tools are not trained on”
But it seemed wary of the last point because that was followed up quickly with this statement:
One key aspect to remember throughout all of this is to balance the importance of mitigating inappropriate AI usage while also being mindful of AI’s benefits in the teaching and learning process.
So VU’s decision was not brave. It was smart. It is also one of the world’s leading educational institutions. How many others will follow?
AI detector detractor
Posted July 27, 2023on:
My reflection today was prompted by a TechCrunch report that OpenAI had sunset its own detection program.
I link this to an article I read yesterday, The Pedagogical Dangers of AI Detectors for the Teaching of Writing.
The author, Jacob Hubbard of San Diego State University, began by recalling how a uni versity professor, Jared Mumm, wrongly accused his students of using ChatGPT and failed their papers [source].
Hubbard explained the purpose of his own research:
…Mumm used ChatGPT exclusively to detect plagiarism, despite ChatGPT not being designed to detect AI generated content. Consequently, students were unfairly accused of academic dishonesty. This alarming trend inspired me to look into how professors have used AI detection software. Because these programs are unreliable as they neither accurately nor fairly detect plagiarism, I argue there is a real danger in using these AI detection software as an effort to mitigate this issue.
Hubbard tested ZeroGPT “as it was the most accessible without a paywall” and had a claimed detection accuracy of up to 98%. His data were his own book chapters and well-known documents.
When the author fed chapters he wrote in August and September 2022, ZeroGPT “flagged parts of my writing as including AI generated content, with scores that ranged from 15% to 53% likely generated by AI/GPT.” This was despite the fact that he had written those chapters on his own and ChatGPT only had training data up to 2021.
When analysed by ZeroGPT, the United States Constitution had a score of 92.15%. This led the author to remark:
I guess the Founding Fathers were using advanced technology at the time! On a more serious note, it is true these are small sample sizes, but these small sample sizes make this level of “detection” questionable and troubling as a valid classroom tool.
He used his findings to raise three questions about so called AI detectors:
- How confident should we be in these programs to detect AI-generated content?
- How do the use of these AI detection programs affect the way we evaluate student work?
- What student-teacher dynamics do the use of these AI detection programs create?
Since such detectors are unreliable, the author suggested that we rely on more comprehensive strategies like requiring students to submit multiple drafts and demonstrate the writing process.
He dissuaded the use of detectors also because they exacerbate bias — students have unequal access to technology like ChatGPT and detectors tend to label the writing of non-native speakers as AI-generated. The unreliability of detectors might also foster distrust between teachers and students because the tools are a source of unfair scrutiny.
I find no better way to conclude than to quote the questions Hubbard raised in his own conclusion:
Why operate under the assumption students are going to cheat? Why assume a student is going to use ChatGPT to write their essay and not put in the work? Wouldn’t it make more sense to work directly with students to mitigate issues of plagiarism, rather than relying on a machine to do it for us?
BS detection Ukraine edition
Posted March 14, 2022on:
Modern literacy should include BS detection.
Scams and falsehoods probably started the moment we became sentient, but they are easier to create and have greater reach now. So we all need to learn how to tell fact from fiction.
We cannot always rely on videos like the one above nor will sites like Snopes have already evaluated what we find. So how might we help ourselves?
For images we have reverse image search with tools like TinEye or even variants of Google image search.
Video reverse search is a bit more involved and might rely on reverse image search engines like Berify.
The tools are not in short supply and they are easy to use. The challenge is mindset. Are we cautiously sceptical and do we bother to check what we find online?
In 2016, much of the Internet-connected world seemed to wake up to the post-truth world.
People have questioned Facebook’s role in spreading fake news [some examples]. There is a Chrome extension that fact-checks Trump’s tweets. Columnists and talk show hosts alike enjoy endless ammunition in the form of dubious news and information.
While all this gets the attention it deserves, there are other less obvious but equally important traps to avoid. I have noticed at least three forms on Twitter.
- The first is direct tweets, mostly from bots, that thank you for following them even though you have not. These tempt you to click on profile or embedded links. Do not do this because you do not know where those URLs lead to. Just look to see if there is a “Following” label in their profile instead.
- There people who might include you on their “myfollowers” lists. If you are not sure, click on their profiles and check if you are following them.
- There are also some bot or bot-like accounts that might follow you. I get these on an almost daily basis and some have identical profile URLs. They are hoping you will reciprocate or hope that your real followers take notice and follow them.
Whether the accounts claim to follow you or that you follow them, their intent is to try to artificially inflate their following or get you to click on dubious URLs. Neither is ethical behaviour.
My main strategy is to block all th ree types of tweet accounts. I also started compiling a list of spambots a while ago. I stopped doing this and just blocked them but recently resumed adding them to the list in case this is useful to others.
I like to think of this sort of curative activity as pruning a garden so that weeds do not have the opportunity to grow.
This sort of crap detection is preventive. As you maintain an open mind, you do not leave it so open that a lot of rubbish falls in.

text:

In the second part, we will tell you how a foreign-language video can be subtitled in Finnish and what kind of new propaganda can be disseminated. Finally, we will give the school classes a fact-checking function.

Climate demonstration video taken out of contextÃ¤
One common way to disseminate disinformation, that is, intentionally misleading information, is to take the correct video or image out of context and use it to create something that is not true.
During the war in Ukraine, the propaganda machine controlled by the Venã¤jã¤n state has, for example, disseminated videos showing civilian victims of the war in Ukraine being brought to life. The videos are intended to create the impression that other images and videos of the war in Ukraine are false, and that these images and videos about the war in Ukraine are false and that they would not have caused civilian casualties.
One example of this is a video circulating on social media in which a man wearing a black respirator speaks to the camera in German. In the background, there are people lying in black body bags, one of whom begins to move. A third personÃ¶ runs to a person lying on the ground, moving.
The video has been distributed on social media with the following words: “IHME! The dead Ukrainians were brought back to life after they died on social media, but they were caught in a live broadcast. Tã¤mã¤ the whole PR disaster leviÃ¤Ã¤Ã¤ to kã¤n very quickly.â
In reality, the video was filmed for the Italian television channel OE24, whose reporter was reporting on the climate demonstration in Vienna. Behind the reporter, 49 protesters lie in body bags to show how many people could die every day because of climate change.
So the video has nothing to do with the war in Ukraine. It was uploaded to YouTube on February 4, 2022, weeks before the start of the HyÃ¶kkã¤ys war. You can check the origin of the video using the same tools that we have presented in the blogs: a search engine, an image search, and try to translate the video into another language.
The same video, which has been circulated on social media as an indication of âUkraine's liesâ, has been circulated in MyÃ¶s Finland, at least on the Overboard discussion board. On the top of the board, the video is about civilian casualties in Ukraine, and for example, in an early February release, the video revealed a corona scam.
Venã¤jã¤ Spreading a new kind of propaganda
By early March, ProPublica, an independent US investigative journalism agency, was in collaboration with Clemson University researchers to publish dozens of propaganda videos supporting Ukrainian propaganda, showing through “fact-checking” the activities of Ukrainians. Elyâ.
One example of this is the presentation of an expression video taken out of context. With the help of similar videos, Venã¤jã¤ therefore suggests that Ukraine has lied about something, when in reality Venã¤jã¤ itself has put the lie in motion in order to be able to blame it on Ukraine.
The leaked exposé videos have gained immense popularity on Telegram and Twitter, among others. According to ProPublica, a screenshot of the âexposé videosâ has been shown on MyÃ¶s VenÃ¤jã¤n state television.
The objective of the purposely published exposé videos is to make sure that the next time they have to do it.  When, for example, photos of the Venã¤s destroyed by Ukraine online, they will determine whether the images are authentic. The goal of venã¤jã¤n disinformation is to motivate recipients by eroding trust in the transmission of information and creating alternative explanations for the events.
The Venã¤llã¤ Venã¤llã¤s in the dark about the correct course of the war and sowing fear of the Venã¤jã¤ regime seeks, for example, the will of its soldiers to fight and the will to fight on the part of the Venã¤, The people of the country came out in great masses to show their minds in the streets
Produced in school classes
Students split into groups and check what the foreign-language video is all about.
This link is provided by the TwitteristÃ¤ link to the climate change video presented in the context of the TwitteristÃ¤. The German-language video has been shared on social media, saying that civilian victims of the war in Ukraine have been brought to life in the video.
What's really going on with the video? Students try to check the facts with a Google search by doing an image search of the video. What are the keywords you can use to check the video? How can I find an image search?
Finally, the video in German can be subtitled in Finnish using the presented tools.
For teachers: You can check the video using Google's search engine, for example, with the search words “fact check ukraine bodiesâ or âfact check ukraine civiliansâ (without quotation marks”). The search terms are used to provide a number of fact-checks on the video in question, such as the Reuters verification.
Perform an image search of the video, make several fact-checks of the video, including the original video.

title: CNNi: Fake videos in service of anti-Ukraine propaganda
author: Newsroom
description: CNNi reveals two such examples of fabricated videos being trafficked on social media #CNNgrNews
text:
CNNi: Fake videos in service of anti-Ukraine propaganda
The propaganda war goes through the use of fake news. CNNi and journalist Daniel Dale reveal how two videos that have gone viral in relation to the war in Ukraine are completely fabricated.
These videos have been shared by social media accounts that essentially support Russian propaganda. As part of this, false material is used in order to “prove” that information and images transmitted from the battlefield are lies.
However, the real lie lies in the fabricated videos used to support the theories of the supporters of the attackers.
CNNi reveals two such examples: one video, while actually originating from a Climate Change protest in Vienna, is “placed” in Ukraine.
The journalist - who because of the mask he is wearing is not aware of what language he is speaking - stands in front of bags where bodies are placed. However, at the Climate Change protest inside the bags were activists. In the video one of the bags is opened and the activist is seen moving. He's obviously not dead. But for social media trolls, it's a Ukrainian who makes the dead man and so... they uncovered the Ukrainian scam!
The video has been constructed so that the audio and text at the bottom of the screen “matches” the fake “script”. These figures are taken from a report by an American correspondent in Ukraine that aired on NBC.
The second video that the CNNi investigation reveals is being used as propaganda material against Ukraine comes from the shooting of a 2013 British science fiction film. Social media accounts circulating it in recent days claim that it is Ukrainian actors playing the terrified civilians in the war...

text:
Disinformation is an important weapon in this war. Help us to deactivate it. Send us your questions to our WhatsApp channel: (+34) 648434618.
What do we verify?
An alleged “corpse” that moves discovers the deception of a television news report that shows false fatalities of Russian attacks in Ukraine.
Conclusion
The people lying on the ground are demonstrators against climate change in Austria, not false victims of the war in Ukraine, and the labels on the news have been manipulated.
The video apparently discovering the manipulation of a television news program to pass off living people as fatalities of the Russian Army has nothing to do with Ukraine and actually shows the television coverage of a climate change protest that took place in Vienna in early February.
EFE Verifica has received a question on its WhatsApp channel about a video where a journalist is seen reporting in English on the number of victims of the war in Ukraine before bags of bodies arranged in rows on the floor and, suddenly, one of the bodies begins to move under the bag that covers him.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/victimas-ucrania-informativo-falso.jpg?resize=551%2C457&ssl=1)
The video, widely shared on social networks, shows how the wind threatens to reveal the body covered with the bag and, to avoid this, the person lying under it moves and even requires the help of another to position itself correctly.
“A montage made by the Ukrainian government for the world media that went wrong”, states in its publication one of the profiles that broadcast the journalist's intervention to show that the video discovers a deception to make living people pass as fatalities of the Russian Army.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/rotulo-video-victimas-ucrania.jpg?resize=642%2C389&ssl=1)
In some of the publications of the video on networks, the images show a sign with figures from the Ukrainian Ministry of Health about victims of the war (“57 dead, 169 injured...”) and the audio with the voice of a journalist also refers in English to those killed and injured by the Russian attack. This can also be seen in another video published on YouTube.
THEY ARE ACTIVISTS OF A CLIMATE PROTEST IN VIENNA
In reality, the journalist who appears in the video does not report about the victims in Ukraine, but about a protest organized by Fridays For Future in Vienna, and it is activists of this movement against climate change who can be seen lying on the ground behind the reporter, as can be seen in a YouTube post by the Austrian television channel OE24.TV.
A reverse search for images on Google leads to the chronicle in German by journalist Marvin Bergauer about a protest organized by this movement on February 4, 2022 against the increase in carbon emissions in Austria.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/victima-ucrania-television-protesta-clima.jpg?resize=764%2C524&ssl=1)
Based on a study published in the scientific journal Nature, Fridays For Future denounced with this protest that not reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Austria “would cost the lives of 49 people every day”, as could be read on their official Twitter profile on February 4.
Hence, the participants in this protest act lay on the floor and covered with plastic as if they were “corpses” in front of the headquarters of the Austrian Federal Chancellery, in protest against what they considered a breach of the Austrian Government's climate commitments. This was explained on Twitter together with a photograph that coincides with the place and time of the television broadcast.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/victimas-ucrania-informativo-television-twitter.jpg?resize=537%2C716&ssl=1)
In fact, in the original video, you can see some demonstrators standing, dressed in black, with hoodies and scythes, in a clear allegory of death, holding two banners with the same slogans, in German, that can be seen in the photograph published by Fridays For Future: “The climate protection law saves lives” and “Current climate policy does not”.
In information from the Austrian media outlet Der Standard, which shares the environmental movement, activists denounce that “Austria's climate protection law has been pending for 400 days” and the Government of this country still lacks a clear policy on how to achieve the expected reduction in polluting emissions.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/victima-ucrania-television-protesta-clima-plano.jpg?resize=763%2C485&ssl=1)
THE SIGN AND THE VOICE CORRESPOND TO ANOTHER NEWSLETTER
Therefore, neither the label nor the voice in English that appear in the video difun Dido on social networks correspond to the original Austrian television news.
In fact, that phrase in English and that label with the data of deaths and injuries reported by the Ukrainian Ministry of Health belong to a chronicle for the American channel NBC News by journalist Cal Perry in which it was stated that 57 people had died and 169 had been injured as a result of the Russian attack on Ukraine.
Thus, the results in the Google search engine for the information that appears in the text lead to the video published by NBC NEWS reporting in English on Russian attacks on Ukrainian territory.
! [] (https://i0.wp.com/verifica.efe.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/montaje-victimas-ucrania-covid-video.jpg?resize=1024%2C653&ssl=1)
It was also used to QUESTION the pandemic
It also happens that the same viral video now out of context on the occasion of the war in Ukraine had already been presented by various profiles on social networks as if it were a montage to make people believe in false fatalities of Covid-19. To this end, there were publications that made fun of the alleged dead man who was moving under the plastic bag and defined the scene as a “miracle of pandemic change”.
Even then, it was possible to see how the journalist in the video explained in German that it was a protest organized by Fridays For Future and how the label, written in that language, indicated: “Vienna: demonstration against climate policy”.
And, in the post he shared on Twitter on February 4, that environmental movement specified that 50 activists had pretended to be “dead” in front of the Federal Chancellery to symbolize those who died prematurely due to the climate crisis.
As in this case, since the beginning of the war in Ukraine, EFE Verifica has demonstrated the falsehood of numerous publications attributed to this crisis and also, on the contrary, how some images questioned on social networks and presented as supposedly unrelated to the conflict did reflect real events of the war.
In short, the viral television broadcast on networks is not a montage to deceive people into believing in the existence of fatalities of the war (or of the coronavirus), but rather a journalistic chronicle of a protest in Vienna by the Fridays For Future movement against Austrian climate policy.
SOURCES:
Reverse image search on Google.
Original video about the Fridays For Future climate protest on the OE24.TV YouTube channel.
Information from the television channel NBC NEWS: “At least 57 dead and 169 injured after Russian attack on Ukraine”.
Article from the Austrian media Der Standard: “Climate activists protest at Heldenplatz: There is no climate protection law for 400 days”.

title: “Fake corpses” in Poland or the climate change protest in Vienna? - What does the video show? | Mythdetector.com
author: Myth Detector
description: On March 1, Facebook user Liudmila Jecheva Andonova posted a video in which, during a live broadcast of the journalist, you can see people behind him
text:
On March 1, Facebook user Liudmila Jecheva Andonova posted a video showing people wrapped in black bags behind the journalist's back. One of them opens the bag, after which the girl comes running to it and covers the black bag again. The author of the post claims that a video about the humanitarian disaster in Ukraine is being shot in Poland using false corpses.
As of March 4, Liudmila Jecheva Andonova's post has been shared more than 1,000 times. The post was later shared on the following Facebook groups: Russian Canada-Russian Canada, Estonian Fraudsters, Estonian News, Nash Lasnamäe.
The video is distributed with a fake description and does not reflect footage shot to illustrate the humanitarian catastrophe in Ukraine, but a performance held in Austria on February 4 in protest against climate policy. By creating imitations of corpses, activists emphasize that the release of large amounts of carbon dioxide will eventually lead to human casualties. A similar video was distributed in Georgia with a false description to deny the pandemic even before Russia attacked Ukraine.
The video, posted by Liudmila user Jecheva Andonova, was not shot in Poland to demonstrate the humanitarian disaster in Ukraine. The video was shot even before the start of the Russian-Ukrainian war, on February 4 in Austria and reflects a protest over climate policy.
This video was tested by Myth Detector in February, when Georgian-speaking Facebook users used the footage to illustrate a simulation of deaths from Covid.
As a result of the audit, it turned out that the authentic video was shot in the Austrian capital Vienna and the story belongs to the Austrian television station OE24tv. According to an article published on oe24.at, activists performed outside the Federal Chancellery on February 4. The performance included an imitation of 49 corpses wrapped in black bags. Performance participants referred to an international study according to which every 4,000 tons of CO2 leads to the death of 1 person, which means 49 deaths in Austria by 2100, and that corpses were used for climate-related performance.
The video is cut in such a way that the credits are not fully visible; only the journalist's first and last names are read. Part of the video showing protesters holding banners was also cut out. One of the banners says “AKTUELL KLIMAPOLITIK NICHT”, which means “No to existing climate policy” in Russian.
Consequently, the information disseminated is a video manipulation and its description is fake.
Read the Myth Detector article in detail on this topic:
A “restless corpse” or a protest over the climate?
This article was prepared as part of the Facebook Fact-Check Program, based on materials on which Facebook may use various restrictions based on this article. Please see this link for the relevant information. Information about our assessment, appeal or correction is available here.
See detailed instructions for correcting the material.

title: The Bizarre But Absolutely True Story Of A Woman Who Birthed 69 Babies
author: Mel Johnson
description: The Guinness World Record for most children born to 1 mom goes to the wife of Russian peasant Feodor Vassilyev. She birthed 69 babies in her lifetime. Here's the bizarre but true story.
text:
The Bizarre But Absolutely True Story Of A Woman Who Birthed 69 Babies
October 02, 2023
![The Bizarre But Absolutely True Story Of A Woman Who Birthed 69 Babies](https://i.swncdn.com/cdn/904w/godtube/godupdates/godupdates-69-babies-birthed-by-1-woman-world-record-fb.jpg)
The Guinness World Record for most children born to 1 mom goes to the wife of Russian peasant Feodor Vassilyev. She birthed 69 babies total in her lifetime! It sounds unbelievable. But here's her bizarre, yet true story.
When Michelle Duggar had 17 kids, her family got their own TV show: 17 Kids And Counting. Of course, then it became 19 Kids And Counting after Michelle birthed two more babies. But as it turns out, the modern-day Duggars have nothing on the 18th-century Russian Vassilyevs.
RELATED: 65-Year-Old Mother Of 13 Decides To Get Pregnant, Then Gives Birth To Quadruplets
History records Feodor Vassilyev as a farmer in Shuya, Russia during the 1700's. But it's his wife who caught the attention of the Guinness Book of World Records. She's recognized as the most prolific mother ever after birthing 69 babies, snagging the world record for most children born to one mother.
There's some question as to whether or not Mrs. Vassilyev's real name is known, but some sources call her Valentina. And it's reported that between the years of 1725 to 1765, she gave birth to four sets of quadruplets, seven sets of triplets, and 16 pairs of twins. That's 69 babies total, with 67 living beyond infancy!
The Math Behind 1 Mom And 69 Babies
4 x 4 = 16
7 x 3 = 21
16 x 2 = 32
----------
27 births, 69 children
Guinness Records Specialists do suggest taking the exact number of babies with a grain of salt, given that 18th-century Russian record keeping could be off just a bit. However, they also point out that these numbers, while extreme, are actually in the realm of possibility.
Let's take another look at the Duggars as a modern-day comparison.
A Rare, Yet Probable Case
The Duggars had their first child in 1988 when Michelle would have been 21. Soon after, Michelle had a miscarriage where the couple feared birth control may have played a role. That's when the Christian couple abandoned birth control altogether and completely surrendered to the will of God. They decided to let Him determine their number of children.
Michelle Duggar gave birth 17 times (twice with twins) over a period of 21 and a half years. So, considering the likelihood that Valentina was even younger when she began bearing children, it's possible she could have had 27 pregnancies during her fertile years.
Researchers also point to the possibility that Valentina may have had a genetic predisposition for hyperovulation. This is where a woman releases multiple eggs in one cycle, greatly increasing the odds of multiples.
Valentina's 27 pregnancies is certainly incredible. But as an equally interesting side note, her husband, Feodor, went on to have even more children!
RELATED: 15 Bizarre Stories That Couldn’t Possibly Be True (But Absolutely Are)
Records say Feodor later remarried. And his second wife gave birth to six pairs of twins and two sets of triplets, making for 18 children in 8 pregnancies. That means Feodor fathered 87 children total in his lifetime!
18-Century Documents Supporting The World Record
Indeed, this was considered a jaw-dropping feat even then and supposedly the Monastery of Nikolsk reported it to the Moscow government in 1782. And when the French Academy looked into the authenticity, supposedly the Imperial Academy of St. Petersburg told them no verification was needed. Apparently, the sons and daughters of the Vassilyevs lived in Moscow and received government assistance to help support the huge family.
Sadly, these records did not include any confirmed photographs of the Vassilyev family. The photograph included in this article began circulating with this bizarre story, but no one has been able to confirm it actually depicts Feodor, Valentina, and their children. Instead, it serves as an illustrative example only.
Throughout the years, another photograph became affiliated with this story by mistake.
However, the black and white photograph is actually of Joseph F. Smith from an article about polygamy published in the Utah Historical Quarterly.
YOU MAY ALSO LIKE: Joanna Gaines Opens Up About The Gift Of Her Unexpected Pregnancy
The story of Valentina's 69 babies is certainly mind-blowing. But God has certainly designed the human body to do incredible things and all things are possible through Him!

h/t: Guinness World Records / Mental Floss
Featured Image Credit: Facebook/Anything Goes
Mel is the senior writer for GodUpdates, finding, writing and sharing Christian, uplifting, and health-related stories from around the world. Mel has a passion for writing and graduated with a degree in English from Randolph-Macon College in Virginia. When she’s not researching a nd writing stories, Mel is very active in her church. You can usually find Mel playing board games with her husband and two young girls, giving someone a hug, or hunting down a good cup of coffee!

text: Family Legend - Valentina Vassilyeva from Russia had 69...

title: The Astonishing But True Story Of A Woman Who Birthed 69 Babies - Jesus Daily
author: Dr Aaron Tabor; MD
description: The Guinness World Record for most children born to 1 mother goes to a woman with 69 babies. This is her bizarre but true story.
text:
The Guinness World Record for most children born to one mother goes to Valentina Vassilyev, the wife of a Russian peasant Feodor Vassilyev. She birthed 69 babies total in her lifetime. She lived to be 76 and, between 1725 and 1765, had 69 children (16 pairs of twins, 7 sets of triplets and 4 sets of quadruplets) 67 of them survived infancy with the loss of one set of twins.
History records Feodor Vassilyev as a farmer in Shuya, Russia during the 1700’s. But it’s his wife who caught the attention of the Guinness Book of World Records. Valentina is recognized as the most prolific mother ever after birthing 69 babies, snagging the world record for most children born to one mother.
The Math Behind 1 Mom And 69 Babies
4 x 4 = 16
7 x 3 = 21
16 x 2 = 32
———-
27 births, 69 children
The first published account about Feodor Vassilyev’s children appeared in a 1783 issue of The Gentleman’s Magazine (Vol. 53 p. 753, London, 1783) and states that the information “however astonishing, may be depended upon, as it came directly from an English merchant in St Petersburg to his relatives in England, who added that the peasant was to be introduced to the Empress”. The same numbers were given in Ivan Nikitich Boltin’s 1788 commentary on Russian history and in an 1834 book by Alexander Pavlovich Bashutskiy, Saint Petersburg Panorama.
Several published sources raised doubts as to the veracity of these claims. According to a 1933 article by Julia Bell in Biometrika, a 1790 book of B. F. J. Hermann Statistische Schilderung von Rußland did provide the claims about Feodor Vassilyev’s children but “with a caution”. Bell also notes that the case was reported by The Lancet in an 1878 article about the study of twins. The Lancet article states that the French Academy of Sciences attempted to verify the claims about Vassilyev’s children and contacted “M. Khanikoff of the Imperial Academy of St Petersburg for advice as to the means they should pursue, but were told by him that all investigation was superfluous, that members of the family still lived in Moscow and that they had been the object of favors from the Government”.
Bell concludes that Vassilyev’s case “must be regarded as under suspicion”. Similarly, Marie Clay in a 1998 book notes: “Sadly, this evasion of proper investigation seems, in retrospect, to have dealt a terminal blow to our chances of ever establishing the true detail of this extraordinary case”.
The data about Vassilyev’s children are included in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Valentina’s 27 pregnancies is certainly incredible. But as an equally interesting side note, her husband, Feodor, went on to have even more children.
Vassilyev also had 18 children with his second wife, who had 6 pairs of twins and 2 sets of triplets, making him a father of 87 children in total. Of his 87 children, at least 82 are said to have survived infancy.
Sadly, there is no confirmed photographs of the Vassilyev family. The photograph included in this article began circulating with this bizarre story, but no one has been able to confirm it actually depicts Feodor, Valentina, and their children. Instead, it serves as an illustrative example only.
Although this historic record for the most kids by one woman should be taken with a pinch of salt, it is certainly conceivable that Mrs Vassilyev could have had a genetic predisposition to hyper-ovulate (release multiple eggs in one cycle), which significantly increases the chance of having twins or multiple children.
It is also not impossible for a woman to have 27 pregnancies during her fertile years.
Please share this astonishing story with your friends!

———-
27 births, 69 children
The first published account about Feodor Vassilyev’s children appeared in a 1783 issue of The Gentleman’s Magazine (Vol. 53 p. 753, London, 1783) and states that the information “however astonishing, may be depended upon, as it came directly from an English merchant in St Petersburg to his relatives in England, who added that the peasant was to be introduced to the Empress”. The same numbers were given in Ivan Nikitich Boltin’s 1788 commentary on Russian history and in an 1834 book by Alexander Pavlovich Bashutskiy, Saint Petersburg Panorama.
Several published sources raised doubts as to the veracity of these claims. According to a 1933 article by Julia Bell in Biometrika, a 1790 book of B. F. J. Hermann Statistische Schilderung von Rußland did provide the claims about Feodor Vassilyev’s children but “with a caution”. Bell also notes that the case was reported by The Lancet in an 1878 article about the study of twins. The Lancet article states that the French Academy of Sciences attempted to verify the claims about Vassilyev’s children and contacted “M. Khanikoff of the Imperial Academy of St Petersburg for advice as to the means they should pursue, but were told by him that all investigation was superfluous, that members of the family still lived in Moscow and that they had been the object of favors from the Government”.
Bell concludes that Vassilyev’s case “must be regarded as under suspicion”. Similarly, Marie Clay in a 1998 book notes: “Sadly, this evasion of proper investigation seems, in retrospect, to have dealt a terminal blow to our chances of ever establishing the true detail of this extraordinary case”.
The data about Vassilyev’s children are included in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Valentina’s 27 pregnancies is certainly incredible. But as an equally interesting side note, her husband, Feodor, went on to have even more children.
Vassilyev also had 18 children with his second wife, who had 6 pairs of twins and 2 sets of triplets, making him a father of 87 children in total. Of his 87 children, at least 82 are said to have survived infancy.
Story Continues Below

Powr
Sadly, there is no confirmed photographs of the Vassilyev family. The photograph included in this article began circulating with this bizarre story, but no one has been able to confirm it actually depicts Feodor, Valentina, and their children. Instead, it serves as an illustrative example only.
Although this historic record for the most kids by one woman should be taken with a pinch of salt, it is certainly conceivable that Mrs Vassilyev could have had a genetic predisposition to hyper-ovulate (release multiple eggs in one cycle), which significantly increases the chance of having twins or multiple children.
It is also not impossible for a woman to have 27 pregnancies during her fertile years.

title: Fascinating Mothers From Around The World
author: Tejas Morey
text:
Published: May 09, 2013, 11:59 IST Updated: May 16, 2013, 06:51 IST
Fascinating Mothers From Around The World
You’re reading this because your mother chose to bring you into the world. Giving birth is a miracle, one of the most under-acknowledged feats ever. As we gear up for mother’s day, MensXP take a look at few of these miracles that have defied t
1. Oldest Mother In The WorldThe honor for the oldest mother in the world goes to a 70-year-old Indian, Omkari Singh. In spite of having two daughters and five grand-children, the
__READMORE__Singhs were keen on having a baby boy and they achieved it through vitro-fertilization. Singh fgave birth to twins, a boy and a girl by Caesarean section. The doctors are confident that the healthy babies will survive despite their mother’s old age. (Image Credit: lindaikeji (dot) blogspot (dot) com)
2. Youngest Mother In The WorldThe tragic conception of a baby to a 5-year-old is a disheartening fact. This case came into the limelight on May 14,
__READMORE__1933, when 5 year and 7 month old Lina Medina of Peru got pregnant. She gave birth to a 2.64 kg healthy baby in her hometown. The child was delivered by the Caesarean section and was reported to be healthy enough to survive. Her father was arrested under suspicion of raping her but was released due to lack of evidence. The father’s identity remained a mystery. (Image Credit: 4 (dot) bp (dot) blogspot (dot) com)
3. Mother With The Most BabiesThe official record of a mother for having the most babies throughout a lifetime is held by Russia’s Feodor Vassilyev. Feodor had 27 different
__READMORE__conceptions, and gave birth to 69 babies! Born in 1707, Feodor and her husband raised 67 children who survived, while only two failed to survive their infancy. Feodor achieved this feat by giving birth to 16 pairs of twins, seven sets of triplets and four sets of quadruplets. Simply fascinating! (Image Credit: temmais (dot) com)
4. Most Multiples Born To A MotherThe highest number of babies born to a mother at one time were nonuplets - a set of nine children. This has been recorded twice in human history, in
__READMORE__1971 and 1999, albeit none of the babies survived during both the instances. Fascinatingly, the most successful conception took place in 2009, when Nadya Suleman gave birth to two healthy boys and six girls in California, United States. These octuplets were conceived by in vitro fertilization and survived infancy! (Image Credit: ssheltonimages (dot) com)
5. Most Children Born To A Surrogate MotherSurrogacy is a boon in itself. And Carole Horlock is at the top of the good Karma list when she gave birth to 13 babies in her 13-year surrogate career. Not just
__READMORE__that, she was capable of conceiving a set of triplets for a Greek couple in 2008. This fascinating surrogate mom finally quit after the thirteenth delivery. Talk about good deeds! (Image Credit: dailymail (dot) co (dot) uk)

title: Woman has 69 kids in 76 years
author: Author FACE
description: The Guinness World Record for most children born to one mother goes to Valentina Vassilyev, the wife of a Russian peasant . She birthed 69 babies total in her l
text:
The Guinness World Record for most children born to one mother goes to Valentina Vassilyev, the wife of a Russian peasant . She birthed 69 babies total in her lifetime.
She lived to be 76 and, between 1725 and 1765, had 69 children (16 pairs of twins, 7 sets of triplets and 4 sets of quadruplets) 67 of them survived infancy with the loss of one set of twins.
History records Feodor Vassilyev as a farmer in Shuya, Russia during the 1700’s. But it’s his wife who caught the attention of the Guinness Book of World Records. Valentina is recognized as the most prolific mother ever after birthing 69 babies, snagging the world record for most children born to one mother.
The Math Behind 1 Mom And 69 Babies
4 x 4 = 16
7 x 3 = 21
16 x 2 = 32
———-
27 births, 69 children
The first published account about Feodor Vassilyev’s children appeared in a 1783 issue of The Gentleman’s Magazine (Vol. 53 p. 753, London, 1783) and states that the information “however astonishing, may be depended upon, as it came directly from an English merchant in St Petersburg to his relatives in England, who added that the peasant was to be introduced to the Empress”. The same numbers were given in Ivan Nikitich Boltin’s 1788 commentary on Russian history and in an 1834 book by Alexander Pavlovich Bashutskiy, Saint Petersburg Panorama.
Several published sources raised doubts as to the veracity of these claims. According to a 1933 article by Julia Bell in Biometrika, a 1790 book of B. F. J. Hermann Statistische Schilderung von Rußland did provide the claims about Feodor Vassilyev’s children but “with a caution”. Bell also notes that the case was reported by The Lancet in an 1878 article about the study of twins. The Lancet article states that the French Academy of Sciences attempted to verify the claims about Vassilyev’s children and contacted “M. Khanikoff of the Imperial Academy of St Petersburg for advice as to the means they should pursue, but were told by him that all investigation was superfluous, that members of the family still lived in Moscow and that they had been the object of favors from the Government”.
The data about Vassilyev’s children are included in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Valentina’s 27 pregnancies is certainly incredible. But as an equally interesting side note, her husband, Feodor, went on to have even more children.
Vassilyev also had 18 children with his second wife, who had 6 pairs of twins and 2 sets of triplets, making him a father of 87 children in total. Of his 87 children, at least 82 are said to have survived infancy.
Sadly, there is no confirmed photographs of the Vassilyev family. The photograph included in this article began circulating with this bizarre story, but no one has been able to confirm it actually depicts Feodor, Valentina, and their children. Instead, it serves as an illustrative example only.
Although this historic record for the most kids by one woman should be taken with a pinch of salt, it is certainly conceivable that Mrs Vassilyev could have had a genetic predisposition to hyper-ovulate (release multiple eggs in one cycle), which significantly increases the chance of having twins or multiple children.

title: Kiev's battle zone: interactive before and after photos
author: L Analysis by Laura Tingle
description: Explore our interactive before and after photos to see how protests have turned the centre of the Ukrainian capital into a battle zone.
text:
Ukraine protests: Before and after photos from Kiev's battle zone
Fresh violence has erupted this week in the Ukrainian capital Kiev, where anti-government protesters have been occupying the centre of the city for almost three months.
Click or tap our five interactive photos to see how the protests have turned the city's Independence Square into a battle zone.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
The protests started late in 2013 after Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych spurned a European trade and political deal and instead sealed a $15 billion bailout from Russia.
They have since transformed into a broader protest movement, with demonstrators calling for the president to resign over claims of corruption and his close ties to Russia.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
Protesters armed with rocks, petrol bombs, bricks - and some with guns - have been fighting running battles with riot police, who replied with water canons, stun grenades and rubber bullets.
At least 26 people have been killed in fighting on Kiev's streets, 10 of them police officers.
Mr Yanukovych now says he has agreed to a "truce" with opposition leaders and a start to negotiations to prevent further bloodshed.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
The Ukrainian crisis is also becoming a new fault line between Russia and the West, as Russian president Vladimir Putin seeks to re-assert his country's influence over former Soviet republics.
Russia says the world is witnessing a fascist coup, with foreign minister Sergei Lavrov blaming the West for encouraging opposition radicals "to act outside of the law".
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
United States president Barack Obama has said the US is "watching very carefully".
"We expect the Ukrainian government to show restraint, to not resort to violence in dealing with peaceful protesters. There will be consequences if people step over the line."
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
Russia analyst and author Ben Judah says Ukraine is teetering on the edge of not only an economic abyss but also civil war.
"History is littered with protest movements that once had the most peaceful intentions that turned bloody, of shootings in cities in multi-ethnic countries, even though nobody wanted it, it managed to spiral into confrontations.
"Currently a full-scale war is unlikely to break out but what seems to have happened is that with these shootings, regions in western Ukraine and regions in southern Ukraine that are supportive of Russia are no longer fully responding to the government's orders and it's going to be very hard to put Ukraine fully together again, whatever happens, without one region or another refusing to take orders from a central government."
Credits
- Reporting/Production: Tim Leslie, Matthew Liddy
- Design/Photo post-production: Ben Spraggon
- Development: Simon Elvery
image_caption: Looking at the centrepiece statue in Kiev's Independence Square. / An aerial view shows Independence Square during clashes between anti-government protesters and Interior Ministry members and riot police in central Kiev February 19, 2014. Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovich warned his opponents on Wednesday that he could deploy force against them after what he called their attempt to "seize power" by means of "arson and murder".;

title: 26 Unbelievable Photos From The Battered Heart Of Ukraine
author: Michael B Kelley; Paul Szoldra
description: Jarring images from the burning streets of Kiev.
text:
26 Unbelievable Photos From The Battered Heart Of Ukraine
The European Union has called an extraordinary meeting of the bloc's 28 foreign ministers to discuss the ongoing crisis in Ukraine. Sanctions "against those responsible for violence and use of excessive force" are expected.
Anti-government protests in Ukraine reached their most violent point on Tuesday as at least 25 people were killed and hundreds injured amid violent clashes between police and citizens.
The protests have evolved into a full-blown crisis on the ground. What happens now is critical to the geopolitical struggle between Russia and the West.
The crisis began on November 21, 2013, when Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych snubbed a plan to sign an Association Agreement and trade pact with the EU after Russia persuaded the most populous former Soviet republic to stay in the Kremlin's orbit.
Citizens subsequently flooded the streets and made Independence Square, aka Maidan, their base in central Kiev. The confrontations between the opposition and Yanukovych's government have been escalating since.
On Wednesday, people poured back into Maidan to prepare for fresh clashes with police. (Here's a Maidan live stream.)
From riot police using ancient military tactics to defend against attacks to streets engulfed in flames, the photos coming for the heart of the standoff are incredible.

Ukrainian riot police advanced on Tuesday onto a central Kiev square occupied by protesters, after at least 14 people died in the worst day of violence since demonstrations erupted against President Viktor Yanukovich 12 weeks ago.

title: Kiev's battle zone: interactive before and after photos
author: L Analysis by Laura Tingle
description: Explore our interactive before and after photos to see how protests have turned the centre of the Ukrainian capital into a battle zone.
text:
Ukraine protests: Before and after photos from Kiev's battle zone
Fresh violence has erupted this week in the Ukrainian capital Kiev, where anti-government protesters have been occupying the centre of the city for almost three months.
Click or tap our five interactive photos to see how the protests have turned the city's Independence Square into a battle zone.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
The protests started late in 2013 after Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych spurned a European trade and political deal and instead sealed a $15 billion bailout from Russia.
They have since transformed into a broader protest movement, with demonstrators calling for the president to resign over claims of corruption and his close ties to Russia.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
Protesters armed with rocks, petrol bombs, bricks - and some with guns - have been fighting running battles with riot police, who replied with water canons, stun grenades and rubber bullets.
At least 26 people have been killed in fighting on Kiev's streets, 10 of them police officers.
Mr Yanukovych now says he has agreed to a "truce" with opposition leaders and a start to negotiations to prevent further bloodshed.
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
The Ukrainian crisis is also becoming a new fault line between Russia and the West, as Russian president Vladimir Putin seeks to re-assert his country's influence over former Soviet republics.
Russia says the world is witnessing a fascist coup, with foreign minister Sergei Lavrov blaming the West for encouraging opposition radicals "to act outside of the law".
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
United States president Barack Obama has said the US is "watching very carefully".
"We expect the Ukrainian government to show restraint, to not resort to violence in dealing with peaceful protesters. There will be consequences if people step over the line."
Before:
After:Toggle before/after image
Russia analyst and author Ben Judah says Ukraine is teetering on the edge of not only an economic abyss but also civil war.
"History is littered with protest movements that once had the most peaceful intentions that turned bloody, of shootings in cities in multi-ethnic countries, even though nobody wanted it, it managed to spiral into confrontations.
"Currently a full-scale war is unlikely to break out but what seems to have happened is that with these shootings, regions in western Ukraine and regions in southern Ukraine that are supportive of Russia are no longer fully responding to the government's orders and it's going to be very hard to put Ukraine fully together again, whatever happens, without one region or another refusing to take orders from a central government."
Credits
- Reporting/Production: Tim Leslie, Matthew Liddy
- Design/Photo post-production: Ben Spraggon
- Development: Simon Elvery

title: 2014 photo is shared as Kyiv’s Independence Square after the Russian invasion of Ukraine - FACTLY
author: Dilip Kumar Sripada
description: 2014 photo is being shared as picture of Kyiv’s Independence Square after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
text:
A collage of images is being shared on social media claiming it as the before and after pictures of the Independence Square in Kyiv, Ukraine after the Russian invasion. Let’s verify the claim made in the post.
![](https://factly.in/wp-content/uploads//2022/02/Before-and-after-Russian-invasion-pictures-at-Indpendence-Square-in-Ukraine-Claim.jpg)
Claim: Before and after pictures of the Independence Square in Kyiv, Ukraine after the Russian invasion.
Fact: The second photo shared in the post was taken in 2014 when violent clashes erupted between the anti-government forces and Ukraine Security forces in Kyiv. The picture shared in the post is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine. Hence, the post shared in the post is MISLEADING.
On reverse image search of the second photo shared in the post, a similar photo was found in an article published by the ‘ABC’ news website on 20 February 2014. According to the article, in February 2014, violent clashes erupted between the anti-government protestors and Ukraine Security forces in Kyiv, the Capital city of Ukraine. These protests reportedly started in 2013 after the then Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych spurned a European trade and political deal and instead sealed a $15 billion bailout from Russia. Several demonstrators and Police reportedly lost their lives in these violent clashes that took place in Kyiv. The photo shared in the post shows the International Square (also called Maidan Square) after the Kyiv riots in 2014.
![](https://factly.in/wp-content/uploads//2022/02/Before-and-after-Russian-invasion-pictures-at-Indpendence-Square-in-Ukraine-Image-1.jpg)
Reporting the same, several news websites have published articles in February 2014. They can be seen here, here, and here. Amie Ferris-Rotman, a journalist who worked in several international news organizations had compared pictures of Kyiv’s International Square before and after the violent riots similarly in 2014.
![](https://factly.in/wp-content/uploads//2022/02/Before-and-after-Russian-invasion-pictures-at-Indpendence-Square-in-Ukraine-Image-2.jpg)
The latest visuals of Kyiv’s Maidan Square after the Russian advance in Ukraine can be seen here. From all these pieces of evidence, it can be concluded that the image shared in the post is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine.
![](https://factly.in/wp-content/uploads//2022/02/Before-and-after-Russian-invasion-pictures-at-Indpendence-Square-in-Ukraine-Image-3.jpg)
To sum it up, a 2014 photo is being shared as the picture of Kyiv’s Independence Square after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

title: Times of crisis
author: Yannis Behrakis
description: Images of turmoil, injury and death have been flowing from Ukraine, a country shaken by its bloodiest unrest since Soviet times.
text:
Times of crisis
Images of turmoil, injury and death have been flowing from Ukraine, a country shaken by its bloodiest unrest since Soviet times.
Dozens have died in clashes between police and protesters, including a gun battle in the centre of Kiev, after some three months of anti-government demonstrations reached their deadliest pitch.
Hours of fierce fighting in Kiev's Independence Square, which was recaptured by anti-government protesters, left bodies strewn on the ground.
Riot police were captured on video shooting from a rooftop at demonstrators in the plaza.
Protesters hurled petrol bombs and paving stones to drive the security forces off a corner of the square the police had captured in battles that began on two days earlier.
Video of the clashes on the edge of the Kiev square also showed riot policemen firing bursts from automatic rifles on the run as they covered retreating colleagues. An opposition militant in a helmet was filmed firing from behind a tree.
In the image above, anti-government protesters detain a wounded policeman during the fighting in Independence Square.
Interior Minister Vitaly Zakharchenko said police had been issued with combat weapons and would use them "in accordance with the law" to defend themselves - or to free 67 of their colleagues his ministry said were being held captive.
Demonstrators said captured police had been allowed to go.
The bloodshed, in which both sides used firearms, traumatised many in the Ukraine, where a 2004-05 Orange Revolution for democracy passed off largely peacefully.
It also heightened concern voiced by Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk that Ukraine could descend into civil war or split between the pro-European west and Russian-speaking east.
In a bid to end the crisis, Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovich on February 21 signed an agreement with three opposition leaders.
The deal sets out plans to hold early presidential elections, form a national unity government and revert to the 2004 constitution, removing some of the presidentâs powers.
Slideshow
Anti-government protesters throw missiles during clashes with riot police in Independence Square.
A protester shoots an improvised device during fighting in the plaza.
Anti-government protesters carry an injured man on a stretcher as flames flare.

Two men, their faces covered with blood, are seen after clashes with riot police.
A wounded man lies in front of a barricade.
A woman covers her eyes in front of dead bodies lying on the ground.
An anti-government protester pays his respects to a fallen comrade.
Protesters prepare Molotov cocktails during clashes.
Demonstrators use a sling to fire objects at members of the Interior Ministry and riot police.
An anti-government protester stands behind his shield during the violence.
A protester aims a rifle during clashes with riot police.
A protester holds a Ukranian flag as he advances through burning barricades.
Another protesters rests, wrapped in a flag.
A medic cleans a protesterâs eyes.
Anti-government protesters listen to speeches by their leaders in Independence Square.
A man holds his dead sonâs hand as over a dozen corpses are transferred from a hotel lobby to a local hospital after clashes with riot police.
A priest performs the last rites on the body of an anti-government protester.
Rows of protesters sleep in Kievâs City Hall.
Smoke billows from Independence Square during clashes between protesters and police.

title: By the tracks of the 2013 revolution and the residence of the runaway president
description: The price includes transportation services, Finnish-guided tours, entrance tickets to the Mezhyhirya Residence, entrance tickets to Honka, an electric car tour and dinner at the restaurant. We begin our journey from Maydan – Kyiv main square and the 2013-2014 revolution centre. Our guide, who was the eyewitness of the historic moment, will share his memories of those shocking events. We stroll to the mysterious Chimaera House and the monumental presidential palace along the street, where in 2014 the demonstrators equipped only with wooden shields marched against the police’s bullets. After visiting the government quarter we travel out of the city to the residence of the former president, who fled during the revolution. It used to be the most secret place hidden behind the 5-metre walls heavily guarded by armed men with dogs. Nowadays it’s the Museum of Corruption. There was even a personal air defense system. Explore 137 hectares of parks and lakes on an electric car. There is everything you can imagine – the ship-restaurant, the heliport, the zoo, the collection of retro cars, golf court, fountains and SPAs – it was still not enough. The true gem of the residence is the masterpiece of Finnish design – Honka. It is a modern 600 square meter palace made of unique kelo wood. Walk the underground tunnel guarded by a stuffed lion and the knights, admire royal parquet flooring and wood engravings, hear the stories about the golden loaf and other stupid whims of the dictator. Our guide is a former demonstrator, who was among the first to enter the mansion and has been living there ever since. He committed himself to maintain and protect the house. Enjoy lunch at the roofed terrace on the canal bank.

title: BEFORE AND AFTER: Kiev's Independence Square
author: Michael B Kelley
description: From tourist center to warzone.
text:
Independence Square (aka Maidan) in central Kiev is the epicenter of an ongoing crisis in Ukraine.
Protesters have been camped out since December, defending Maidan against Russian-backed riot police and security forces loyal to Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. At least 26 people have died in the clashes over the past two days.
Here's what Independence Square looked like in September 2009 as compared to Wednesday morning:
Here's what the square looked like before dawn on Wednesday morning:
And here's a look at the no-man's land that has formed between anti-government protesters and police:

title: Old Image of Kyiv’s Independence Square Falsely Linked To Ongoing War in Ukraine
author: Aishwarya Varma
description: Two photos comparing Kyiv's Independence Square are being shared to claim that it shows its condition before and after the Russian invasion. But the second photo is from 2014 and shows anti-government protesters clashing with riot police in Ukraine.
text:
A set of two photographs showing Ukraine's Independence Square at Kyiv are being shared on social media, which purportedly show the condition of the square five days apart, on 20 February and 25 February. The first shows what the area looks like on a regular day, whereas the second one shows ash, fire, smoke and rubble surrounding it.
The photos are being shared claiming to show a damaged Independence Square in Kyiv on 25 February, a day after Russian forces started invading Ukraine.
However, the claim is misleading. We found that the second photo being shared as a recent visual of the damaged Independence Square is actually from 2014, when large scale anti-government protests erupted in the Ukrainian capital. Activists and protesters had set up camps and barricades around the city's square.
CLAIM
The photographs showing the Independence Square at Kyiv in Ukraine are being shared to claim that it shows the 'before' and 'after' situation of the area, a day after Russia announced Ukraine's invasion.
WHAT WE FOUND OUT
We ran a reverse image search on the photo of the damaged Square on Google, and the results led us to the same photo in articles by Canada's CBC News and The Atlantic. Both articles were published in February 2014 and discussed anti-government protests in Kyiv, Ukraine.
The photo's caption noted that it showed an "aerial view" of the Independence Square in Kyiv, "during clashes between anti-government protesters and riot police" on 19 February and credited it to Reuters' Olga Yakimovich.
Using relevant keywords, we looked for the photo on Reuters' website, which led us to the same photo as the claim, along with a description noting that it was taken on 19 February 2014.
The description said that the photo showed clashes between anti-government protesters and Interior Ministry members and riot police in central Kyiv, Ukraine.
We looked up news reports on the same for additional context.
A detailed explainer by CNN noted that the protests at Kyiv's Independence Square, also known as Maidan, erupted after former President Viktor Yanukovych suspended talks regarding a "historical political and trade agreement" with the European Union (EU). Russia had threatened Ukraine with sanctions and a hike in fuel rates if the agreement was signed.
Ukrainians were strongly in support of the EU agreement, and as the protests intensified, an anti-protest law was passed by the Ukrainian parliament, raising questions about curtailing people's right to free speech and protests.
This led to further escalations where the protesters occupied the area for three months, eventually leading to clashes between them and riot police.
WHAT ABOUT KYIV'S INDEPENDENCE SQUARE?
We looked for news reports on any damage to Kyiv's Independence Square but did not come across any. However, we found tweets from verified Ukrainian media outlets that showed recent visuals of the Square.
On 4 March, The Kyiv Independent tweeted photographs of anti-tank structures being placed around the Independence Square.
We also came across a photo of the Square, undamaged, dated 2 March, 2022 on Getty Images.
(Note: Swipe right to view both images.)
A photo taken on 2 March shows no damage to the area.
(Source: Getty Images/Screenshot)
Evidently, the Independence Square in Ukraine's Kyiv has not been affected by the Russian invasion as of 7 March 2022. The photo being shared to claim that the structure had been damaged by 25 February is actually from February 2014, when clashes broke out between anti-government protesters and riot police.
(Not convinced of a post or information you came across online and want it verified? Send us the details on WhatsApp at 9643651818, or e-mail it to us at webqoof@thequint.com and we'll fact-check it for you. You can also read all our fact-checked stories here.)
(At The Quint, we question everything. Play an active role in shaping our journalism by becoming a member today.)
