title: Italo-Abyssinian (Ethiopian) war in photography [gallery]
author: Roman Sidorsky
description: The Italian-Abyssinian War of 1935—1936 was part of the realization of Benito Mussolini's imperial and colonial ambitions. Press photos from this conflict show the glaring disproportion of the forces and means of the warring parties, the clash of cultures, as well as the hardships and cruelties of war.
text:
Abyssinian family (grandfather, father, sons) from Harar, going to the Italian border, after the announced mobilization and recruitment into the army of men aged 14 to 40 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-126-7, public domain)
The Italian-Abyssinian War of 1935—1936 was part of the realization of Benito Mussolini's imperial and colonial ambitions. Press photos from this conflict show the glaring disproportion of the forces and means of the warring parties, the clash of cultures, as well as the hardships and cruelties of war.
Mobilization of the Abyssinians. Marching boys, with sticks and wooden rifle deposits instead of weapons, in the square in front of St. George's Church in Addis Ababa, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-126-10, public domain) One of the first female warriors to learn to shoot a rifle, 1935 (photo: National Archives Digital, ref. 1-E-126-16, public domain) Abyssinian warriors heading to the northern front, Addis Ababa, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-126-14, public domain) One of the veterans of the 1896 fighting with a Lebel rifle vol. 86/93 on his arm ( photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-126-15, public domain) Abyssinian family (grandfather, father, sons) from Harar, going to the Italian border, after the announced mobilization and conscription into the army of men aged 14 to 40 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-126-7, domn. The concentration of Italian troops in Somalia. Convoy of General Rodolfo Graziani, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-132, public domain) Concentration of Italian troops in Somalia. 75/27 C.K. anti-aircraft guns installed on the basis of Ceirano 50 CMA, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-131, public domain) Concentration of Italian troops in Somalia. Fortified positions of the Somali battalion, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-133, public domain) Troops of Italian soldiers arriving at the front in Eritrea, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-138-2, public domain) Italian artillery on the southern front captured by the Dubats, or Somali Riflemen, March 1936 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-163, public domain) Indigenous troops in Italian service. Visible Schwarzlose M.7/12 machine gun (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-158, public domain) Column of Italian CV 3/33 tankettes heading to the northern front (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-162, public domain) Unification of the civilian population. Food distribution in an Italian-occupied town, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-214, public domain) Abolition of slavery by Italians. An Italian officer with the assistance of a Somali gunner removes the shackles from the legs of an Abyssinian, Mekelie, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-212, public domain) Italian militia soldiers (black shirts) during a combat campaign in the town of Taga Taga, 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, sygn. 1-E-E-12) 138-4, public domain) Members of the Abyssinian and American Red Cross bring aid to victims of the Desje bombing, 1935 (photo National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-168, public domain) Abyssinian soldiers wounded by Italian bombing. On the left stands a member of the British Red Cross, April 1936 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-172, public domain) A soldier of an irregular Abyssinian detachment carries his wounded colleague on his back. November 1935 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-166, public domain) Italian soldiers build a road to rocky slope (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-153, public domain) Italian soldiers pull a two-wheeled mule-drawn wagon out of the mud (photo: National Digital Archive, sygn. 1-E-151, public domain) Transport inventory of Italian troops (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-146, public domain) Italian sappers during the construction of artesian wells (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-156, public domain) The camp of the Italian troops near Addis Ababa after the capture of the city. May 1936 (photo: National Digital Archive Sygn. 1-E-164. public domain) Italian occupation of Aksum. Marshal Emilio de Bono and his wife accept the tribute of the Coptic elders and clergy of Aksum and Adua, November 1935 (photo National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-140-1, public domain) Italian troops after entering Addis Ababa. Pietro Badoglio (3rd from left in the foreground) looks at the weapons captured on the enemy, 1936 (photo: National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-144-1, public domain) Italian troops after entering Addis Ababa. Pietro Badoglio occupies the airfield, 1936 (photo National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-144-2, public domain) Parades of Italian troops, including Somali Rifles, in Addis Ababa, May 1936 (photo National Digital Archive, ref. 1-E-199-1, public domain)
“Count Titus” is a popular science and educational website dedicated to the history of Poland and the world, with s Special attention to Greater Poland. Our goal is to tell stories in such a way that learning about them is pure pleasure and gives birth to the passion that we ourselves contracted years ago. At the same time, we want our portal to be a reliable source of knowledge that does not sacrifice reliability in favor of cheap sensation.

title: War fascinates when it is far away
author: Piotr Korczynski
text:
After the entry of the United States into World War I in 1917, Kodak began a special advertising campaign aimed at soldiers going to the front. In a catalogue encouraging the purchase of handheld cameras, it was written: “And when peace finally reigns, the war story you tell mothers, wives, sisters and children will become more vivid and real thanks to photographs.”
Imagine the brainstorming in Kodak's advertising office, during which the above text was created. Surely it was supposed to sound optimistic — hence the word “peace” and the promise of a happy return home, where veterans of the great war would sit among their families and would in the evenings, by the fireplace, tell about heroic deeds, showing women and children hand-made front photos of... Well, with what? What was really behind the slogan that the war would become “more expressive and more real” thanks to cameras?
Did the creators of this ad realize that in addition to group photos of comrades in arms, there would be those with the horrors of war, that soldiers would take pictures of the corpses of killed enemies with their own hands, the ruins of houses demolished by them, and even the execution of civilians suspected of spying? And they're going to treat them like war trophies? The answer to this question is not at all easy. Photographers have accompanied soldiers fighting at the front since the Crimean War, that is, since the middle of the 19th century, but technology stood in the way of capturing battle scenes — the first cameras were large and heavy boxes. So, most often static camp scenes and battlefields were photographed, that is, everything that happened before and after the battle. It wasn't until the introduction of lightweight and wearable cameras, such as Kodak advertised, that there was a real struggle in the pictures. In this way, people crossed another frontier of showing the bestiality of war.
On the antipodes, more is allowed
Just as important as technical progress was the fact that, according to the postulates of Kodak advertising, cameras were massively found in soldiers' backpacks. Their owners, most often unaware of both artistic and technical requirements and moral aspects, took pictures without self-censorship. It was then that this race of macabre began, which today, thanks to the Internet, has the hallmarks of an epidemic of endless horror, where killing can be traced in all details... In the first decades of the twentieth century, the limit of cruelty to the enemy could be pushed further if one participated in a colonial war, against exotic peoples. In a word, racist ideas turned war into punitive expeditions, during which massacres and pacifications often occurred. British, French, Italian and German soldiers imported from exotic wars entire files of photographs documenting their own bloody exploits. The latter also extended the concept of “exoticism” to Eastern Europe.
“Somewhere in the East” — very often Austrian or German soldiers would sign similar pictures sent home from the front of the great war. Wretched and ruined by war settlements, and before them their poor inhabitants, arousing pity, but also the conviction of the civilizational superiority of the conquerors. Similar photos were sent again by the German field post after the occupation of Poland in 1939, then large areas of the USSR in the summer of 1941. Fig. Wikipedia
It was not at all Adolf Hitler who first announced that in the lands inhabited by the Slavs it was possible to do more cruel things to each other. Already during the First World War, in the vast territories of the Russian Empire, German and Austrian generals felt themselves colonizers. At the time, soldiers sent home photographs of Jewish towns and Polish, Belarusian or Ukrainian villages, whose squalid, thatched huts were as exotic as the homes of tribes in German South-West Africa — the only Kaiser colony in the Black Land (present-day Namibia). Among the photographs, there was also no shortage of those in which executions and war destruction were captured. Both Germans and Austrians left behind gallows on which they hung people suspected of spying for the Russian army.
Joseph Roth, in his famous novel Radetzky's March, wrote: “The war of the Austrian army began with court-martial. After days, real and alleged traitors hung on the graveyard trees to scare away the living. But as far as the eye could see, the living inquired.” This cruel law of war did not escape the Polish Legions, as evidenced by this photo in the “Illustrated Chronicle of the Polish Legions 1914—1918” published in the 1930s. The caption under it reads: “Spy from Kielce hanged under Konarami”. Source: Illustrated Chronicle of the Polish Legions, reprint WIW, Warsaw 2018
Professor Martin Pollack in the book “Topography of Memory” quotes the memories of the Austrian poet, Georg Trakl, who in 1914, as a soldier, met with went to the Galician front, where he took part in the pacification actions of the Rusyn villages. The poet recalled one of them as follows: “There, in this square, which seemed to be full of chaos and life, it was again like extinct, standing trees. A whole group of trees, frozen in incredible stillness, on each of the hangers, the Rusini, the rightful citizens of this land. George Trakl could not stand these atrocities psychologically and with symptoms of insanity he ended up in a hospital in Krakow. He died there in November 1914. Trakl could not reconcile himself with the murder of people he was convinced of innocence; with the senseless destruction of Lemkov or Hukul villages. The sensitive poet in uniform belonged to the minority. Most of his colleagues unreservedly approved the orders of the command. In many of the soldiers' letters home were attached pictures from the “Wild East, where our army is finally bringing order” — as one soldier wrote to his family in Vienna, forgetting that Eastern Galicia belonged to the Austro-Hungarian monarchy...
Terror! Terror!
At the end of the Great War, in addition to light cameras, a hand-held film camera appeared, but for the following decades photography was still the main medium by which they tried to convey the horror of war. In the 1930s, the world press, not excluding the Polish one, was dominated by photojournalism of the Spanish Civil War. Depending on the political sympathies of the editors, the crimes of the nationalists and the German-Italian troops supporting them were depicted, the symbol of which was the ruined Guernica air raid, or not at all the lesser atrocities of the Republicans. Newspaper readers around the world watched how terrible a civil war could be, but quickly Spain was outclassed by two more conflicts of the so-called interwar: the Italian-Abyssinian War and the Sino-Japanese War. What pictures were sent from the fronts there fully confirmed the idea that more could be shown from exotic wars.
These pictures are from the 1935 “Illustrated Daily Courier”, where they were captioned: “Wild Abyssinian warriors heading to the northern front. Attention is drawn to a member of the auxiliary guard of Emperor Hajle Syllasje practicing shooting with a modern rifle. Against these “savage” fighters, the Italians threw aviation, armored weapons and artillery into battle, and when they could not break their resistance, they poisoned the Abyssinian settlements with battle gas on a massive scale. Fig. NAÏVE
Recalling both of these conflicts, it is worth looking at how they were perceived in Poland. Diaries with the “Illustrated Daily Courier” at the head published a lot of photoreports from both distant wars for the Polish reader. In the case of the Italian aggression against Abyssinia (present-day Ethiopia), the sympathy of most editors and readers took the side of the attacked. Images of the warriors of Emperor Hajle Syllasje were eagerly published, whose often “medieval” weaponry (swords, spears and shields) contrasted too painfully with the modernly equipped Italian army. It was no secret that the Italians used chemical weapons prohibited by the Geneva Convention to break the resistance of the Ethiopian guerrillas. Sometimes the Abyssinians were only reminded of the torture of Italian prisoners, and it was pointed out that the Italians in the conquered territories had abolished slavery and built roads — a typical action of colonizers preparing conquered lands for future investments.
The Japanese then did the same in China, except that they were a hundred times more cruel than the Italians. Japanese soldiers imbued with the medieval samurai code of Bushidō and the nationalism that grew stronger with each successive victory over chaos and civil war China, entered the heights of bestiality. The most drastic example is Nanjing, the capital of the Republic of China in the 1930s. After the occupation of the city by the Imperial Japanese Army, a regular massacre began on December 13, 1937. The apocalypse of torture, rape and mass executions, during which Japanese soldiers practiced bayonet thrusting or samurai sword cutting on their victims, lasted until the New Year. According to various estimates, the Japanese murdered between 50,000 and 400,000 people—without sparing children and women.
“The Japanese Army on Its Victorious March in China.” It is clear that the Japanese passing the massacred body of a Chinese soldier are satisfied. Easy victories also fueled contempt and, consequently, cruelty towards the vanquished. And even a few years earlier, in 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, war commentators emphasized that the Japanese army treated the enemy's prisoners and civilians extremely humanely... NAÏVE
The Japanese army used war gases on a large scale against the Chinese (including civilians), and its air force relentlessly bombed defenseless districts of Chinese cities, such as Shanghai, which in November 1937 was almost completely destroyed. They were destroyed by bombing raids. This was the total war that the world experienced a few years later.
“Chinese thief guarded by Japanese sailor in Shanghai”. However, it is not at all certain whether this unfortunate man was indeed a thief, and not just a man accidentally captured on the streets of a pacified city, who was massacred by the Japanese under any pretext. Such a “justification” of terror was used by the Germans after entering Poland in 1939, signing, for example, photographs with hostages “Polish murderers”. Fig. NAÏVE
The Polish press closely followed this Asian conflict and published many photos from the areas affected by the fighting, including from Shanghai, but in articles and comments sympathy was rather on the side of Japan. This was mainly due to the fact that the “Japanese samurai” were seen as irreconcilable enemies of communism and, consequently, a rival of the Soviet Union. Nothing arouses sympathy and cements friendship like a common enemy. Who could have predicted then that two years later, in September 1939, the Poles would fall victim to equally ruthless and cruel actions by Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia. And ironically, Japan will become the only country to which the Polish government will officially declare war in 1941...
In August 1938, this picture appeared in the “Illustrated Daily Courier”, whose caption reported: “Military training of Buddhist monks from the Temple of Eternal Peace at Eiheii-ji near Fukui, Japan. The monks are armed with Arisaka Meiji 30-Shiki and 38-Shiki rifles. The name of the temple no longer corresponded to reality at that time in the Land of the Blossom Cherry. Fig. NAÏVE
Thanks to the popularization of photography, the war has indeed become more vivid and real, but also more terrible. The creators of advertising slogans from Kodak and other companies least expected that their products in the hands of soldiers would become another weapon as dangerous as a rifle, and most of the front shots would not be suitable for viewing in the family circle by the fireplace or the festive table.
Bibliography
Andrzej Bartnicki, Joanna Mantel Niećko, “History of Ethiopia”, Wrocław 1987
Jakub Polit, “China”, Warsaw 2004
Martin Pollack, “The Topography of Memory,” trans. Karolina Niedenthal, Volovets 2017
Joseph Roth, “Radetzky's March,” trans. Wanda Kragen, Warsaw 1977

title: Who nominated Jon Fosse for the Nobel Prize?
author: Selma Stormyren Larsen; Day Eivind Undheim Larsen
description: Who nominated Jon Fosse for the Nobel Prize? We won't get the answer until 50 years from now. Unless someone's babbling, then.
text:
Straight to the Heart
Ronen Bahar leads the Mosaic Faith Community. But he's not religious.
! [] (https://cdn.sanity.io/images/u4eaiudq/production/da944d8b5e130847c95f05d69d2dd4f44483fbba-1734x2600.jpg?w=1600&q=80&auto=format)
The first time Ronen Bahar cooked, he was six years old. It was during the First Lebanon War in 1982. Both his father and his two eldest brothers were away in the war. Her mother was home alone in Beer Sheva, a desert town in southern Israel, with Ronen and her 13-year-old brother.

title: The Italian military were not stupid
author: Pocheon High School, uh
description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8iA3achhdY&list=PL5C04ADB75A827FD9&index=23&ab_channel=INTERROMARIO때는 As World War II continued to be in full swing, the Italian army fought back and forth, and 300,000 soldiers were taken prisoner by the Allied forces in North Africa alone, and deserters were so messed up that matched the number of prisoners. Italian soldiers taken prisoner by the Allied forces lived in camps...
text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8iA3achhdY&list=PL5C04ADB75A827FD9&index=23&ab_channel=INTERROMARIO
때는 계속해서 2차세계대전이 한창이던 시기
이탈리아군은 졸전을 거듭하며 북아프리카에서만 30만명에 달하는 병사가 연합군 포로가 되었으며
탈영병도 포로 숫자에 맞먹을 정도로 엉망이 되어 있었다
연합군 포로가 된 이탈리아군 병사들은 수용소생활을 하면서 연합군 식량을 축내는 역할을 담당했으며
( 실제로 연합군은 너무 많은 이탈리아군 포로들 때문에 보급이 힘들었다 )
이탈리아인 특유의 친화력으로 간수나 감시병들과 농담따먹기나 하고
연합군 점령지 근처의 여자들을 꼬시는 작태를 보였다
심지어 충성심 강한 독일군들이 시도때도 없이 수용소에서 탈출을 할 때
이탈리아군 포로들은 탈출시도조차 하지 않았다
오히려 저녁에 수용소 문이 닫히자 늦게 복귀한 이탈리아군 포로들이 들여보내달라고 아우성칠 정도였으니 말 다했다
이렇게 이탈리아군은 보람찬 수용소생활을 보내며 종전 후 무사히 본국으로 돌려보내진다
이렇게만보면 이탈리아군은 무능한 병신이지만 착한 동네 바보형처럼 보일 수도 있다
하지만 과연 그랬을까
1. 활약
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x4N1WN3juOU&feature=emb_title&ab_channel=JulesAdam
( 흔히 정예 이탈리아군이라면 생각나는 영상 )
이탈리아군에 대한 편견과 달리 굉장히 용감하게 싸웠던 이들이 있었으니
바로 베르살리에리 여단이었다
흔히 행진할 때 무조건 뛰어다니는 부대로 잘 알려져 있는데 2차세계대전 기간엔 자전거나 오토바이등
각종 이동수단으로 이동속도가 발전되었다
그 외에 뛰어난 체력과 빠른 기동전술
그리고 정예라는 자긍심으로 유럽전선 이곳저곳에서 수많은 활약했다
그동안 이탈리아군이 바보취급받던거에 비하면 참으로 의외다
"독일군은 세상을 놀라게 하지만 베르살리에리는 독일군을 놀라게 한다."
- 독일군 기갑장교 '에르빈 롬멜'
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/99b983892094b5c6d2fc3736e15da7d1_1.png)
( 베르살리에리는 뇌조깃털을 현재까지 착용하고 있다 )
부대 전통 중 하나인 뇌조깃털을 달고 다니는 간지를 보여준 이들은
첫인상부터 범상치 않았는데 마치 고인물이 패션쇼하는 느낌이겠다
베르살리에리 부대는 북아프리카전선에서 그 유명한 미국의 조지 패튼 장군을 무찌르는 기염을 토해내기도 했는데
이 보고를 받은 패튼 장군이 어떻게 이탈리아군을 상대로 졌냐며 노발대발했지만
'상대가 베르살리에리였다' 는 답변을 듣자 패배를 인정했을 정도로 이들의 위상은 대단했다
롤에서 미드 정글 하체가 줄줄이 터지면 상체가 캐리하는게 이런 느낌일까
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/6cbdd845b39138479b3121ab7e975e01.png)
( 2차세계대전 기간의 베르살리에리 여단 )
나치독일의 기갑장교 에르빈 롬멜은 처음에 이들을 신뢰하지 않았으나
(사실 모든 이탈리아군을 신뢰하지 않았다)
이들이 보여준 무공으로 인해 롬멜은 이들을 정예군으로 잘 써먹었다
베르살리에리 여단은 롬멜이 이탈리아군 중에서 거의 유일하게 신뢰하던 부대였고
포로가 되기를 거부하고 장렬하게 전사하는 경우가 많아 연합군 상대로 악명을 떨쳤다
하지만 이탈리아에겐 정예보병만이 있는것은 아니었으니
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/99b983892094b5c6d2fc3736e15da7d1.png)
( 북아프리카 전선. 공격을 감행하는 아리에테 기갑사단 )
바로 아리에테 기갑사단이 있었다
이들은 북아프리카 전선에서 롬멜의 기갑군에 못지않은 전과를 톡톡히 올렸는데
영국의 명장 버나드 로 몽고메리 장군의 공격을 성공적으로 방어하기도 했다
물론 독일군의 지원이 더해졌기에 가능한 일이었지만
어쨌든 적군을 방어하는 것만으로 1인분 역할을 훌륭히 해냈던 것이다
하지만 이탈리아군의 고질적인 역량부족과 패퇴를 거듭하는 불리한 상황이 지속되자
이들은 결국 전멸에 가까운 피해를 입고 해산되고 만다
하지만 아리에테 기갑사단은 다시 부활하여 나중에 동맹이었던
독일 기갑군단과 맞서 싸우게 되는 순간이 오게 되는데
제 135기갑사단 '아리에테-II' 가 바로 그러하다
이들은 무솔리니가 이탈리아 본토를 방어하기 위해 짱박아둔 최신식 전차로 구성되어 있었으며
무장수준도 독일군과 비교해도 꿀리지 않을 정도였다
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 이탈리아가 조기항복한 이후 들어온 연합군 병사들. 뒤편으로 콜로세움이 보인다 )
아리에테 기갑사단을 비롯한 이탈리아군은 연합군편에 서서 독일군에 대항했고
패전도 많이 겪었지만 그래도 나름 분전을 치루었으며 이는 이탈리아가 패전국이었음에도
국제적 지위를 크게 잃지 않게 만드는 주요한 요인이 되었다
여기까지만 보면 이탈리아군도 악하지 않다는 인상을 받기 쉽겠으나
사실 그 뒤엔 숨겨진 실상이 더 있기 마련이다
2. 학살
" 독일군은 영혼이 없어서 괴물같이 싸우는 것이다. "
- 이탈리아군의 명장 '조반니 메세' 가 포로심문에 답하며
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 2차 이탈리아-에티오피아 전쟁 中, 징집된 에티오피아 병사들이 제식훈련을 받고 있따 )
위 사례만 보자면 이탈리아는 악랄한 나치 독일에 비하면 전쟁범죄도 못 저지르는 바보지만
사실 알고보면 이 새끼들도 더하면 더했지, 못한게 없는 어지간한 씹새끼들이었는데
에티오피아를 먹으려고 두번이나 전쟁을 일으킨 엄연한 전범국이었다
게다가 패배는 이탈리아의 유구한 전통인지 첫번째 시도도 사실상 실패로 끝났었다
이탈리아의 독재자 무솔리니는 전부터 완전히 장악하지 못한 에티오피아를 눈엣가시로 여겼고
대외적으로 이탈리아의 국력을 확실히 홍보하기 위해서라도 그들을 철저히 짓밟을 필요가 있었다
그래서 그는 대군을 동원하면서 2차 이탈리아-에티오피아 전쟁을 일으켰는데
그 때의 에티오피아군은 예전처럼 창들고 싸우던 원시인들이 아니었다
그들은 철저히 서구식으로 무장했으며 훈련을 받아왔었고 이탈리아군은 고전을 면치못하는데
여기서 이탈리아군은 국제적으로 금지된 독가스를 사용했다
중일전쟁 당시 일본군이 중국군을 향해 독가스를 살포하던 것과 똑같다
그렇게 이탈리아는 독가스를 쓰면서 겨우겨우 에티오피아를 점령하게 된다
게다가 당시 대공황의 여파로 자기 발등에 붙은 불을 끄는거마저 버거웠던 열강들은
이탈리아의 이러한 막장행보를 어느 정도 눈감아줬고
이는 이탈리아가 세계를 상대로 더욱 날뛰게 하는 계기를 마련해주게 되었다
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 현대식 라이플로 무장한 에티오피아 여성. 에티오피아군의 무장 수준이 뒤떨어지지 않는 걸 잘 보여준다 )
이탈리아는 일단 에티오피아 점령에는 성공했지만 완전한 장악에는 실패했다
에티오피아인들의 항전의지는 굳셌고, 곳곳에서 산발적인 게릴라 활동으로
이탈리아군에게 지속적인 출혈을 강요했기 때문인데
그들의 게릴라 활동은 이탈리아가 연합국에게 항복하고 식민지를 포기하기 직전까지 이어졌다
한마디로 이탈리아는 점령지 단속도 제대로 못하고 나치독일과 연합국에 맞서 싸운 것이다
참으로 바보병신이 아닐 수가 없다
이탈리아의 전형적인 '강약약약' 의 태도는 점령지 주민들에게도 마찬가지였다
이탈리아군은 죽어나간 이탈리아군의 복수심과 게릴라 축출을 목적으로
에티오피아 주민들을 마구 학살하고 다녔는데 그 목록들은 대강 이렇다
우물에 시멘트 붓기
건물에 주민들을 몰아넣어 불태우기
묻지마 총살은 기본에 약탈, 강간은 당연했고
여태껏 저질렀던 만행들은 연합국에 대한 무조건 항복으로 말끔히 지워졌다
일본과 마찬가지로 이탈리아 역시 전범처리가 가장 안 된 나라 중 하나이다
3. 그저
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 6.25전쟁 당시 한국에 파병된 에티오피아의 정예 '강뉴 부대' )
전후 피해에 대한 배상도 제대로 치뤄지지 않아 엉망이 된 에티오피아
하지만 그들은 복구가 미처 완성되기도 전에 또 한번의 전쟁을 겪게 되는데 바로 6.25전쟁이다
조국이 침략에 의해 만신창이가 되어가던 것을 지켜봐온 에티오피아는
자신의 상처가 아물기도전에 한국에 파병을 보낸것이다
그동안 숱한 전쟁으로 갈고 닦은 정예중에 정예였던 이 '흑인병사' 들은
253번의 크고 작은 전투 중에 단 한번도 패배하지 않았고
포로는 존재하지 않았다
즉 남의 나라를 위해 죽기살기로 싸운것이다
"가라.
살아 돌아올 생각을 하지 말고, 전부 거기에 가서 모두 맹렬하게 싸워서 전사하라.
. . .
우리 민족이 과거에 이탈리아인들에게 무엇을 당해왔는지는
말하지 않아도 그 고통은 뼛속까지 알고 있을 것이다.
그걸 알면서 모른 척한다면, 침략자들보다 못한 더러운 위선자일 뿐이다."
- 에티오피아 국왕 '하일레 셀라시에'
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( '그저 빛' 이셨던 하일레 셀라시에. 하지만 그는 훗날 쿠데타로 인해 폐위되고 만다ㅠㅠㅠㅠ )
어쨌든 이탈리아는 수많은 패전과 졸전으로 전쟁범죄가 가려지는 부분이 없지 않아 있다
특히 독재자 무솔리니의 손녀 딸이 버젓이 정치활동을 하고  If you see that it's getting more and more popular
Still, history is spinning and going
Thank you for reading
image_caption: ;image.png The Italian army was not stupid

title: The Italian military were not stupid
author: Tsuyu
description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8iA3achhdY&list=PL5C04ADB75A827FD9&index=23&ab_channel=INTERROMARIO때는 As World War II continued to be in full swing, the Italian army fought back and forth, and 300,000 soldiers were taken prisoner by the Allied forces in North Africa alone, and deserters were so messed up that matched the number of prisoners. Italian soldiers taken prisoner by the Allied forces lived in camps...
text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8iA3achhdY&list=PL5C04ADB75A827FD9&index=23&ab_channel=INTERROMARIO
때는 계속해서 2차세계대전이 한창이던 시기
이탈리아군은 졸전을 거듭하며 북아프리카에서만 30만명에 달하는 병사가 연합군 포로가 되었으며
탈영병도 포로 숫자에 맞먹을 정도로 엉망이 되어 있었다
연합군 포로가 된 이탈리아군 병사들은 수용소생활을 하면서 연합군 식량을 축내는 역할을 담당했으며
( 실제로 연합군은 너무 많은 이탈리아군 포로들 때문에 보급이 힘들었다 )
이탈리아인 특유의 친화력으로 간수나 감시병들과 농담따먹기나 하고
연합군 점령지 근처의 여자들을 꼬시는 작태를 보였다
심지어 충성심 강한 독일군들이 시도때도 없이 수용소에서 탈출을 할 때
이탈리아군 포로들은 탈출시도조차 하지 않았다
오히려 저녁에 수용소 문이 닫히자 늦게 복귀한 이탈리아군 포로들이 들여보내달라고 아우성칠 정도였으니 말 다했다
이렇게 이탈리아군은 보람찬 수용소생활을 보내며 종전 후 무사히 본국으로 돌려보내진다
이렇게만보면 이탈리아군은 무능한 병신이지만 착한 동네 바보형처럼 보일 수도 있다
하지만 과연 그랬을까
1. 활약
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x4N1WN3juOU&feature=emb_title&ab_channel=JulesAdam
( 흔히 정예 이탈리아군이라면 생각나는 영상 )
이탈리아군에 대한 편견과 달리 굉장히 용감하게 싸웠던 이들이 있었으니
바로 베르살리에리 여단이었다
흔히 행진할 때 무조건 뛰어다니는 부대로 잘 알려져 있는데 2차세계대전 기간엔 자전거나 오토바이등
각종 이동수단으로 이동속도가 발전되었다
그 외에 뛰어난 체력과 빠른 기동전술
그리고 정예라는 자긍심으로 유럽전선 이곳저곳에서 수많은 활약했다
그동안 이탈리아군이 바보취급받던거에 비하면 참으로 의외다
"독일군은 세상을 놀라게 하지만 베르살리에리는 독일군을 놀라게 한다."
- 독일군 기갑장교 '에르빈 롬멜'
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/99b983892094b5c6d2fc3736e15da7d1_1.png)
( 베르살리에리는 뇌조깃털을 현재까지 착용하고 있다 )
부대 전통 중 하나인 뇌조깃털을 달고 다니는 간지를 보여준 이들은
첫인상부터 범상치 않았는데 마치 고인물이 패션쇼하는 느낌이겠다
베르살리에리 부대는 북아프리카전선에서 그 유명한 미국의 조지 패튼 장군을 무찌르는 기염을 토해내기도 했는데
이 보고를 받은 패튼 장군이 어떻게 이탈리아군을 상대로 졌냐며 노발대발했지만
'상대가 베르살리에리였다' 는 답변을 듣자 패배를 인정했을 정도로 이들의 위상은 대단했다
롤에서 미드 정글 하체가 줄줄이 터지면 상체가 캐리하는게 이런 느낌일까
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/6cbdd845b39138479b3121ab7e975e01.png)
( 2차세계대전 기간의 베르살리에리 여단 )
나치독일의 기갑장교 에르빈 롬멜은 처음에 이들을 신뢰하지 않았으나
(사실 모든 이탈리아군을 신뢰하지 않았다)
이들이 보여준 무공으로 인해 롬멜은 이들을 정예군으로 잘 써먹었다
베르살리에리 여단은 롬멜이 이탈리아군 중에서 거의 유일하게 신뢰하던 부대였고
포로가 되기를 거부하고 장렬하게 전사하는 경우가 많아 연합군 상대로 악명을 떨쳤다
하지만 이탈리아에겐 정예보병만이 있는것은 아니었으니
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/files/attach/new3/20221102/486263/1670932254/5172864200/99b983892094b5c6d2fc3736e15da7d1.png)
( 북아프리카 전선. 공격을 감행하는 아리에테 기갑사단 )
바로 아리에테 기갑사단이 있었다
이들은 북아프리카 전선에서 롬멜의 기갑군에 못지않은 전과를 톡톡히 올렸는데
영국의 명장 버나드 로 몽고메리 장군의 공격을 성공적으로 방어하기도 했다
물론 독일군의 지원이 더해졌기에 가능한 일이었지만
어쨌든 적군을 방어하는 것만으로 1인분 역할을 훌륭히 해냈던 것이다
하지만 이탈리아군의 고질적인 역량부족과 패퇴를 거듭하는 불리한 상황이 지속되자
이들은 결국 전멸에 가까운 피해를 입고 해산되고 만다
하지만 아리에테 기갑사단은 다시 부활하여 나중에 동맹이었던
독일 기갑군단과 맞서 싸우게 되는 순간이 오게 되는데
제 135기갑사단 '아리에테-II' 가 바로 그러하다
이들은 무솔리니가 이탈리아 본토를 방어하기 위해 짱박아둔 최신식 전차로 구성되어 있었으며
무장수준도 독일군과 비교해도 꿀리지 않을 정도였다
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 이탈리아가 조기항복한 이후 들어온 연합군 병사들. 뒤편으로 콜로세움이 보인다 )
아리에테 기갑사단을 비롯한 이탈리아군은 연합군편에 서서 독일군에 대항했고
패전도 많이 겪었지만 그래도 나름 분전을 치루었으며 이는 이탈리아가 패전국이었음에도
국제적 지위를 크게 잃지 않게 만드는 주요한 요인이 되었다
여기까지만 보면 이탈리아군도 악하지 않다는 인상을 받기 쉽겠으나
사실 그 뒤엔 숨겨진 실상이 더 있기 마련이다
2. 학살
" 독일군은 영혼이 없어서 괴물같이 싸우는 것이다. "
- 이탈리아군의 명장 '조반니 메세' 가 포로심문에 답하며
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 2차 이탈리아-에티오피아 전쟁 中, 징집된 에티오피아 병사들이 제식훈련을 받고 있따 )
위 사례만 보자면 이탈리아는 악랄한 나치 독일에 비하면 전쟁범죄도 못 저지르는 바보지만
사실 알고보면 이 새끼들도 더하면 더했지, 못한게 없는 어지간한 씹새끼들이었는데
에티오피아를 먹으려고 두번이나 전쟁을 일으킨 엄연한 전범국이었다
게다가 패배는 이탈리아의 유구한 전통인지 첫번째 시도도 사실상 실패로 끝났었다
이탈리아의 독재자 무솔리니는 전부터 완전히 장악하지 못한 에티오피아를 눈엣가시로 여겼고
대외적으로 이탈리아의 국력을 확실히 홍보하기 위해서라도 그들을 철저히 짓밟을 필요가 있었다
그래서 그는 대군을 동원하면서 2차 이탈리아-에티오피아 전쟁을 일으켰는데
그 때의 에티오피아군은 예전처럼 창들고 싸우던 원시인들이 아니었다
그들은 철저히 서구식으로 무장했으며 훈련을 받아왔었고 이탈리아군은 고전을 면치못하는데
여기서 이탈리아군은 국제적으로 금지된 독가스를 사용했다
중일전쟁 당시 일본군이 중국군을 향해 독가스를 살포하던 것과 똑같다
그렇게 이탈리아는 독가스를 쓰면서 겨우겨우 에티오피아를 점령하게 된다
게다가 당시 대공황의 여파로 자기 발등에 붙은 불을 끄는거마저 버거웠던 열강들은
이탈리아의 이러한 막장행보를 어느 정도 눈감아줬고
이는 이탈리아가 세계를 상대로 더욱 날뛰게 하는 계기를 마련해주게 되었다
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 현대식 라이플로 무장한 에티오피아 여성. 에티오피아군의 무장 수준이 뒤떨어지지 않는 걸 잘 보여준다 )
이탈리아는 일단 에티오피아 점령에는 성공했지만 완전한 장악에는 실패했다
에티오피아인들의 항전의지는 굳셌고, 곳곳에서 산발적인 게릴라 활동으로
이탈리아군에게 지속적인 출혈을 강요했기 때문인데
그들의 게릴라 활동은 이탈리아가 연합국에게 항복하고 식민지를 포기하기 직전까지 이어졌다
한마디로 이탈리아는 점령지 단속도 제대로 못하고 나치독일과 연합국에 맞서 싸운 것이다
참으로 바보병신이 아닐 수가 없다
이탈리아의 전형적인 '강약약약' 의 태도는 점령지 주민들에게도 마찬가지였다
이탈리아군은 죽어나간 이탈리아군의 복수심과 게릴라 축출을 목적으로
에티오피아 주민들을 마구 학살하고 다녔는데 그 목록들은 대강 이렇다
우물에 시멘트 붓기
건물에 주민들을 몰아넣어 불태우기
묻지마 총살은 기본에 약탈, 강간은 당연했고
여태껏 저질렀던 만행들은 연합국에 대한 무조건 항복으로 말끔히 지워졌다
일본과 마찬가지로 이탈리아 역시 전범처리가 가장 안 된 나라 중 하나이다
3. 그저
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( 6.25전쟁 당시 한국에 파병된 에티오피아의 정예 '강뉴 부대' )
전후 피해에 대한 배상도 제대로 치뤄지지 않아 엉망이 된 에티오피아
하지만 그들은 복구가 미처 완성되기도 전에 또 한번의 전쟁을 겪게 되는데 바로 6.25전쟁이다
조국이 침략에 의해 만신창이가 되어가던 것을 지켜봐온 에티오피아는
자신의 상처가 아물기도전에 한국에 파병을 보낸것이다
그동안 숱한 전쟁으로 갈고 닦은 정예중에 정예였던 이 '흑인병사' 들은
253번의 크고 작은 전투 중에 단 한번도 패배하지 않았고
포로는 존재하지 않았다
즉 남의 나라를 위해 죽기살기로 싸운것이다
"가라.
살아 돌아올 생각을 하지 말고, 전부 거기에 가서 모두 맹렬하게 싸워서 전사하라.
. . .
우리 민족이 과거에 이탈리아인들에게 무엇을 당해왔는지는
말하지 않아도 그 고통은 뼛속까지 알고 있을 것이다.
그걸 알면서 모른 척한다면, 침략자들보다 못한 더러운 위선자일 뿐이다."
- 에티오피아 국왕 '하일레 셀라시에'
![image.png 이탈리아군은 바보가 아니었다](http://image.fmkorea.com/classes/lazy/img/transparent.gif)
( '그저 빛' 이셨던 하일레 셀라시에. 하지만 그는 훗날 쿠데타로 인해 폐위되고 만다ㅠㅠㅠㅠ )
어쨌든 이탈리아는 수많은 패전과 졸전으로 전쟁범죄가 가려지는 부분이 없지 않아 있다
특히 독재자 무솔리니의 손녀 딸이 버젓이 정치활동을 하고  If you see that it's getting more and more popular
Still, history is spinning and going
Thank you for reading

title: Surfing Hercules' 27ft waves
author: Independent
description: Waves were recorded as high as 27ft at Land's End, and reports on surfing forecast websites suggested scores of professional "big wave chasers" had followed Hercules' movements across the Atlantic.
text:
People watch and photograph enormous waves as they break, on Porthcawl harbour, South Wales. Photo / AP
People watch and photograph enormous waves as they break, on Porthcawl harbour, South Wales. Photo / AP
The UK has been warned to expect at least three more days of heavy rain and flooding as the west coast counted its losses following the arrival of "Winter Storm Hercules", the system which has left behind a record-breaking deep freeze in the US.
Last night a flood siren warning of extreme danger to people and property was sounded in Dorset, as gales and tidal surges battered the coast.
The Environment Agency raised the alarm after its sea defences were breached at Chiswell Beach in Portland last night, following on from a severe flood warning in the area.
Image 1 of 9: People watch and photograph enormous waves as they break, on Porthcawl harbour, South Wales. Photo / AP
Dorset Police told families to move to an upstairs room facing away from the sea and arm themselves with flood kits.
While evacuated residents in Aberystwyth were told they could return to their homes today, flood warnings remained in place across every region of England and Wales.
The Met Office said a further band of heavy showers was passing northeastwards across the country, and extended its severe weather warnings for rain into Thursday morning (local time).
This was reflected by the Environment Agency's flooding forecast, which said 45 counties would still be at risk as we head into the end of the week.
In addition to the severe flood warning at Chiswell, two others remained in place today - meaning there is also a real "danger to life and property" at nearby Preston Beach and the Lower Stour in Dorset.
Around 105 less serious flood warnings are in place across the country, including in Dorset, Oxfordshire, south Wiltshire, Hampshire and along the river Thames, while the number of low-level "flooding is possible" alerts dropped just under 200.
Yesterday waves were recorded as high as 27ft at Land's End, and reports on surfing forecast websites suggested scores of professional "big wave chasers" had followed Hercules' movements across the Atlantic.
Big waves slap against the seawall at the beach in Anglet, southwestern France. Photo / AFP
The British big wave surfer Andrew Cotton wrote on his official Facebook page on Monday: "With the 'biggest swell ever' on the charts for Europe I'm packing all my equipment and hitting the road."
He told the action sports news outlet Grind TV: "We left for Ireland on Saturday, getting on the last ferry before they were all cancelled."
The Met Office's chief forecaster said a "large, deep depression" was whipping up waves out to sea as a system of low pressures moved northeastwards across the Atlantic.
Nicola Maxey, a spokesperson for the Met Office, confirmed that Britain was feeling the effects of the same system that had led to such extraordinary conditions in the US over the past week.
She told The Independent the storm was "a different beast" after moving across the ocean, picking up water but also gaining heat. It passed to the west of Scotland later on Monday, but left behind a trail of devastation and took visible chunks out of much of the coastline.
Meanwhile, the transport networks were still reeling from the widespread disruption yesterday as commuters tried to return to work after the Christmas and New Year holidays.
Waves crash against the Aberystwyth coastline, in Wales, as strong winds and high tides continue to blow in from the west. Photo / AP
The storms were believed to have claimed three lives over the course of the past week. In Oxford, a 47-year-old man died when his mobility scooter fell from a flooded path into a river.
A 27-year-old man from Surrey was found on Porthleven Sands beach in Cornwall after he was swept out to sea on New Year's Eve night and a woman died after being rescued from the sea in Croyde Bay, north Devon.
Searches were still going on over the weekend in south Devon for missing 18-year-old university student Harry Martin, who was last seen leaving his home to take photographs of the weather - with more than 100 people volunteering to look for him.
Devon and Cornwall Police said a 32-kilometres stretch of coastline - 16 km either side of the 18-year-old's home at Newton Ferrers - has been extensively searched as well as inland areas with the help of a range of groups and emergency services.
Jonathan Day, flood risk manager at the Environment Agency, warned at the weekend that the risk of flooding could continue throughout this week.
He said: "Although high tides are now falling, there remains a risk of coastal flooding, especially on the south and west coasts.
"In addition, wet conditions have left the ground saturated in many areas, increasing the risk of river and surface water flooding.
"We would urge people to be prepared by checking their flood risk, signing up to free flood warnings and keeping an eye on the latest flood updates," Mr Day said.

title: UK weather: London battered by gales as more floods set to hit in
author: Benedict Moore-Bridger; Josh Pettitt
text:
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/09/brolluy.jpg?crop=8:5,smart&quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
London was hit by gale force winds today as the worst winter storms to hit Britain in more than 20 years continued to ravage the country.
Winds of up to 40 miles per hour and heavy showers battered the capital with experts predicting gusts could reach 50 mph before Wednesday.
The Thames Barrier remained closed to protect London from tidal surges while the Army also worked to build up flood defences in Kent with soldiers from 36 Engineer Regiment and 2 Royal Gurkha Rifles helping to fill sandbags.
A total of 106 flood warnings have been issued by the Environment Agency and a further 236 areas placed on flood alert.
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/09/commute1.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
Emma Compton, a forecaster for the Met Office, said: “It’s another windy day with further showers and heavy winds. There is a risk of hail and thunder as well, but it should improve throughout the week.”
One severe flood warning was in place in Dorset - meaning “there is significant risk to life” - wi near hurricane-force winds of up to 70 mph expected on the west and south-west coast of Britain and the east coast of Northern Ireland will cause “exceptionally high waves” of up to 30 feet, the Met Office said.
A gale is classed as winds of between 39 and 46 mph, rising to a strong gale, storm, violent storm and finally hurricane force for anything above 74 mph.
The ferocious weather which began over Christmas has left widespread damage.
Around 220 properties have been flooded so far as miles of coastline have been hit, with roads and fields across the country under water and the conditions causing transport chaos in many areas.
Anne McIntosh, chairman of the Commons environmental select committee, described the country as being in the “eye of an emergency”.
Three people have already died in the storms, while the search continued today for 18-year-old London student Harry Martin who went missing while trying to photograph the weather conditions.
Rescue crews today embarked on their fourth day of searching for the photography student at Greenwich University, last seen leaving his family home in Newtow Ferrers, Devon, on Thursday.
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/09/commute2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
Mr Martin had recently started a course in film production at Greenwich University but was back home visiting his parents Anthony, 57 and Georgina, 52, for the Christmas holidays.
Read More
His uncle, Darrell Marshall, said: “He went off on Thursday morning with his camera about 11am and we haven’t seen him since.
“He is very interested in photography, he is doing a course in film production at the University of Greenwich, it is part of his course.”
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/08/henleyonthames.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
Police, the Dartmoor Rescue Group, coastguards and up to 100 members of the public have taken part in the hunt. Prayers were said for the missing 18-year-old in local church services yesterday.
Chief Inspector Shaun Kenneally, of Devon and Cornwall Police, said: “All the resources we can muster are being used, but it’s an extensive coastline and a rugged area that we’ve got to manage, so it’s difficult.”
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/13/wav3.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
An unnamed 27-year-old man from Guildford died after being washed out to sea after going for a swim with friends on New Year’s Eve. A woman on holiday in Croyde, Devon also died after being swept out to sea last Tuesday.
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/13/wav1.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
In Oxford a 47-year-old man died when his mobility scooter fell from a flooded path into a river.
Thames Valley Police were called to Osney Lock near the city centre at 6.30pm on Saturday after receiving a report that the man had fallen into the river.
![](https://static.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2014/01/06/13/wav2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&width=960)
A police spokesman said the man’s death was being treated as unexplained but was not believed to be suspicious.
Meanwhile Environment Secretary Owen Paterson chaired a meeting of the Government’s Cobra emergency committee on Sunday, while David Cameron pledged lessons will be learned from the flooding.
Mr Paterson said: “Surface water flooding remains likely in some parts of the UK and the Government remains ready to respond and continue to help communities.
“When clean-up operations are able to begin, then assistance will be provided.”
The wet and windy weather made it a miserable return to work for many workers in London, who also suffered delays on the Tube.
A signal problem at Tower Hill led to suspension, for a tim e, of clockwise services on the Circle line and also to severe delays on the District line and hold-ups on the Hammersmith & Circle line.
There were also morning rush-hour problems on the Victoria line which was suspended between Victoria and Highbury & Islington due to a person under a train.

title: UK says hello to Hercules
author: Independent
description: Waves up to 8.2 metres high slammed into Britain's southwestern coast, as lashing winds and heavy rain battered parts of the U.K.
text:
Waves crash against the Aberystwyth coastline, in Wales, as strong winds and high tides continue to blow in from the west. Photo / AP
Waves crash against the Aberystwyth coastline, in Wales, as strong winds and high tides continue to blow in from the west. Photo / AP
More flooding is expected across Britain today as the west coast braced for the arrival of "Winter Storm Hercules", the system which has left behind a record-breaking deep freeze in the US.
Waves have been recorded as high as 27ft (8.2m) at Land's End, and reports on surfing forecast websites suggested scores of professional "big wave chasers" were tracking Hercules' movements across the Atlantic.
The Met Office's chief forecaster said a "large, deep depression" was whipping up waves out to sea, and the system of low pressures continues to move "northeastwards across the Atlantic".
People watch and photograph enormous waves as they break, on Porthcawl harbour, South Wales. Photo / AP
Nicola Maxey, a spokesperson for the Met Office, confirmed that Britain was faced with the same system that had led to such extraordinary conditions in the US over the past week.
She added that the storm was "a different beast" after moving across the ocean, picking up water but also gaining heat. It was forecast to pass to the west of Scotland later today, and though not crossing the country led the Met Office to issue severe weather warnings for rain and 70mph winds along the coast.
Meanwhile, the transport networks were hit with widespread disruption today as commuters tried to return to work after the Christmas and New Year holidays.
Heavy rain fell across the majority of the UK last night, and with rivers high and ground saturated by the worst series of winter storms to hit Britain in more than 20 years, the Environment Agency said flooding was "expected" in almost every region of England and Wales.
Residents in coastal areas were advised to be particularly cautious, with the strong winds set to cause "exceptionally high waves", the Met Office said earlier.
Yet the effects of the storm will also have been felt by those returning to work this morning.
First Great Western warned passengers there was a risk to services in Cornwall, Devon, Somerset, Wiltshire and Dorset.
South West Trains services between Fulwell in south-west London and Shepperton in Surrey were not running due to flooding, BBC News reported, while major roads in areas including Pembrokeshire, West Sussex, Gloucestershire, Berkshire, Somerset and Devon were also closed.
The Thames Barrier was in operation last night, while the Environment Agency urged communities in Dorset and Oxfordshire to brace for "significant flooding" in the lower reaches of the Thames, Dorset Stour and Frome rivers.
The agency also estimated that around 220 properties in coastal areas have been flooded so far.
Image 1 of 9: People watch and photograph enormous waves as they break, on Porthcawl harbour, South Wales. Photo / AP
The storms were believed to have claimed three lives over the course of the past week. In Oxford, a 47-year-old man died when his mobility scooter fell from a flooded path into a river.
A 27-year-old man from Surrey was found on Porthleven Sands beach in Cornwall after he was swept out to sea on New Year's Eve night and a woman died after being rescued from the sea in Croyde Bay, north Devon.
Searches were still going on over the weekend in south Devon for missing 18-year-old university student Harry Martin, who was last seen leaving his home to take photographs of the weather - with more than 100 people volunteering to look for him.
Jonathan Day, flood risk manager at the Environment Agency, warned that the risk of flooding continued this week.
He said: "Although high tides are now falling, there remains a risk of coastal flooding, especially on the south and west coasts.

title: Further flooding expected as UK gets back to work
author: Blake Welton
description: Flooding is "expected" across almost every region in England and Wales as strong winds and large waves continue to batter the UK
text:
Further flooding expected as UK gets back to work
Flooding is "expected" across almost every region in England and Wales as strong winds and large waves continue to batter the UK
Strong winds and large waves are expected to cause further coastal flooding today.
The Environment Agency issued one severe flood warning in Dorset - meaning "there is significant risk to life" - and 87 flood warnings where flooding is "expected" across almost every region in England and Wales.
Heavy rain fell across much of the UK last night, with up to 1.6in (40mm) expected on higher ground today.
The Environment Agency estimates about 220 properties have been flooded so far as miles of coastline have been battered and roads and fields across the country are under water.
The Met Office also issued a "be aware" yellow warning for wind as gusts of up to 70mph are expected on the west and south-west coast of Britain and the east coast of Northern Ireland today, causing ''exceptionally high waves''.
The transport network has also been hit, with roads closed and trains delayed or cancelled in many areas.
First Great Western warned passengers there was a risk to services in Cornwall, Devon, Somerset, Wiltshire and Dorset.
The Thames Barrier was in operation last night to protect people and property along the river.
The Environment Agency (EA) urged communities in Dorset and Oxfordshire to remain prepared for ''significant flooding'' in the lower reaches of the Thames, Dorset Stour and Frome rivers.
Ongoing flooding is expected on the Somerset Levels and rivers in the South East, including the Severn, remain ''very high'' after recent rainfall.
Jonathan Day, flood risk manager at the Environment Agency, warned the risk of flooding continued this week.
He said: ''Although high tides are now falling, there remains a risk of coastal flooding, especially on the south and west coasts.
''In addition, wet conditions have left the ground saturated in many areas, increasing the risk of river and surface water flooding.
''We would urge people to be prepared by checking their flood risk, signing up to free flood warnings and keeping an eye on the latest flood updates via the EA website and Twitter.''
The coastal surge in recent days has tested more than 1,864 miles (3,000km) of flood defences in England and more than 205,000 properties have been protected, according to the Environment Agency.
David Cameron pledged lessons will be learned from the flooding and insisted that the Environment Agency has been given the funding to protect frontline services.
The Prime Minister told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: ''We're spending £2.3 billion in this four-year period on flood defences which is more than the previous four-year period.
''We have also enabled them to access other sources of money - partnership funding - so I think we're going to see record levels of spending on flood defences and we have guaranteed that right out into 2020 so they can really plan for the future.''
Mr Cameron added: ''I think flood warnings are better, I think the flood defences have protected tens of thousands of homes but there will always be lessons to learn and I'll make sure they are learned.''
![videoHeadline](http://brightcove.vo.llnwd.net/d21/unsecured/media/4221396001/201401/1115/4221396001_3017086139001_Ipkg1389006824480I-70440-1-480x360.jpg?pubId=4221396001)

title: Wales weather: Homes, student halls and businesses on Aberystwyth seafront evacuated ahead of second huge tidal swell
author: Rachael Misstear
description: Ceredigion council is telling people to leave their properties in light of 'very high tides and exceptional wave swell'
text:
Residents and business owners on the Aberystwyth seafront have been told to leave their properties in light of fears of further flooding.
Very high tides with exceptional wave swell hit on Monday morning, with fears that this could cause "serious injury, substantial flooding and damage to properties".
And Ceredigion Council has now said that another "exceptional wave swell" is due at 11.37pm tonight, carrying a threat of "serious injury, flooding and damage to properties", in the light of the damage to the promenade from the weekend's storms.
A council statement added issued at around 4pm added: "We strongly advise residents on the Promenade to vacate all properties and move to our Evacuation Support Centre in Plascrug Leisure Centre (please note change of venue from this morning) as soon as possible before 22.00."
Students who live in seafront halls of residence have also been told not to return until at least the middle of the week.
The Met Office warned that another band of gales and heavy rain is on the way and Winter Storm Hercules, which hit the US bringing major snow storms, has affected tidal swells.
It said coastal areas would be vulnerable to further flooding, with some areas being hit by winds of up to 70mph.
Earlier, Ceredigion council said: "Residents between Pier and Constitution Hill should leave properties and go to our Rest Centre in Penglais School ASAP before 10am.
"Everyone should keep away from the promenade as it is very dangerous."
Photographer Keith Morris, who was at Aberystwyth promenade, said: "They are preparing for the worst, the council officers and police came around door to door leafletting and telling people to get out along the entire promenade from the Pier to Constitution Hill.
"People seem to be heeding the warnings but seem to be leaving via their back doors. It's all pretty dramatic."
Richard Griffiths, who runs the Richmond Hotel on the promenade, said he wasn't going to evacuate.
He said: "The council have recommend, in the strongest possible terms, that properties are evacuated right along the promenade.
"We had a team come in to start reopening the hotel after the storms on Friday, and we intended to be open this evening. We will now have to wait and see how bad or what damage is caused by the storm this morning.
"Barring any catastrophes in this morning's very high tide, we will be open tonight."
![](https://cdn.jwplayer.com/v2/media/ee27OR8x/poster.jpg)
But despite the building's previous resilience he said staff would be evacuated later: "We will get all of the staff out at the height of the storm, ensuring they are in safe areas but once that's over and we've had the all clear we will bring everyone back."
In Carmarthenshire high tides caused "huge" sprays along the sea wall at Pendine. And high tides again led to spectacular waves at Porthcawl, where a coastal path has been torn up in parts.
In Pembrokeshire, council workers were dealing with fresh damage caused by floods. Officers were investigating a collapsed footpath on the promenade in Neyland. Elsewhere, roads were closed and several areas reported sea water topping shoreline defences.
Jackie James, who works at the village's Point Cafe next to the front, said they were expecting the worst: "The waves seem to be getting worse it 's now going over the roofs of shore houses. These are mega waves, spectacular scenes."
![Waves pick up on Monday at Pendine before high tide](https://i2-prod.walesonline.co.uk/news/article6471197.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/Pendine-Monday-1.jpg)
A Ceredigion council spokeswoman confirmed the Aberystwyth evacuation: "We are putting up notices and urging people to evacuate ahead of the forecast tides and high winds."
On Monday morning, the Met Office issued a yellow weather warning for wind covering the entire coastline, as well as a yellow warning for rain in north and north-west Wales.
A Met Office statement warned about the areas covered by the wind warning: "Strong winds will combine with large waves to bring the risk of coastal flooding.
"Winds will gust to 60mph or so on coasts, and locally to 70mph, but waves will be larger than usually associated with this strength.
"The public should be aware of the dangers of waves crashing onshore and over topping shore lines and sea fronts."
![Waves come over the road in Pendine on Monday](https://i2-prod.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/article6471328.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/pendine.jpg)
And for the parts of Wales affected by the rain warning, it added: "Some 5 to 10mm of rain could occur in less than an hour with locally 15 to 25mm of rain through today and perhaps as much as 40 mm on high ground.
"The public should be aware of the potential for localised flooding leading to difficult driving conditions, with hail providing an additional hazard."
Parts of Porthcawl's coastal path have been left impassable after huge waves undermined its foundations.
Rest Bay councillor Norah Clarke said she had never before seen such damage caused by the sea  there.
“The tide has thrown up pebbles and it has covered large area of the coastal path. It goes right from Rest Bay around to Sker Point.
“Part of the boardwalk has actually been picked up and thrown towards the [Royal Porthcawl] golf club. Much of it has been undermined and is now completely unsafe.
“The slip way by the Rest Bay Lifeguard Club has also been undermined. It was only extended last year and now it will need huge amounts of remedial work.
“There is a lot of debris that has been thrown up on to the pavements in town.
“Given that we have the second highest tide in the world, we have to feel grateful that we haven’t been affected as badly as places like Aberystwyth.”
At 2.30pm there were three flood warnings and nine flood alerts in place for Wales.
Yesterday the Welsh Government ordered a review of Wales’ coastal defences .
Just under 500 students live in seafront halls of residence at Aberystwyth. Many had already heeded the university’s advice last Friday asking them to delay their return to university until the mid of this week.
The university told all students on Monday who live in the seafront halls and in private accommodation not to return until an update on Wednesday.
Around 150 students currently resident in the halls have been evacuated.
Environment minister Alun Davies, in Wales to witness the damage from Friday's tidal surges, said: “Friday saw the worst storms to have affected the Welsh coastline for 15 years. My thoughts are with those affected and who have had a very difficult start to the New Year.
Flood map shows flood warnings and alerts in Wales on Monday:
![](https://i2-prod.walesonline.co.uk/incoming/article6471735.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/floodmap.jpg)
“I would like to thank Natural Resources Wales, local authorities, the fire and rescue services, the police, RNLI and other agencies for their efforts in evacuating those at risk and in undertaking the clean up operation.
“It is impossible to totally prevent flooding but we are working to build resilience around our coasts in Wales.
“Our coastal flood defences have been severely tested by these storms and it is vital to look at how our sea defences have managed to stand up to the power of the recent storms.
“That is why I have asked Natural Resources Wales to carry out this swift review with the immediate priority being to identify and assess any damage caused so that we can prioritise repair work and see what lessons we can learn to be well prepared for future severe weather, particularly given that these events are forecast to become more frequent as a result of climate change.”
The Met Office weather warning for Wales on Monday:
![](https://i2-prod.walesonline.co.uk/incoming/article6470395.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/warning.jpg)
Waves of around 70ft have been reported in the mid-Atlantic, which are expected to be around to hit the Welsh coast in Pembrokeshire this afternoon - albeit at a much smaller size.
NRW officials were continuing to monitor closely as more high winds are forecast throughout Monday.
“This additional rainfall, following the recent very wet weather, means that the public should be aware of an increased risk of both surface water and river flooding as well as disruption to transport,” said a spokesman.
A series of train routes were replaced by buses due to the weather conditions, including between Machynlleth and both Pwllheli and Aberystwyth, Llandudno Junction and Blaenau Ffestiniog, Llanelli and Carmarthen, and Swansea and Pantyffynnon.
Huge waves hammer the seafront at Porthcawl on Saturday:
![](https://cdn.jwplayer.com/v2/media/SZr9Co4L/poster.jpg)
However, the risk of further flooding today was not expected to be as severe as it was on Friday, when hundreds of homes were affected.
The wet conditions and storm damage were still causing chaos yesterday, as some roads remained closed and train services were disrupted.
Debris remained strewn across the promenade in Aberystwyth, rail lines in north Wales were left buckled by the power of the sea and a road collapsed in Amroth, Pembrokeshire.
Arriva Trains Wales services between Machynlleth and Aberystwyth, Llanelli and Carmarthen, and Llandudno Junction to Blaenau Ffestiniog, were disrupted on yesterday due to flooding.
High winds led to a lane being closed on the M48 Severn Bridge and in Pembrokeshire, the A487 was closed due to flooding between Welsh Road (Newgale) and Anchor Down (Solva). The council closed the road for the weekend, due to forecast of further storms.
image_caption: The view from Aberystwyth's Constitution Hill as the seafront is battered by waves (Image: Jem Rowland);The view from Aberystwyth's Constitution Hill as the seafront is battered by waves (Image: Jem Rowland)

title: Explainer: what causes winter storms?
author: Nigel Arnell
description: The storms which have battered the UK over recent weeks can be traced back to a strong front of contrasting temperature between particularly cold air over the north Atlantic, which has also brought extreme…
text:
The storms which have battered the UK over recent weeks can be traced back to a strong front of contrasting temperature between particularly cold air over the north Atlantic, which has also brought extreme cold and snow to parts of the US, and warmer air further south. The strong temperature contrast across the Atlantic leads to storms forming around the front, circulating and mixing air along the temperature gradient, trying to find an equilibrium of hot and cold air.
You could think of this as like adding cold water to a hot bath, where at some point the cold water entering from the tap forms a “front” with the hot water, and must be mixed more evenly throughout the bath for a comfortable equilibrium.
So a succession of deep Atlantic low pressure systems, steered by a strong high level jet stream in the upper atmosphere, where winds are also driven by strong contrasting temperatures, has brought very wet and windy weather to the UK over the last month.
The run of stormy and wet yet mild weather has made this December feel very different to recent winters. In the UK, December 2013 was more than 1.5°C warmer than average, while December 2010 was more than 3.5°C colder than average as the entire country shivered in snow and freezing temperatures.
In fact the wet and relatively mild weather arriving from the Atlantic is more typical of British weather. But the depth of the Atlantic lows this winter has been unusual. On Christmas Eve as cyclone Dirk made landfall in Scotland, the the barometric pressure recorded in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis was 936.8 millibar, the lowest recorded anywhere in the UK since 1886.
At the University of Reading Met Department Observatory rainfall has also been quite unusual. A whole winter’s worth of rain, 162.3mm, has fallen in just three weeks. Only another 1.1mm of rainfall – which looks likely – would break the record for the wettest consecutive 24-day period at any time of the year, 163.3mm recorded in late October 2000.
These very active weather depressions have wrought widespread damage and problems from wind and flooding. Winds have been strong, but not exceptionally so, with gusts of up to 90-100mph on the coast and 70mph inland. But the relentless rain has saturated the ground, and flooding has again been a major issue affecting many parts of the country. Southern and western coasts have also had to cope with inundations from the sea as, swept by the long run of strong winds across the Atlantic, strong sea surges boosted by high spring tides have challenged coastal flood defences.
So why has this winter started off so stormy, while other recent winters have been much more calm, and others frozen? Of course, the variability of weather from year to year and month to month is normal for the UK – we all know how changeable our weather can be.
Whether the storms hit us or miss us is due to the path of the high level jet stream. But there is an added level of complexity, because the storms themselves influence where the temperature gradient is strongest and the position of the jet stream (meteorologists call this “internal dynamics”). So it’s very hard to predict exactly where the storms will be beyond the next five to ten days.
Interestingly, winter storms in the UK tend to arrive in ten or 20-year cycles. For example, during the 1980s and 1990s there were more frequent periods when storms tracked across the UK, bringing mild and wet weather. But during the 1950s and 1960s the opposite was true, with more years when storms missed the UK to the north or south, bringing colder, icier winters. A “stormy phase” doesn’t mean that every winter will be stormy, it just increases the chances.
Superimposed on natural weather variations is climate change. It’s clear that over the past century the UK has warmed, as have many other regions. Between 1961-2006, winter temperatures rose on average by more than 1°C. A warmer atmosphere holds more moisture, providing fuel for heavier rainfall. There’s already evidence of heavier rainfall over the UK and Europe, increasing the risks of flooding. Sea levels are also rising as the oceans warm, and this will also add to coastal flood risk.
Storminess itself is harder to predict and forecasts of future changes vary considerably between models. University of Reading scientists have looked at results from the latest suite of climate models and found indications of a slight increase in the number of UK storms, but climate model projections are quite uncertain in this regard. While we don’t know exactly if storms will become more frequent in coming decades, we do know that their impact is likely to become more severe when combined with the effects of a warming world and higher sea levels.
Written with input from and thanks to Dr Andrew Barrett, Professor Richard Allan, and Kathy Maskell of the University of Reading’s Department of Meteorology and Walker Institute for Climate System Research.

title: Further flooding expected as UK gets back to work
author: Blake Welton
description: Flooding is "expected" across almost every region in England and Wales as strong winds and large waves continue to batter the UK
text:
Strong winds and large waves are expected to cause further coastal flooding today.
The Environment Agency issued one severe flood warning in Dorset - meaning "there is significant risk to life" - and 87 flood warnings where flooding is "expected" across almost every region in England and Wales.
Heavy rain fell across much of the UK last night, with up to 1.6in (40mm) expected on higher ground today.
The Environment Agency estimates about 220 properties have been flooded so far as miles of coastline have been battered and roads and fields across the country are under water.
The Met Office also issued a "be aware" yellow warning for wind as gusts of up to 70mph are expected on the west and south-west coast of Britain and the east coast of Northern Ireland today, causing ''exceptionally high waves''.
The transport network has also been hit, with roads closed and trains delayed or cancelled in many areas.
First Great Western warned passengers there was a risk to services in Cornwall, Devon, Somerset, Wiltshire and Dorset.
The Thames Barrier was in operation last night to protect people and property along the river.
The Environment Agency (EA) urged communities in Dorset and Oxfordshire to remain prepared for ''significant flooding'' in the lower reaches of the Thames, Dorset Stour and Frome rivers.
Ongoing flooding is expected on the Somerset Levels and rivers in the South East, including the Severn, remain ''very high'' after recent rainfall.
Jonathan Day, flood risk manager at the Environment Agency, warned the risk of flooding continued this week.
He said: ''Although high tides are now falling, there remains a risk of coastal flooding, especially on the south and west coasts.
''In addition, wet conditions have left the ground saturated in many areas, increasing the risk of river and surface water flooding.
''We would urge people to be prepared by checking their flood risk, signing up to free flood warnings and keeping an eye on the latest flood updates via the EA website and Twitter.''
The coastal surge in recent days has tested more than 1,864 miles (3,000km) of flood defences in England and more than 205,000 properties have been protected, according to the Environment Agency.
David Cameron pledged lessons will be learned from the flooding and insisted that the Environment Agency has been given the funding to protect frontline services.
The Prime Minister told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: ''We're spending £2.3 billion in this four-year period on flood defences which is more than the previous four-year period.
''We have also enabled them to access other sources of money - partnership funding - so I think we're going to see record levels of spending on flood defences and we have guaranteed that right out into 2020 so they can really plan for the future.''
Mr Cameron added: ''I think flood warnings are better, I think the flood defences have protected tens of thousands of homes but there will always be lessons to learn and I'll make sure they are learned.''
![](https://cdn.jwplayer.com/v2/media/VORcZVNM/poster.jpg)

title: Global warming likely already dangerous, may be irreversible | CBC News
author: Seth Borenstein
description: Global warming is here, human-caused and probably already dangerous — and it's increasingly likely that the heating trend could be irreversible, a draft of a new international science report says.
text:
Climate change impacts 'might already be considered dangerous'
Language stark in latest UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report
![](https://i.cbc.ca/1.2485708.1409147730!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/aptopix-britain-storms.jpg?im=Resize%3D780)
Global warming is here, human-caused and probably already dangerous — and it's increasingly likely that the heating trend could be irreversible, a draft of a new international science report says.
The United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on Monday sent governments a final draft of its synthesis report, which combines three earlier, gigantic documents by the Nobel Prize-winning group. There is little in the report that wasn't in the other more-detailed versions, but the language is more stark and the report attempts to connect the different scientific disciplines studying problems caused by the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal, oil and gas.
The 127-page draft, obtained by The Associated Press, paints a harsh warning of what's causing global warming and what it will do to humans and the environment. It also describes what can be done about it.
![](https://i.cbc.ca/1.2733569.1407785213!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/monsoon-india-drought.jpg?im=)
"Continued emission of greenhouse gases will cause further warming and long-lasting changes in all components of the climate system, increasing the likelihood of severe, pervasive and irreversible impacts for people and ecosystems," the report says. The final report will be issued after governments and scientists go over the draft line by line in an October conference in Copenhagen.
Depending on circumstances and values, "currently observed impacts might already be considered dangerous," the report says. It mentions extreme weather and rising sea levels, such as heat waves, flooding and droughts. It even raises, as an earlier report did, the idea that climate change will worsen violent conflicts and refugee problems and could hinder efforts to grow more food. And ocean acidification, which comes from the added carbon absorbed by oceans, will harm marine life, it says.
Risks high or very high by end of century
Without changes in greenhouse gas emissions, "climate change risks are likely to be high or very high by the end of the 21st century," the report says.
In 2009, countries across the globe set a goal of limiting global warming to about another degree Celsius above current levels. But the report says that it is looking more likely that the world will shoot past that point. Limiting warming to that much is possible but would require dramatic and immediate cuts in carbon dioxide pollution.
The report says if the world continues to spew greenhouse gases at its accelerating rate, it's likely that by mid-century temperatures will increase by about another two degrees compared to temperatures from 1986 to 2005. And by the end of the century, that scenario will bring temperatures that are about 3.7 degrees warmer.
"The report tells us once again what we know with a greater degree of certainty: that climate change is real, it is caused by us, and it is already causing substantial damage to us and our environment," Pennsylvania State University climate scientist Michael Mann wrote in an email. "If there is one take home point of this report it is this: We have to act now."
John Christy of the University of Alabama, Huntsville, is in the tiny minority of scientists who are skeptical of mainstream science's claim that global warming is a major problem. He says people will do OK: "Humans are clever. We shall adapt to whatever happens."
While projections show that the world will warm and climate will change, there's still a level of uncertainty about how much, and that makes the problem all about how much risk we accept, said MIT climate scientist Kerry Emanuel.
If it's soon and only a little risk, he said, that's not too bad, but when you look at the risk curve the other end of it is "very frightening."
The report used the word risk 351 times in just 127 pages.

title: Was Lindsey Graham Just Photographed with Geert Wilders?
author: Dan Evon
description: Wilders is a far-right politician from the Netherlands.
text:
A picture supposedly showing Republican U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham with Geert Wilders, a far-right politician from the Netherlands, was widely shared on social media in March 2021 along with a caption stating that the photograph had "just" been taken:
This is a genuine photograph of Graham and Wilders. However, it was not "just" taken.
Wilders, who has been accused of spreading racist and Islamophobic views (he once compared the Quran to Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf"), posted the photograph to Twitter in September 2019 along, with a caption explaining that it was taken at the Ambrosetti Forum, an annual international economic conference in Italy. Wilders quickly deleted it, but Washington Post reporter John Hudson managed to capture a screenshot of the original post:
Kevin Bishop, a spokesperson for Graham, confirmed at the time that the photograph was real. Bishop said that Graham took pictures with several people at the forum, and that he did not know why Wilders deleted the photograph.
The Washington Post reported at the time:
Kevin Bishop, a spokesman for Graham, said Sunday that the senator took pictures with many of the attendees at the forum and that Graham has no idea why Wilders deleted the tweet with the picture of them.
“Mr. Wilder took a photo with Sen. Graham as did many others at the conference,” Bishop said, adding that he has “no idea why Mr. Wilder removed the photo from Twitter. You may want to ask him.”
This is a genuine photograph of Graham and Wilders. However, it was taken in 2019, not 2021. It should also be noted that being photographed with someone does not automatically mean that you share that person's views.

title: Peaceful protests over George Floyd killing continue in Portland
author: KATU Staff
description: PORTLAND, Ore. – A fifth night of protests got underway in Portland on Tuesday evening denouncing the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed by a white officer in Minneapolis over a week ago. A large group started gathering at Pioneer Courthouse Square at about 5 p. m. and then marched east over the Burnside Bridge. They met up with another large group at 13th and Stark Street for a rally outside Revolution Hall. They have since returned to Pioneer Courthouse Square.
text:
PORTLAND, Ore. – A fifth night of protests got underway in Portland on Tuesday evening denouncing the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed by a white officer in Minneapolis over a week ago.
A large group started gathering at Pioneer Courthouse Square at about 5 p.m. and then marched east over the Burnside Bridge.
They met up with another large group at 13th and Stark Street for a rally outside Revolution Hall. They have since returned to Pioneer Courthouse Square.
Portland police tweeted that things have been peaceful. However, another group near Southwest 4th and Taylor that police said wasn't connected to the peaceful protesters started throwing objects at police at around 9:15 p.m. Police responded with pepper spray and tear gas
. The situation then degraded as police worked to control that crowd. The larger, peaceful, group eventually left the downtown core via the Burnside Bridge.At the Burnside Bridge, thousands of protesters laid down on their stomachs with there hands behind their backs. They did the same thing during Monday night's protest.Thousands assembled during that protest that featured a lengthy march through the city that was largely peaceful.Monday’s protest held a different climate than previous evenings, which were marked with violent clashes, riots, and looting.On Tuesday, there was also a rally held in the Cedar Mill community to address racial injustice and police brutality.Dozens also gathered in Tualatin’s Lake at the Commons park for a rally and march.After four days of protests, a group of volunteers with SOLVE worked to clean up the downtown streets through the day Tuesday.
image_caption: Thousands of protesters march over the Burnside Bridge Tuesday night, June 2, 2020 over the killing of George Floyd by police in Minneapolis. (KATU/Chopper 2);  ;  ;  ;  ;

They met up with another large group at 13th and Stark Street for a rally outside Revolution Hall. They have since returned to Pioneer Courthouse Square.
text:
PORTLAND, Ore. – A fifth night of protests got underway in Portland on Tuesday evening denouncing the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed by a white officer in Minneapolis over a week ago.
A large group started gathering at Pioneer Courthouse Square at about 5 p.m. and then marched east over the Burnside Bridge.
They met up with another large group at 13th and Stark Street for a rally outside Revolution Hall. They have since returned to Pioneer Courthouse Square.
Portland police tweeted that things have been peaceful. However, another group near Southwest 4th and Taylor that police said wasn't connected to the peaceful protesters started throwing objects at police at around 9:15 p.m. Police responded with pepper spray and tear gas
. The situation then degraded as police worked to control that crowd. The larger, peaceful, group eventually left the downtown core via the Burnside Bridge.At the Burnside Bridge, thousands of protesters laid down on their stomachs with there hands behind their backs. They did the same thing during Monday night's protest.Thousands assembled during that protest that featured a lengthy march through the city that was largely peaceful.Monday’s protest held a different climate than previous evenings, which were marked with violent clashes, riots, and looting.On Tuesday, there was also a rally held in the Cedar Mill community to address racial injustice and police brutality.Dozens also gathered in Tualatin’s Lake at the Commons park for a rally and march.After four days of protests, a group of volunteers with SOLVE worked to clean up the downtown streets through the day Tuesday.
image_caption: Thousands of protesters march over the Burnside Bridge Tuesday night, June 2, 2020 over the killing of George Floyd by police in Minneapolis. (KATU/Chopper 2);  ;  ;  ;
